description:
Five stars because the food is always good here. The fish always taste very fresh and yummy. My wife and I dine at Kazu Sushi at least once a week. We like the fact that you don't get all of your order at once. Each order takes some time to prepare which give us opportunity to conversate (and digest) in between. 

Tonight's order; 

Hawaiian Roll (4/5)
Spicy Scallop Roll (5/5)
Saba Shoyaki and side order of rice (5/5) I order this dish every time
Spicy Salmon Nabe (soup) (5/5)

A small mom and pop real Japanese restaurant (one of the few left in SF). Definitely a neighborhood gem. A must try if you don't mind waiting between each of your order for some great food!
author: Tawan G.

description:
EVENT: I'm OFF! It's Friday night and I'm ready to eatttttt something!!!!

SERVICE: it's such a small cute little place... I walk pass here all of the time and always see a bunch of people waiting. Now, I can see why cause it's such a small place.. very home-y. I came here at 5pm and got seated right away! It was fast! Come at 5pm! lol

FOOD:
(1) Salmon Maki: love how they put a big chunk of salmon in a little baby roll! I love maki rolls cause I can eat it with one bite! Mm!
(2) Crispy Spicy Tuna Roll: this is soo unique! So, I had to try! It was an excellent choice!! Crispy crunchies... had the spice of the tuna roll! So good! **recommended**

OVERALL: love the spicy tuna roll... the crispy one... nice crunch to it!
author: Mindy Y.

description: In my opinion the best, and most authentic sushi in SF.  Owner is an awesome guy and really cares about the quality of the fish he serves.  Most times we don't even look at the menu and just ask him to set us up.  He will ask what you like and don't to tailor what he serves you.  Authentic sushi without the "Jiro" attitude.  Highly recommend this spot.
author: Mark W.

description:
Reasonably good-quality stuff, whether their nigiri or their sushi rolls. I came early in the evening and everything seemed fairly fresh and went down smoothly; moreover, there was a good variety of fish on offer. Be adventurous and pick items off the specials board that you haven't had before.

If you're not being served directly by the sushi chefs, then service can be a bit perfunctory. Nevertheless, this is a decent venue for sushi in the Inner Sunset.
author: Vincent L.

description:
It's a small business so it does get crowded on the weekends. We came in on a Saturday night and it was packed but we were seated in less than ten minutes. 

I really like the quality of the fish here, you can see the freshness of it through its opaque color and it has no fishy smell. We ordered a 15-piece sashimi combo, a seafood sunomono salad (not recommended), rainbow roll, and the zig zag roll (very spicy). The food was good but like everyone is saying, be ready to wait 30 minutes in between your orders.

There were two waitress/hosts working but the restaurant is tiny. They were talking to the chefs while a lot of the tables were waiting for the plates lined up to be served on multiple occasions 

It's a good option if Ebisu is busy
author: Lori T.

description:
Honestly, I hesitated in writing this review because I fear that reviewing Kazu will bring ruin it as a "secret" destination.  

We dipped into Kazu on a Monday night where they were having a VERY slow night.  However, their lack of customers was our benefit since we were able to receive a private VIP experience!  

The sushi was ridiculously fresh and each item was plated as a true work of art.  The chef sincerely knows what he's doing here!  The waitress was beyond friendly and took painful care to details.  Both the chef and waitress took time to talk to us not only about the food we were enjoying, but about how we were doing and asked about us.  

The dining room is a bit small here, and may not be great for large groups.  However, the small dining room and peaceful, quiet ambiance is perfect for a date or small group dinner.  

Kazu has promptly been bookmarked and will certainly be one of my "special" sushi destinations!
author: Andrea H.

description: Wonderful staff and wonderful atmosphere + the food was amazing especially the salmon!!!
author: Ernesto E.

description:
I can't understand why they got 3.5 stars.
Bad food, bad service.
I went there with my friends on thrusday. We ordered hamachi toro and salmon toro. They told me it was last order but when it came. It seems like part of a left over and I waited for it so long time. I asked them the waitress said 'it's coming' but it's not!!!
Next day, I and my friend got stomachached.

I think it's very worth.
I glad to recommend if you guys want a new experience.
author: Pajaree S.

description:
Hungry for excellent sushi? Please bring your patience. The problem was the service is slow. It took a while for our food to arrive and we were starving. What made the difference was our waitress checked on us to make sure our tea was filled and whether we needed more beer.
My girlfriend and I ordered the Crunchy Roll,Caterpillar Roll,Dragon Roll and the Rainbow Roll. When it did arrive,the sushi was fresh and delicious.
I highly recommend this place if you are patient and don't mind waiting for delicious sushi.
author: Zardu H.

description:
I am very sorry to do this to an old fav, but there were a few big strike-outs on a recent Friday visit when I brought some friends over for dinner:

-Nigiri rice was way, way too sweet and mushy and warm.
-Strange sinewy cut of maguro on my nigiri
-Strands of hair in agedashi tofu - yikes!
-Fried batter was super limp on agedashi tofu (honestly, whoever cooked it last Friday should be fired)

What happened? I know business isn't always hopping here, but I think it's *especially* important for underrated restaurants to perform at maximum impressiveness at all times. Otherwise you can't win converts, and old fans might find it hard to defend it.
author: Ken H.

description: It's only few place truly know about Japanese food and culture in US sushi restaurant. My most favorite is "Sushi Rice" in here, it's amazingly perfect, plus perfectly pressured and melt after put it in my mouse. I'm born and raised in Osaka Japan, I'm so happy about existing this true Japanese sushi place in Inner Sunset district.
author: Sattee F.

description:
Given that over priced Ebisu is right down the street it doesn't surprise me that this hidden gem of a place is pretty easy to get a seat on a Saturday night. 

Enjoy this place because it is Japanese owned, fresh fish/ingredients and authentic food on the menu & daily specials on the white board. I enjoy the selection of menu Nigiri sushi offered as well as the appetizers. I enjoy the Ika Nato as well and also Uni. 

Good place to drop in & grub, drink tea and have a little conversation with the Sushi chef and waitress. They're all so friendly.
author: John M.

description:
2.5. The service was slow and the rolls were mediocre. The simple rolls (think spicy salmon or avocado roll) were teeny tiny. I could fill all 6-8 rolls in my mouth at once. 

The crunchy roll was good. Everything else was pretty bland. Tuna poke app was pretty good.
author: Kelly G.

description: I actually really liked this small neighborhood spot. Ignore the dirty carpet. The salad, sushi, including the vegetable roll, the chicken meatballs, were all great. Loved the waitress who was a champion juggler. I look forward to returning.
author: Andrew K.

description:
What a great little neighborhood spot.  

Just had their nigiri and im delighted to say the proportions were on point.  The fish all very tasty.

The ambiance very Japanese.

Will try some hot food next time.   

Salmon- solid piece but nothing extravagant. 
Tako - again solid offering
Kani- nothing better than real crab
Otoro- nice helping! 


All flavors very mild.  If you want some traditional sushi.  I highly recommend this place.  

For the money I'd  go here everyone if it wasn't so far from my place
author: Spanky M.

description:
A-OK. Wasn't amazing, wasn't disappointing. 

Ordered the Sake sashimi (came with rice and miso soup) and it was good but it wasn't anything special as it was $24.00... I'd rather go elsewhere to have sake and rice for a fraction of the price. 

My bf ordered the Sushi Combo D, which had a variety of nigiri, cali roll and sashimi. This was $25.00 and I thought it was much more worth it for the price but it still wasn't anything special.

All in all, I didn't think this place was special or amazing enough for me to come back again.
author: Leilani Y.

description: The shop looks okay but their heater is clutch. Service was less than average and sushi could have been made by cubans
author: Amir H.

description:
Hadn't been here in probably over a year. Boy, has this place changed! Totally uninteresting sushi (in particular the salmon skin roll which was completely tasteless). Had made up my mind not to make the effort to come back (I don't live in the neighborhood) but what cinched it was when the waitress came to tell me my credit card didn't work. I explained to her that there is a problem with the chip and that she had to enter the number by hand.  She came back again and said it didn't work. I gave her another card but I know the original worked because I had used it less than an hour before and used it again at Walgreens on the way home.
Bad sushi+ bad service= bad review
author: Francoise F.

description: I love Kazu -- excellent sushi, good service, and almost always no wait for a table! In my opinion, the quality of the sushi is better than Ebisu (which is around the corner), and it is less expensive. It's a mystery to me why this restaurant is not more popular. My only caveat is to only order sushi and quick stuff like miso soup. Once I made the mistake of ordering potstickers as an appetizer and they came out thirty minutes after we had finished our sushi.
author: Claire K.

description:
Highlights
- Opened late night and on a Monday too
- Cozy spot with about 5 tables and sushi bar seating
- Not crowded and no wait around 8:30pm
- Traditional feel with Japanese speaking waitress and sushi chef
- Crunch roll: my favorite toll with spicy tuna, avocado, and topped with crunchy flakes
- Spider roll: One of the best I've had. One of the classics that I tend to order and judge a restaurant by. There is an evident amount of soft shelled crab wrapped in a pretty large roll with plenty of veggies.
- Service was very attentive, not over bearing, and efficient

Improvements
- None really, their rolls aren't as long as other sushi restaurants, but the quality and taste is evident. This matters more to me than quantity.
- Hamachi dragon: Nothing special, it was good and fish was fresh, but I would probably try something else and not order this next time.

Tips
- Parking is hard around prime lunch and dinner time. Only metered and residential street parking.
author: Tracy T.

description:
So I had to call the cops on the employees/manager  because apparently sending sushi back that I didn't like was a big deal. Manager physically touched me hand his hand on my shoulder for a few and on top of that manager kept clapping  in my face while yelling at me saying that I'm being childish that I didn't like their salmon. Alright so here's the deal. These cry babies over here decided to surround my table. Then this lady buts in and puts her two sense in while sitting at the bar and have the sushi chef screaming from behind the sushi bar. 
Professionalism guys. Professionalism. Lol

Food: Chicken that  Ordered is what gave this place that 1 little itty bitty star.

So I get there around 10. My partner and I end up ordering two sushi rolls and a bunch of little things.
My partner didn't like the sushi roll she ordered so she had let the server know. Server said " would you like to try the smoke salmon to compare" 
She said "yeah I'll like to taste a small piece " MIND YOU.. A TASTE . He came back with a whole nigiri smokes salmon. 
So she took a bite but it still tasted the same and she just put it back on the plate.  Told him she wasn't interested and he brought back the menu for a new order. 
THEN ASKED ME TO EAT HER ROLL BECAUSE SHE DIDNT WANT IT.  Hold up? Did you just ask me to eat somebody else's roll because they didn't like it? 

We asked for the check and they brought the check still charging us for the entire roll we didn't even eat & for the nigri that was a "taste". 

So we let them know there was a mistake on the bill. They said no we need to stop acting childish because we didn't like the roll we needed to pay for it. 

Then oh best part -maybe because we are lesbians lol because apparently we are the ONNYYY PEOPLE EVER TO COMPLAIN. literally ever.  Lady even said " because some people like to complain"

It's our fault for "complaining" that we didn't like the food. 
Seriously ? We took 1 bite of the sushi and we didn't like the way the salmon tasted but it's our fault because we are the only ones tasting it and sending it back. And lol their sushi chef also tasted the same sushi we sent back ... Yeah I'm sure.  
Then the manager tells me to pay for the whole meal. Excuse you/ this is not my meal. So don't touch me. don't ask me for my debit card because you wanna charge the whole bill because I'm a "friend". 
I Said no, so they said they were going to call the cops. Then that's where the whole clapping in my face and touching my shoulders came into play. I said screw that . Called the police department on my own. You don't touch your  customers. 
So  I called SFPD they came. Right before they got there the other lady asks " what time they getting here" I said "maybe soon?"
So she tosses the bill on the table again and asks me to pay for the whole thing. I said no. 
So SFPD got there. We settled it by paying for 1 sushi out of a whole roll $6 because apparently that's how much 1 sushi out of the roll costs 

So congrats Guys! Better make sure you like your food if not then your gunna pay for the whole entire plate even if they threw the whole plate away. Oh and if they accommodate a "taste" your paying for a whole other plate too.



When I was walking out I told them never to touch or clap in other customers faces
The lady server screams " don't come back"
I said aight. 

Trust me. Yelp does goes a long way especially since this is one of the first one stars y'all got. 
Congrats for looking stupid also. :)
author: Gabriela C.

description:
Small little sushi place. They have probably about 8 tables and some bar seats and one waiter for the entire place. I came here on a Saturday night so obviously it was packed. Service was extremely slow but I don't blame the waiter because it was basically him running the whole place. It took at least 10 minutes for someone to even come to the table.

Got the Hawaiian, Yamekekee, and double double roll. Sushi wasn't too bad, but not great. Nothing was memorable enough to come back.
author: Tanya Y.

description:
Just one step up from being a hole in the wall, in a crowded market: Ebisu and Koo are slightly better, slightly more expensive, and slightly more crowded. This is where my wife and I come regularly, alternating with Koo. It's smaller, more down-to-earth in cuisine and decor (though Koo is nothing fancy); it's definitely less trendy than Ebisu (a plus in my book).

We're very lucky that in San Francisco, this is the neighborhood joint around the corner. We've eaten there a half dozen times, and we intend to continue. Highly recommended for authenticity, by our Japanese contractor.

Everything you would expect, nothing else. Specials shown on a portable whiteboard they bring to whoever sat down most recently. High quality fish, thoughtful preparation, decent portions. Nothing to complain about.

A few interesting items, such as the cod roe on grated daikon (pictured). The daikon is fresh and strong. 

It looks like a mom and pop operation, so service is a bit slow.
author: Frank W.

description:
Another Yelper described it best, "good sushi with mediocre and disorganized service."  This was our experience tonight.  We were actually trying to eat at Ebisu, but the wait would have probably been 20-30 minutes, which we were not willing to wait since our time was limited.  Yes, I am fully aware that it is a Saturday night.  So, that's how we decided to give this place a try.

We ordered mostly from their specials board:
otoro and fatty salmon sashimi ($15/$7.95-2 pcs ea.)
spicy salmon nabe
spicy salmon tempura roll (4 pcs)
From their menu: zigzag roll (4 pcs)

Everything was good but the spicy salmon nabe was the standout.  The broth was just the right level of spicy (at least for us) and the salmon was tasty and not overcooked.  Yay.  Still trying to figure out how much MSG was in the broth.  Fortunately, I'm not feeling thirsty, so that's a plus.

Although he was nice, our waiter didn't really check on us and he seemed easily overwhelmed.  He brought out a sushi roll that wasn't ours and had to try catching his attention which was surprisingly tough given how tiny that restaurant is.  I had to ask someone else for a tea refill.

Overall: 4 stars for food; 3 stars for service
author: Wendy K.

description: Still the best sushi in town. Great prices, generous pieces and some of the best tasting nigiri you will find in town. After 10 years it is still my mainstay.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Pretty decent sushi for good prices. It's at a higher level than your regular rolls place, but at a better price than most omakase places. The dining room is small so either come early or make a reservation!

The chef and assistant are very nice. Service can be slow (especially on a Monday) because they're kind of short handed. But they're very gracious and not pretentious at all. Sit at the bar (duh) and get the omakase. The pieces are really big so I guess it counter balances the long wait between each piece. Plus you can chat up the chef. He's nice!
author: Sherry L.

description: I live in the neighborhood and had passed this place so many times I can't count, and finally did my research on it in an attempt to find a Japanese option for dinner for a couple girlfriends and I. These few blocks of the inner sunset have definitely no shortage of sushi spots, but this is a great option if you want something more authentic and cozy than the rest. We all ordered the Moriawase, which was a very filling chef's choice assortment of sashimi. So yummy it harkened the days we spent eating our way thru Japan. And at a little over $30 after Rex and tip pp, not too shabby. I also think they're a mom-and-pop joint so I'm all for supporting their business. Very short wait for a table on a Friday night, which is a huge bonus (it was crazy at ebisu).
author: Vivian H.

description:
Fabulous vegan sushi! Asparagus tempura nigiri was perfect and cute. I highly recommend the veggie crunch and sitting at the bar.

You can definitely satisfy herbivores and omnivores alike at this establishment. Good place for a date night or night out with friends.
author: Nissa K.

description:
This place is small and unpretentious. The servers didn't interact with me much. It was a rather quiet meal with little interaction with the servers from the bar on which we were sitting. I tried the double double roll due to popular talk about it on Yelp. It was fresh and simple but not particularly memorable. I also tried a tofu dish that I thought was overpriced. 

Getting a table here for more than 4 people can be difficult because it is so small. I'd advise making reservations if possible.
author: Brenda L.

description: The epicness or epic fail you receive at your door (via Door Dash), seems to depend on who the sushi chef is that night. The last time we ordered, we received the latter. Im breakin' up with you, Kazu. Sad, but true.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
I came here with my boyfriend for a birthday celebration and at most, it was just ok. The buta was gooood. The ankimo was only 3 slices, which i feel was a rip off since they were expensive but weren't overtly amazing. The sashimi plate we got was good and bad. The tuna was clearly frozen from the night before and served the day after because it was grainy and unappetizing. I loved the uni the most. Delicious and tasty, it was a good turn around from the tuna. But the thing that lowered my rating was the rice. I swear that rice was old. It smelled old and it took me a small taste to know that. Both my boyfriend and I had tummy aches today and I really want to say it was that rice. 

The service was good. But man, oh man, that rice is keeping me from wanting to go back again.
author: Pamela B.

description:
Cute little sushi house on Irving.  

Parking is KILLER.  The hamachi kama is cooked perfectly, seasoned right and as big as my head.  Note: my head is BIG.  Great sashimi salad, but instead of iceburg, who uses that anymore, try mixed greens like everyone else.  Passable nigiri.  Firm for my taste.  Great rice. The one roll we had was quite good, very clean, no sauces and it was cooked, King Kong.
author: Cynthia C.

description: This is the real Japanese sushi restaurant in SF. I'm from Japan so I'm very picky when it comes to Japanese food. But this restaurant is owned by Japanese couple. The food is perfect. I can recall real Japanese food back in Japan. They also serve some Californian rolls and stuff, if you like American Japanese food. But I do recommend you to have some real Japanese food here, without avocado in it
author: Seika R.

description: Sushi is fresh and rolls are good!  Stick to the sushi and rolls, the cooked is not as good.  Place is small, so may get crowded.
author: E F.

description:
Today. April 15. In the year 2014. My mother, boyfriend, and I decided to take a risk. Not just any risk, but a risk to try out a new Japanese restaurant. Seriousness to the max.

Their ambience was quite "Japanesie" if I do say so myself. This is a traditional Japanese restaurant; mainly sushi and sushi rolls, and maybe a couple of entrees. 

The fish was undoubtedly fresh, but not the best that I've had. From my experience, I think Ebisu has better quality fish. But anyhow, back to my review of Kazu!

-Ankimo ($8.75): OMG THIS IS A MUST GET. 6 STARS OUT OF 5. Yes it is THAT good. They made this monk fish liver pate so smooth that it instantly melts in your mouth. The flavor is simply amazing and UUUGH I wanted more. The only down side is that it only comes with 3 pieces =/ it's slightly larger than most places, but still I think it is a bit overpriced for that little amount. But I would still get it next time just because it is SO FREAKIN AMAZING!

-Fresh Aji ($8.95): definitely fresh! Did not have much taste to it but it is without a doubt quality fish

-Fresh Uni ($7.95): fresh and amazing flavors! Again, very fresh and just the right amount of uni:rice ratio.

-Moriawase ($25): cames with fresh salmon, albacore, saba, octopus, hamachi, kanpachi, and tuna. Like I said earlier, all the fish is extremely fresh! That was it though. For me, the quality is better than other sushi places, but not quite up there like Ebisu. (Sorry for comparing Kazu with Ebisu again)

-Double Double ($12.50): "Spicy salmon, avocado, and cucumber wrapped with fresh salmon and mango layers topped with spicy sesame chili sauce". This was a very delicious roll! I would definitely order this again and I think you should give this a try too if you like salmon! It just has a hint of spice, so for the people out there who can't take spicy food like me, this should be fine for you (: 

-Hamachi Dragon ($13): it has shrimp tempura on the inside and hamachi/avocado on the outside. This roll was not my favorite, but it was still pretty decent. However, my boyfriend and my mom both liked this more than the double double, so idk...haha. Everyone has different tastes I guess :P
author: Jackie T.

description:
Kazu is quite an experience.

I don't really get when people want sushi and don't try the sashimi and get rolls. I believe a good sashimi is a great indicator on if the spot is a great sushi spot or not. 

I came here to Kazu and got almost everything I could. I had the fatty tuna, chicken wing, mackerel, anchovy -ish fish, nabe, and crab ramen.

The nabe was amazing - i have never seen or heard of this at any sushi spot. It was great to try on chilly day.

The crab ramen was amazing- top off with fresh and REAL seaweed and crab. It was definitely different than any other ramen I have had, and not as rich as Izakaya sozai's but light and delicious. 

All the fish I had at Kazu was fresh and tasty and I would try to list all the names of the things I ate, but I believe at Kazu the menu can change quite frequently so it wouldnt even matter if I did list them all. Yes they may not have chirashi bowl but if you just pick 7-8 pieces of fish with some rice you can make your own chirashi bowl.

Parking is difficult but hopefully you have good parking karma or try to go up or down 2-3 blocks.
author: Grace C.

description:
Here's my list of things to get:

Hamachi Toro
Uni
Chu Toro
Salmon Toro
Ankimo
Zig zag: Their version of the spider roll
Croquettes
Porkbelly
Miso seabass
Veggie Dragon Roll: Fried green bean tempura with eggplant and avocado
Spicy Salmon Dragon Roll

Here's the thing, I love this place in general. I really like their zig zag roll and their veggie dragon where I find the flavor to be unique. The fish is always fresh, and their miso seabass is my favorite in the Bay Area. I've been coming here consistently for 3 years now. When I was doing my graduate studies, my classmates and I would come here every other week. The only con that I can see is that since this place is small, the refills on tea can be a long wait, and the dishes can take a while to get to your table. This can be a problem when I just had a jalapeño on a spicy roll, and I'm burning up inside. Other than that, they've always been pleasant.
author: Jack R.

description:
I had hopes. I had dreams. They were thrown in the floor and stomped on. With stilettos. In the rain. :(

The sushi itself was good. Overpriced. But good. The service was downright awful and non existent. We weren't greeted at the door. When we were finally acknowledged it was to be shoved out the way. When we sat down we got no plates, no tray for soy sauce, no love. I asked four times for ginger. It came at the end of the meal. I asked for my salad I ordered for an app. It came at the end. 

I should have taken the cash and gone toe busy for that price.
author: Michelle I.

description: I'm pretty impressed with Kazu's sake (salmon) and hamachi (yellowtail) nigiri. The cuts and quality of fish were very reasonable considering the price. What disappointed me was the rice...it was definitely not sushi rice and belongs only in a bowl. But again, at this price point, I shouldn't expect anything better. I am, however, a fan of their hamachi and kanpachi kama. Not many Japanese sushi restaurants offer both. Could definitely live without their toro, but the rolls are decent.
author: Tiffany H.

description:
I walked in there late on a Monday night so I decided to do take out instead of dining there. I ordered the spicy roll with yellowtail and the King Kong roll to go. I thought they were both amazing and I look forward to coming here for a sit down dinner. 

It's a quiet cozy little place with a nice atmosphere. Not very many tables so I wouldn't be surprised if one would have to wait for a table. 

The staff there came off as very polite and accommodating. I can't wait to try this place on the weekend
author: Nic P.

description:
I have been here three times and every time the sushi is tasty. The seafood is always fresh. The uni was buttery and bursting with flavor. The hamachi toro was huge. The restaurant is a small and there is only one sushi chef and one waitress so there is a bit of a wait for the food. However, the wait is worth it when you can taste the different layers of flavor that each sushi roll is given. For example, the spicy scallop roll had cilantro paired with a sweet and spicy sauce all wrapped in the roll with the scallop and not on top of the roll. 

I read a review below about the waitress and the table not receiving their miso soup. I understand that people love their miso soup but don't go to a sushi restaurant and order miso soup. All that does is fill you up and then you can't enjoy the sushi.
author: Patricia I.

description:
Always a great place for dinner.
We had the Omakase this last time.  Delicious fish.  There was a bit too much wasabi in the beginning, but I eventually got used to it.  My mom loves the Salmon Sashimi Dinner.  Comes with decent amount of salmon pieces, and very fresh.  The cooked rolls are pretty good too, although not a lot to choose from.
author: Karen L.

description:
We ordered sushi for pick up and it was made quickly and service was ok. So no problem there.


We got home and everything we ordered was simply bad. A simply rainbow roll had sushi that was clearly nearly frozen or bad. The sashimi platter had bad pieces as well and you could taste the fish wasn't fresh at all.

Ahi poke had its own special flavor that no Japanese food that I ever ate had before. To be clear... It sucked.

The only good thing was Pot stickers, which I guess is impossible to screw up.

Overall... Probably he worst sushi ever and we threw away 80% of it. Really disappointing.
author: Paul K.

description: My first and last time dining here. The service was attentive, but the fish wasn't fresh. All the fish in the rolls and nigiri, representative of different types of fish, tasted and looked dried out. We were fooled into trying it because the restaurant was half full when we walked by. Sorry but I've had fresher fish in rolls from Safeway.
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description: Food is great. Ultimate Crunchy tuna sushi is fantastic but service is questionable. There were seats available but they didn't want to let two people to sit at a table for four, even though there were no other people coming in at the time! WTF!
author: Jin N.

description:
Complete disappointment and utterly dismayed -- those are the lingering feeling after a meal at Kazu Sushi. I had such high hopes for Kazu Sushi, Being in the vicinity of great sushi restaurants, like Ebisu and Koo, Kazu Sushi had to be just as good to receive 4 stars from Yelp. Sadly this was not the case. 

Since I could not think straight from the hunger, I decided to opt for omakase. Received the Chu Toro, Salmon Toro, Hamachi Toro, Kanpachi, Kurodai, Aji, Alaskan Wild Salmon, Uni, and Japanese scallop. The fish quality and freshness was okay, nothing repulsive and stinky but not worth the price. Worst part was not the overpriced fish but the apathy. The first three pieces came out very quickly then there was a long long pause. Then the long pause became more frequent, after every piece. Dinner took over two hours. I left still hungry but was too impatient to wait for another piece.
author: Andrew W.

description:
The bf was craving sushi and since I had to find a restaurant, I wanted to find a Japanese restaurant that also serves grilled squid.  Bingo!  Kazu has it all.

Sashimi (variety plate)-  Wow, who knew this tiny, unknown sushi place served such fresh sashimi.  You could tell a lot of lovin' was put into this dish.

Chicken Karage- I've had my fair share of chicken karage and THIS is the best freakin chicken karage evarr!  I might not have 21 million reviews or 56 billion friends but I know good food and you have to trust me on this!  It's soft yet crispy, flavorful but not overpowering, and the right amount of grease.  

Ultimate Crispy Spicy Tuna Roll and Hamachi Dragon- I enjoyed the Ultimate roll over the Hamachi because it had more flavor but since these rolls were big, stuffing the whole thing in my mouth mushed everything together and they both ended up tasting the same.  The spice really made the difference.

Grilled Squid- Four words described my initial impression as they placed the plate on our table:  King Calamari is dead.  From the tentacles to the head, everything was nicely plated.  The only issue I had with this was that it wasn't grilled as much as I would have liked it to be.  It was semi-grilled, semi raw.  Lemon wedges were not included so make sure you ask for some.

I would come back ONLY for the sashimi and chicken karage.
author: Linda N.

description:
My friend and I went here for a small dinner today. We were both craving sushi and we heard this place was pretty good.

The place itself is pretty small but quaint. The decor is a mix between modern and traditional Japanese style. My friend and I sat by the window. 

When our waitress gave us our menus, she asked us what we would like to drink. We just went for water. I thought it was strange that they didn't provide complementary tea like most places do, but I shrugged it off. 

Looking through the menu, I saw a little notation on the bottom that said to check out their daily specials on their white board. I kept looking around for it and asked my friend if she saw it (she didn't). I guess I talk too loud because our waitress came back to put the white board next to us. The peculiar thing about the special menu was that....the prices were the same as what was in the menu. Hmm...

What I liked about their menu was that there was a lot of variety (and they have cute names for some of their items). They had items on their menu that I don't typically see in other sushi shops. 

We ended up ordering one ikayaki (grilled squid), a yamakake roll, and a double double roll. The grilled squid was delicious, the double double roll was delicious, and the yamakake roll was okay. It was plain in taste but it was the prettiest in presentation. Each item was priced around $10.

What I liked about everything was that it was all very fresh tasting and well made. My friend wasn't as satisfied as I was, but I think it's because she didn't like her yamakake roll. 

Our waitress was a bit slow and didn't check up on us that often even though we were one of the only groups (out of two) that were in the shop. She took forever getting our check to us too, but I guess it wasn't that big of a deal. We just had to get her attention.

I would go here again just because this has been the best sushi place that I've been to ever.
author: Sofia R.

description: Very friendly staff, even when we ran in at the end of the night, hungry and tired. Hot sake and tasty rolls. Quaint little joint in the Sunset. Yum.
author: Zara S.

description: Amazing Resteraunt!!! Wonderful family, great hole in the wall with the best sashimi you ever had!!!
author: Marsha B.

description:
This place is real good... You wanna know why? It's because there were actually Japanese people eating here. I hardly see the real real Japanese people eating a sushi spots so when you see them eating here, you know it's good.

So to not sound too foreign in front of the Japanese customers,  I ordered the simple rolls (no rainbow raider or Philadelphia sugar roll) this was simple tuna and or salmon roll... Along with some sashimi.

So excited when it came cause I was super hungry, I was glad that the sushi came in my mouth and bursted with good flavor. The rice and sushi complimented well and was done right and the added tuna and salmon just complimented it more. 

A must try? I think so!
author: Ladonna A.

description: My boyfriend and I were very impressed with this sushi joint!  We ordered the seaweed salad, miso soup, gyozas, hamachi dragon roll, crunchy roll, and vegetable tempura roll.  There wasn't anything we didn't love.  You know it's good when your boyfriend, who normally doesn't love sushi, orders a second round of rolls because he loved them so much.
author: Jessica K.

description:
Wow, a Japanese restaurant that's actually owned by Japanese people.

The omakase here is not bad. It's definitely not as pricey as some other places that are now featuring omakase. You can choose however many pieces you want so whether you're a small or big eater. It works. The service is very nice and prompt. The place is a little small but even coming here on a Friday night had no wait.

Overall, I would totally come here again.
author: edward k.

description:
I love food. And I never really care about service. If the service sucks, just don't tip them good. But I've never had service ruin a meal until I came to this restaurant.

I came here on a Saturday with my cousin. We walked in and were told it would be a half hour wait (even though we were second on the list and a table just left). We waited 5 minutes in the cold outside before they started cleaning the empty table. After ten minutes the table remained vacant and ANOTHER table paid and left. After another ten minutes, we finally get sat at the first table that was cleaned 20 minutes ago...

We sat down, and it took a while until they came up to us to take our order. Once the order came, we had to ask for soy sauce plates. TWICE. At any other sushi restaurant, the soy sauce dish should've already been at the table.

The food was actually pretty good. It was my first time trying ankimo, which I really liked. I had the King Kong roll, and the Double Double, which were both really tasty. I also ordered amaebi but it didn't taste that fresh.

After we finished our food, the waitress brought our check. And I realized that we never got the fried shrimp heads that come with amaebi, which is the BEST PART. We tell the waitress, and she asks if we still want it? OF COURSE WE WANT IT.

After five minutes, she brings out ONE fried shrimp head when one order should come with two. I had to ask for the tempura sauce to dip in, which took another five minutes to bring out. When they brought it out, it was only enough sauce for one dip. I was really frustrated at this point.

I tipped a little less than 15%. I am a server so I know a lot about service, but it didn't even seem like the waitresses were trying. One of them just stood by the register the entire time doing nothing.

I wanted to give this place one star but I don't want to be those snobby people who don't give credit where it's deserved. The food was good, but the service ruined it.
author: Derek T.

description: I ordered for pick-up and after a 20 minute ride home, my food was completely cold, and it wasn't even that good. The tempura was pathetic and this meal did not satisfy my craving like I wanted it to. Best words to describe this place is mediocre and overpriced.
author: Julia A.

description:
Ehhh. Came here trying to explore some of the new eateries near my new apartment in SF and wasn't too impressed :( 

To start, our tea came out luke warm, and the rest of our appetizers didn't seem...too authentic.  Our chicken karaage was a bit soggy, the sunomono salad was a little too sour, and the sushi wasn't as fresh as I would've liked. It's a bit on the pricey side as well, so I was disappointed with the quality of food for the price. 

Overall, it was mediocre.  If you're craving sushi and in the area and all the other places have long waits (which is very typical of inner sunset), I guess you can come here. But don't order too many appetizers off the regular sushi menu! Wasn't impressed :(
author: Steph S.

description:
Good sashimi, and a cozy little restaurant. Oh, and they're one of the few restaurants I've found in the city that serves tamago warm, which I strongly prefer to chilled tamago. 

While I enjoyed my food, I had to dock two stars for service. It wasn't that crowded when I came here with my girlfriend, but we felt ignored the entire time, to the point where another server completely took over for our waitress as we were trying to wrap up our meal. It's also a tad pricey compared to other restaurants with comparable quality.  

I'll update my review next time I'm back if this improves.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
I've come here a handful of times and thought the food was pretty good quality. However, this last visit, I will never ever return.

Arrive 7pm with my boyfriend, dad and daughter. We ordered a handful of things:

- hawaiian roll
- miso soup & seaweed soup
- tempura
- ankimo
- hamachi dinner (suppose to include miso soup + rice)
- 2 hamachi collars.

Simple enough right? wrong. First off, she brings everything out of order. hamachi dinner first with the rice, no soup. then the hawaiian roll w/ ankimo, no soup still. every time she passed our table "excuse me, but may we get our soups please?". She either forgets or just ignores us. Either way she brings everything out in 30-minute increments. I must've asked her 5x before she brought each item... always missing the accompanying side dish - rice or soup. So the whole dinner was either eating rice w/ nothing. Or my main dish with nothing. Worst part, it is 8:35pm.. no hamachi collars. When I asked if they are coming or I'm going to cancel it, she brings 1 out, the 2nd 15 minutes later. I asked her can I please get a hot bowl of rice since I've been waiting for an hour for these fishes. She takes my half filled rice bowl, heats it up in a microwave and gives it back. This lady couldn't even give me fresh bowl of rice??! Left the restaurant pass 9pm...

This was the most stressful dinner ever... over 2 hours attempting to flag a waitress running around with her head cut off. And to add insult to injury... charged us for the soup she never brought out. By that time we just paid for it, didn't want to bother waiting for her to fix the check.
author: Crystal S.

description: Overpriced sushi. I understand that SF food can be a bit pricey, but I've definitely had better sushi in the area. The menu has a good amount of variety and the place wasn't too crowded on a Saturday night for dinner. The overall quality of fish was not very impressive and  neither was the service. We had to ask for a bowl of rice 3 times and our miso soup did not not come until the end of the meal, after had long been consumned.
author: Christy K.

description: I've wanted to try this joint for the last 12 months and am so glad I finally did. Amazingly fresh, melt-in-your-mouth fish. Great service. Warm, intimate vibe. Will definitely be back.
author: Gemma B.

description:
DO NOT EAT HERE.  Straight up nasty.
Veggie sushi desired?  Go to 5 stars Ebisu around the corner!!!!! 
Kazu had disgracefully stale sushi rice and veggies.  The Nori tasted like cardboard.  We received exceptionally rude service when I called to report the very bad quality.  Being vegan, we enjoy veggie sushi to go from many places that is screaming fresh but I wanted to try Kazu because of their selection.
Let me repeat...straight up nasty.  When we called to tell them, the guy that was to help us just yelled saying he worked for some acronym. I guess that should have resolved the nastiness.  It didn't and $44 was wasted.  I made soup and took too long to post this review.
author: Renee C.

description:
After reading the good reviews, I decided to give Kazu a try. I was craving for some good quality sashimi and sushi, and Kazu promised just that. 
When we arrived, we were glad to find no line (it was a saturday night). The watiress was friendly and quickly seated us by the counter. We ordered a sashimi platter, uni with quail egg sushi and a slow cooked pork belly. The sashimi and sushi was good, but I have had better.  The pork belly was flavorless and the texture was rough. We almost left it untouched. The bill was around $55. The food was decent, and the main disappointment was the pork belly. Maybe for this reason, I felt underwhelmed by this place.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Kazu is the real deal -- authentic, small, a perfect neighborhood Japanese restaurant. We absolutely loved the personal service and even got to meet Kazu himself. 

We sat at the sushi bar and enjoyed salmon toro, some of the best kampachi I've had, great rolls, and an exquisitely grilled salmon. 

Gluten free notes: They know what gluten is and have tamari. Fish is naturally gluten-free.
author: Ellie P.

description:
OMAKASE? HAIIIIII! (YESSSSSS!)

Having gone to Kazu Sushi four years ago and not having much of a memorable experience (probably because I went with my scrub-a-dud ex), I didn't have high expectations the second time around. However, when my friend and I went this past Friday, I was AMAZED with their Omakase (similar to a chef's tasting menu).

First things first, Kazu Sushi is small (~28 people) so make a reservation and sit at the sushi bar. Also, parking is a biatchhhhhh so allow an extra 15 minutes for parking.  

F O O D
Aside from both Traditional and Americanized Sushi, Kazu has Izakaya (Japanese Tapas) and Tataki (Seared/Grilled) items on the menu. There's no Bento Boxes on the menu. 

*OMAKASE (8 piece - $27.50) - 4.5 STARS
The beauty of the Omakase at Kazu is that you can customize one to your own budget. 

As we wanted to try other rolls and sushi on the menu, we opted for the 8-piece Omakase which was a bargain considering the specialty selection of fish we were given. 
1. Hotate (Raw Scallops): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=GcTXnqttWC0pgXAbHVVTrA
2. Abura Ahi (Hawaiian Big Eye Tuna) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=0K3YQ1rWZVLXHTn5cRBJ0w
3. Wild Sake (Wild Salmon): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=nmOExIf82DBCfCUz0OEJow
4. Tai (Red Snapper): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=4DOgXfuzo3Ao1jGCMTGoZA
5. Sake Toro (Salmon Belly): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=ECAbV4uLuKSRL0LWKgLzKQ
6. Maguro Toro (Tuna Belly): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=IEBKCQDYn6wfQNTa3sN6lw
7. Hamachi (Yellow Tail): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=wFBJ7x3DFyATSEy2_6S8hw
8. Unagi (Freshwater Eel): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=YIb5nnM9pwlbJgEnZZbM8A

With each flip and turn, my eyes glistened with anticipation as I waited for Kazu-San (Chef/Owner) to present us with the beautifully molded nigiri. The shari (rice component) was nicely seasoned with just the right sticky consistency while the neta (fish) was artistically cut and laid on top. Like silk, each amazingly fresh neta melted on my tongue like a triple cream butter. Clean and unadulterated, the omakase nigiri was a SUSHGASMIC experience!

*ANKIMO - Monkfish Liver ($8.95) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=A0PMpNvI8CaWzuqo9ec7wA
Like foie gras of the sea, the ankimo was decadently rich with a kiss from the fresh ocean sea. The ponzu brightened up the ankimo with a subtle salty citrusy punch. 

*UNI NIGIRI w/ Quail Egg ($7 + $1) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=YYfBWP5EUmrDYcqjQ3tltQ
My test for all sushi restaurants, Kazu passed with flying colors. The uni was divine with a custardy texture and an intense hit of fresh brine which followed with a buttery sweetness on my palate. 

*DOUBLE DOUBLE SPICY SALMON ROLL: Spicy Salmon & Avocado Wrapped w/Fresh Salmon Topped w/ Mango & Spicy Sesame Chili Sauce ($13) - 4 STARS
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=9Wk3aJwOYx01D_9GsHE0vQ
Not being a fan of most Americanized rolls (you know the ones suffocating in the gawd awful orange glop masking the borderline rancid fish), I thoroughly enjoyed this roll. The unique combination of ingredients worked surprisingly well with one another. The buttery salmon and ripen avocado paired along with the mango slices and the spicy sesame sauce was a fiery umami sensation in my mouth. 

S E R V I C E
Keeping with the traditional Japanese hospitality fashion, Kazu-San and staff were very welcoming and pleasant. 

Sitting at the corner of the sushi bar did compromise service a bit as we had to flag down our waitress for things such as green tea refills. We were also charged with a roll we never received but it was quickly resolved after bringing it to their attention. Had the service been a tad more attentive, Kazu would have easily earned an extra star.

A M B I A N C E / D E C O R
Simple, clean, and casual, Kazu Sushi is where you come for the food and food only. With seating for less than 30 people, opt for the sushi bar (seats 8 very tightly) for a front view of Kazu-San in action. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/sZPWB4TTX06W5Ht5kv7qdg?select=tY3FuSt37u1WPXsP9bscTA

P A R K I N G
#$%^& #7@^*&%$*! It almost drove me to a bottle of sake so please allow yourself an additional 15 minutes to look for parking or remember to take your valium beforehand. No joke. 

The highlight of the night? Being too consumed with stuffing my face, my friend brought up the fact that Kazu-San looked like a Japanese Richard Gere (Circa Pretty Women). Boy, DID he. *Drools* Hmmm, I wonder if he has a son...HOLLAAAA! ( ^_~ )

^^^Prime example of WHY I'm single.^^^
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I took two kids I was babysitting to this place on Friday at 5:30. We were the only ones there for about a half hour. The kids weren't crazy, but, you know. We were a little messy, but the server was sweet and I made sure to clean up our mess.

Just came by to tell y'all it was not a good time. The miso soup was lukewarm. They had to be hosting some kind of children's cooking class on GroupOn. This is the only excuse I will accept for the crumbling, bland crunch roll I received. 

I ordered teriyaki chicken for the 2 and a half year old. $7 gets you a small chicken breast with lettuce garnish and two baby tomatoes cut in half. WHY, KAZU? I LITERALLY HAVE MULTIPLE SMALL MOUTHS TO FEED. HELP ME OUT.

The cutlet was like rubber, and if I had to guess their cooking instructions, it would look like this: remove Costco frozen chicken breast from package. Thaw. Remove skin, set aside. Microwave the chicken until it isn't pink. Dip raw chicken flesh into teriyaki substance. Carefully blanket the cooked chicken in its uncooked skin. Do it. They'll love it. Serve.

Moral of the story: if you want to find good, or even passable sushi in the city, ask a friend for a recommendation! 2 stars because one of the kids said "I'm full," and that's all I can really ask for.
author: Meredith D.

description: This place was delicious! I little small, but most places in the neighborhood are. We were seated immediately at the bar, and the chefs and waitresses were very friendly and quick to take our orders. Sushi is one of my favorite types of food, and this place had a great selection. Some pretty unique rolls that you don't see on all menus. My boyfriend and I split four rolls between us because we couldn't decide haha and we ended up loving all of them. The pot stickers were also great! I will definitely be back.
author: Natalie H.

description:
The restaurants on Irving continue to impress, and Kazu is no exception. Their fish is extremely fresh, and they have a very robust board of specials.  Walked in on a Friday night with no issue (and that's not to say that the restaurant wasn't busy). Walked out having crushed a good amount of delicious food at about $30/head.

My only knock on Kazu is the space is a bit cramped, but, in all fairness, that seems to be a common symptom of great, hole-in-the-wall sushi joints.
author: Matt T.

description: Came here with my lovely daughter and hubby . Highly recommend it. Loved the veggie sushi selection. Small place , parking was hard. But food and ambiance were really lovely, especially with a fresh peony on the table
author: Roopali R.

description:
Came here last weekend since Ebisu was packed, there was no wait here even for being a small place, though a replacement for some of my other favorite sushi in the area. 

My friends and I ordered quite a bit including some beers and sake. Nothing really stood out for me, in general I would stick with the sashimi or nigiri vs the special rolls. Here are some highlights of the meal:

Chicken Karaage: lots of batter and kind of lacked flavor to it, definitely have had better karaage
Lamb Chop: pretty tasty and juicy, though kind of sad that they were only able to give us 2 instead of 3
Nuclear Roll: basically a spicy california roll
Yamakake Roll: now, I have never had Yamakake before, which is basically a gooey yam sauce... but it is just not appetizing at all, the texture is pretty gross and I'm not really sure if it went well with the roll at all, in addition the tuna didn't taste very fresh
Salmon Nigiri: comes with a few pieces but the slices of salmon are huge!
Assorted Sashimi: this was actually a pretty good value for what you get, again I appreciated how big the sashimi pieces were 

Overall, if you have the time to wait or have time to make reservations elsewhere, I would pass. In another location Kazu might be good but doesn't stack up to this area.
author: Tracy Joy K.

description:
Special fish board read like this:

fish
fish
fish
fish
shellfish
fish
fish
shellfish
fish
BEEF TONGUE
fish
fish
fish

Whoa...since when was BEEF TONGUE a fish?

Who carez, it's absolutely delicious! You can forget about otoro, seared Ko-Bay (or Ko-Bee depending on how you want to pronounce it) style beef, or foie gras nigiri sushi. Get it if it is on the white board.
It's grilled to order, has a little fat on it, and appears to be miso marinated. I love dis chit ta bits.

Other than that:

- this place is really really good. Already outperforms many places in the Peninsula. The only problem is the inconsistency of the shari (rice pad), some molded too hard or too soft, resulting in collapsing or breaking apart into at least two pieces when picked up by chopsticks, and perhaps rice a tad bit on the moist side.

- very high quality fish overall. Konoshiro (adult kohada) was out of this world, uni, shimesaba (splendid marination receipe, with great salt and vinegar balance), aji, hirame, suzuki, mirugai. The good stuff. Prices aren't too far off from Ino, but you do get what you pay for. Going crazy on the white board a la carte ordering will co$t you, which is why some of you prefer to do the "let the chef sock it to me baby" style ordering to sample, maybe fill up by getting a burger outside afterwards and save a few more buckeroo$.

- the jive ass rolls here look extremely erotic (but I didn't partake). So tempting that I felt like cheating on the nigiri I had, but would feel very guilty inside.
author: Ken K.

description: My uncle used to rate restaurants with four stars : lots, cheap, fast and good. This place gets those four stars plus another for being extra good!
author: Mike K.

description: Japanese owned and operated. Super fresh fish and skilled sushi chefs who know what they're doing. The omakase here is 100% legit. FYI: if you like mayo rolls this probably isn't the place for you.
author: Ken P.

description:
First time here and the food was not bad.  

We came here on a Monday around 7pm and the restaurant was full.  Luckily there were last two seats at the bar.....no wait yeah!

We ordered nigiri sushi and they were all good.  Very fresh.  I especially liked the Toro.  So good.  We also had the fried eggplants and grilled black cod.  Both dishes were very good.  

The staffs and sushi chefs were all friendly and professional.  

The price were reasonable in term of the quality.

I will definitely go back for more sushi.
author: Liza T.

description:
My favorite sushi in the city. Yeah, I'm a local but this place is awesome. Their salmon toro is so delicious it will melt in your mouth. The rice with the nigiri is warm and has great flavor with creamy texture. I like to get the chicken karaage and the California roll - I wouldn't eat this roll anywhere else but here. The hamachi toro is equally good as is all their fish.

Also, I really like the sake - hakatsuru I think - it's in a blue bottle.

Only negative is that the area is getting a bit crowded and more folks are discovering this awesome-ness (so much better than Ebisu around the corner). It is a small place with a small staff and when it's crowded, it can be a long wait for your food. But they've added some additional wait staff when I went there recently, so once she gets better, hopefully this won't be an issue.
author: Laurie S.

description: Couldn't get service the other night.  Was horrible.  We ordered 2 waters, 2 misos, and some sashimi.  The sashimi came out before we even got our waters or miso soups, and that was over 10 minutes from when we ordered.  We didn't even have napkins or chopsticks or soy sauce or plates either.  Ended up just walking out.  The waitress just couldn't be bothered to help us.  Took her 10 mins before she could even come over to take our order.  So 20 mins and... just horrible.  Just disgraceful.  We ended up getting up and walking and went to Naan and Curry instead, which was GREAT.  Not sure I can do this place again... so so so disappointing.
author: T. E.

description:
The vegetarian rolls here are fantastic. 

They flavors are so pronounced and though their rolls are a little pricey, they're also substantial and made with obvious care.

If you're looking for a mellow intimate spot to take a friend or date with high quality sushi - Kazu is your spot.

The place is never too busy, and their staff are extremely sweet. They even give you a warmed hand towel before you start your meal.

I'm looking forward to returning, to try more of their sushi menu as well as their ramen.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
The food was good, but the service was really poor. 

It took 2 hours for dinner, it was only 2 of us and we didn't order much.  Maybe it was an off night.  There were a few apologies for the inconvenience but no real acknowledgement of it.  I don't plan on going back.
author: Bennett H.

description: Nice staff, great sushi semi expensive. I'd suggest going when it's not super busy, they don't have a lot of space and the service gets slower, otherwise must go.
author: Ramin A.

description:
We were on our way to the inner sunset to get some pho and driving down Irving Street when we noticed the Kazu Sushi sign. Intrigued, we decided to forgo our original plans and try a new place (after all, sushi is our favorite go to meal!) 

Hubs dropped me off as parking can be tricky around this neighborhood and lucky that he did because I nabbed one of the open tables. 5 minutes later, all the open tables were taken and there was a slight wait. 

While waiting for hubs started reading some of the reviews which indicated service was slow (yes, this is true) so opted to order a spicy scallop roll and the king kong roll first. 

Ambiance: no frills decor, in fact there's only one daily special board that the waitresses have to move around (it's kinda cute and funny seeing them carry the white board to each customer) 

Authenticity: Chef and staff were Japanese! 

Food: 

I have never written a review on sushi rice before but wow was this some delicious rice! When a sushi chef trains, it's a 7 year process and the first year alone is spent on perfecting rice. I can say without a doubt the chef mastered this. Absolutely delicious, well worth the carbs! 

Rolls: both the specialty rolls and the regular rolls were good. I really enjoyed the spicy scallop roll. 

Sashimi: very fresh, good generous cuts 

Vegetarian: saw lots of veggie sushi options for anyone who's vegetarian but loves sushi 

The tempura also looked really good, will order that next time we are here. 

Overall, enjoyed this authentic Japanese dining experience. 

Arigato Kazu Sushi!
author: Betty C.

description:
This place is an unmitigated disaster. I've been going for a while now. Over time, I have learned that the "specials" board is just a gimmick. In the last 9 months, it hasn't changed at all! 

Nevermind that. 

The food quality has absolutely gone to shit. 

During our last meal, our toro (the most expensive fish you can order by the way) was frozen. Yes, frozen. 

The miso soup was boiled to death. They destroyed all the delicate enzymes in the miso and they used crap for dashi and they emulsified all the ingredients from the heavy boiling. Insane. 

Our grilled mushrooms were raw. 

Need I say more? 

Won't be going back again. These people have lost it. Completely.
author: Eater S.

description:
EXCELLENT OMAKASE!  ONE PIECE OF NIGIRI FOR EACH TYPE OF FISH! 

Chef Kazu, I noticed that his American customers call him Kaz which sounds cool to me.  I got there just after 5PM (just after opening time) and sat across from Kaz at the bar.  The waitress asked me if I'm ready to order, and I told her Omakase, so she told Kaz, and Kaz started right away. 

Not only was the Omakase 1 piece of Nigiri each Kaz served me 1 piece at a time and presented each piece by telling me what type of fish it was.  I must have had at least 15 pieces of Nigiri in which I believe is the traditional Nigiri order which is going from the lightest fish to the most oily rich fish.

After the end of the Nigiri Omakase Kaz asked if I would like anything else, and I asked him if he recommends anything, and he served me his own creative tuna roll with I believe had tuna, avocado, and lettuce, and it was delicious.  All that came to total of just over $50.00.  REASONABLE PRICE!


MY SUGGESTIONS AT KAZU SUSHI:

1) Try your best to sit at the sushi bar.

2) Get Omakase.

3) The reason I recommend the Omakase at the bar is so Kaz can serve you 1 piece at a time and present each piece to you with an introduction which I personally like.


SO IF YOUR IN THE INNER SUNSET DISTRICT LOOKING FOR A GOOD NIGIRI OMAKASE WITH LOTS OF FISH VARIETY THEN SUSHI KAZU IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!
author: Rudi A.

description:
A recent visit didn't disappoint.

* Spicy Hamachi "Yellowtail with spicy sauce" ($5)
* Spicy Salmon "Salmon with spicy sauce" ($5)
* Spicy Hotate "Scallop with spicy sauce" ($5)

Ultimately, I like their spicy sauce here.  Simple as that.  It's good and yummy, and just has me wanting more!  Their spicy scallop was exceptionally good!

* Crunchy Roll "Spicy tuna, avocado, and cucumber wrapped with tempura specks topped with tobiko, and spicy sauce" ($8.75) - Enjoyed it the first time and it didn't disappoint this time either.  It's a great roll - with great sauce!

* King Kong Roll "Grilled ginger soy marinated yellowtail, avocado, cucumber, shiso leaf, onion, and burdock topped with yuzu miso sauce" ($7) - It only came with four pieces, which isn't a whole lot.  My friend's BF really liked this roll, so we gave him the extra piece. 

* Agedashi Tofu "Deep fried tofu topped with grated Japanese radish" ($5.50) - About five pieces of tofu with bonito shavings, freshly grated ginger, and Japanese radish sprinkled all over.  Good, but I appreciate a lighter fry on there.

* Chicken Karaage "Deep fried boneless chicken" ($6) - Five pieces of chicken sitting on a simple salad with seaweed sprinkled on top.  It's not something I usually order, but it was good.

Service was really good on a Friday night.  There was one waitress when we came in, but noticed there was two by the time we left.  Our waitress was great with refilling our tea and clearing plates.  Definitely a step up from previous complaints from others.

Has anyone else noticed how gorgeous their orchids are?  The one sitting in the bathroom is really exceptional! 

4.5 stars.

(Pics posted!)
author: Teri C.

description:
I had dinner here the other day and it was ok. I am originally from Japan and I ordered the Ankimo, Nanbanzuke and the Kisu Tempura. Everything I ordered food wise was awesome for me and the beer (Asahi, my favorite was good). My main problem was the sushi. Since the restaurant is called Kazu Sushi, I would expect their sushi to be better, but I was less than enthused. The sushi took a while and it was ok. The maki-mono was poorly wrapped, although the fish was good. 

Also, the sake was ok. I probably should have ordered the cold sake. I ordered the hot sake and was not as good as I expected. 

I would recommend their non sushi menu though. The Nanbanzuke was the highlight for me. Not too many Japanese restaurant serve this item and they do it very well.
author: Cody M.

description: This is the best sushi I've had anywhere in the world! Kazu & his wife were fabulous!
author: Laura C.

description:
This is a cozy, relatively small sushi restaurants that appears Japanese-run.  It was a plus that the evening I went (last Tuesday) there were a few attrative Japanese ladies dining at the sushi counter. :)

I ordered the 15-piece sashimi moriawase ($25) and I got a plate with seven variety of raw fish (two pieces of each) and one piece of sweet cooked shrimp.  The sashimi was indeed fresh.  I enjoyed the spicy hamachi roll that I also ordered.

The only thing preventing me from rating them higher was my disappointing with their clam in sake broth.  For $9 the broth portion was rather tiny.  The amount of clams was fine, but for the dollar amount I would've like to have gotten a larger amount of the broth for consumption (and the enjoyment of the broth is why I look for this item to order at Japanese restaurants).
author: H K.

description:
I give 3 stars, but it might be more like 3.5, and the caveat is, we just got takeout...haven't had the full dining experience yet.

We got a spider roll, a double-double roll and a yellowtail roll, plus the Hawaiian tuna poke and miso soup. 

It was good. Solid. The rolls could have been rolled a little tighter. The flavors were good and the fish definitely seemed fresh. 

We went to pick it up, and the interior was small and cozy, leaning toward the shabby side but not all the way there. It wasn't bad and I would try eating in. I'd be interested to try some of the traditional Japanese non-sushi dishes after reading some of the reviews on this page.

The price was...meh. A little on the expensive side, but then we did choose two special rolls. It was $47 for the 3 rolls (2 special and 1 regular) and the poke and the soups. I guess I've paid more for sushi, but I've also paid less for similar quality.

All in all, the sushi was good, but I wasn't overwhelmed, especially considering the price. Ebisu is a block away, and that place is amazing. It was closed that day, otherwise we probably would have ordered our takeout from there in the first place. I would give this place another shot, especially for the non-sushi items, but Ebisu is still my #1 for sushi in the Inner Sunset.
author: Jennie S.

description:
No chirashi
They didn't even know what that was
Seriously, that's interesting....
Their roll selections was less than subpar. Totally sucked compared to most places

I got the double double roll, I was less than impressed. Not flavorful.

Apparently if you sit in any of the last 5 seats of the 9 at the bar you do not get a sushi chef service.

Instead you get sucky service.

Lame. Food mediocre service sucks and environment sucks
author: Zoe D.

description:
Service: 1 out of 5 stars, would be lower if possible.

There are but a few basic rules of thumb when it comes to the dining experience, of which a violation of is inexcusable. One so heinous was experienced at Kazu, I feel it necessary to warn my fellow San Francisco diners, and make an alternative recommendation for Japanese cuisine in the Inner Sunset.

This was our third visit to Kazu, and our second "special occasion" event, a birthday. We arrived early on a Monday evening, to be seated in a window table. We were seated, ordered drinks (disapprovingly non-alcoholic), and were given the special list to view. Our drinks arrived and we decided on an appetizer.

Shortly afterwards, we were rudely "told" to move to the least attractive table, near the restroom, to make room for another couple, of whom, did NOT have a reservation.

Now, I cannot think of a single reason a restaurant would think that, moving patrons within direct viewing of someone who has just been given the best seating in the restaurant, your previous table, would provide even a reasonably enjoyable dining experience. The dynamics of such a faux pas are, in the dining world, simply not done. Ever.

Sure, we have watched scenes like this played out in television or the media, when the famous actor arrives at the trendy restaurant, ala Saturday Night Live. But really? We still can't understand the gall, and unprofessional behavior of the Kazu staff. We left, and will not return.

Our advice, when looking for Japanese cuisine in the Inner Sunset, is located less than 2 blocks East, on the North side of Irving, twords UCSF from Kazu. You will find a Zaggat AND Michelin rated Japanese restaurant, with comparable prices, who understand the art, and need I say common sense and decency, in treating their patrons. Visiting anywhere else, least of all Kazu, is a no brainer.

I cannot, in any way, recommend Kazu. Quality of preparation, ingredients, and presentation mean little when the basics of understanding dining etiquette are disregarded.
author: Enoch K.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Friday night as a party of three, we were lucky to have a table without reservation since half the tables seem to have been reserved already even though there was only one table occupied.  The overall image of this place is traditional Japanese, very small and tidy.  

Ordered omakase, each nigiri piece came out one at a time, everything seemed to be nigiri on the specials board.  Because we sat at a table, the waitress delivered each piece at a time and stated the name of the sashimi, however not the English translation haha.  We had 9 pieces each, the nigiri already was seasoned or flavored and with wasabi sandwiched between the fish and rice.  Some pieces had too much wasabi though.  I also could have dipped some pieces in soy sauce, except for the unspoken rule that it is unnecessary.  We ended with uni which I loved because it was fresh, sweet and strong; I like my uni to have a strong flavor.  Nothing else stood out too much to me but I will come back for quality sashimi.  Omakase turned out to be about $60 for two.
author: Renee L.

description: My wife and I lived one block from Kazu for four years, and boy, were we lucky!! It's one of the best sushi restaurants in the bay, and once in a while we go to sf just to have it. Super fresh nigiri and sashimi, tasty rolls, friendly staff, and a cute relaxing ambiance. We love the spicy salmon dragon roll, pork belly appetizer, and all the nigiri, especially the albacore. Not my favorite unagi sadly but try anything else. Check the specials board, which is very sweetly brought right to your table by hand.
author: Bryan C.

description:
Sushi Kazu is a great alternative to the crowded and noisy Ebisu on 9th Avenue.

The food quality and taste are great!
I usually like to order from the board specials. For example:
- Kampachi (Amberjack) sashimi
- Kisu tempura (boneless little fish fried w/tempura batter)
- Sawara shioyaki (tender fish section, crispy skin, salt, lemon slice, delicious!!)

I also like the Nambanzuke (fried sardines or similar fish, then marinated in a vinaigrette sauce served cold), but some people might not like it because it has a lot of bones. To remedy that I just bite into each quarter section of the fish to avoid most of the little bones.  In addition to the regular nigiri, I really like any of the special rolls too.

The restaurant normally closes at 10 pm, or 10:30 pm depending on how busy they are. They are closed on Sunday.
author: Luis C.

description:
I'll grant most restaurants an off night, but man...this was really rough. It's a tiny place, which should limit how hectic it can possibly get (note: it was not that hectic). 

Perhaps it was opposites day and I missed the sign, but I'm accustomed to the edamame and then sashimi coming out more or less in order at the beginning of the meal - not 45 min after everything else. The end result: walking away from a 2/3 full plate of sashimi and relatively untouched edamame.

The quality of the sushi...fine, not that bad. I guess going to sushi on a Monday is tempting fate anyway. The King Kong roll was solid.

Anyway, there are ample options in the Inner Sunset, and I can't see much of a need for anyone to go here when Koo, Ebisu and even Jimisan are just a couple blocks away.
author: Jon H.

description:
Service: 2 out of 5 stars

When our party of 3 arrived here at 6pm, the place was pretty empty. Happy to have the place to ourselves, we were given drinks and menus. 10 minutes in, everyone else started coming. After giving our orders, it took a while for  3 rolls of sushi and 2 pieces of raw fish to arrive. I was so hungry. The hardest part was they'd only bring out one plate at a time so our party of 3 ate staggered meals watching each other.

Service overall seemed really slow. At one point, the waitress came to refill my cup of tea and poured 3 drops before getting distracted and walking away to pour for other customers. I had literally the same amount of tea before she gave me the extra 3 drops. Thanks! Kazu just needs to get some extra waiters to help out or something because I have to agree with posts before-- she just seemed frazzled and all over the place. 

-----------------------
Food: 2 out of 5 stars

Hamachi Toro ($7.95) - The only reason why I came here was to get some raw fish. I was so surprised when I only got 2 slices. Two.  Our other orders included the rock n roll, california, and double tuna (I think). There were 6 pieces for each order. Honestly, it wasn't bad but it wasn't anything special either. A disappointment in light of the expected and hoped for 4 star rating. Overall, we paid around $55 for 3 rolls and 2 pieces of Hamachi Toro. Too much for too little.

Kazu has left me so very sad and running into the arms of Sushi Bistro for comfort.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Very tasty and fresh. I love trying out their specials on the white board. The kids give their miso soup, gyozas and California rolls a thumbs up. I never get to try them because they hobble it up too fast...but I guess that is a good thing.
author: Kirsten F.

description: This restaurant is right across the street from my house, so I thought I'd try it. I was very disappointed. The restaurant was filthy and the fish didn't seem all that fresh.
author: Sarrina S.

description: Decided to check out this Japanese restaurant on Irving. It's small, but packs a punch. The menu has long list that is varied. Ordered salmon sashimi and tempura. Food was decent and I'd come back again because I live close.
author: Denise C.

description:
Really, the east Asian food in the sunset can't be beat (unless you venture out to little Saigon). 

For a Saturday night, it was pretty quiet so I was a bit wary. However, it was pretty early and I trusted my fellow yelpers. 

For two people the bill came out to less than $40! This included saki and waaay too much sushi. We might order less next time as the rolls were pretty big.

We got some spicy hamachi (good), the crunchy roll (perfect if you want to get some deep fried goodness),  sabagari (meh, couldve done without), and my favorite: the Hawaiian. The fish was so fresh it almost tasted kind of sweet. I think I would have been fine with just straight fish. 

As I said, the rolls are gigantic so I'd probably come here with someone you wouldn't mind seeing you with sushi bits dripping down your face.

One star lost for ambiance and the sabagari. It was very no nonsense. I would definitely come here again. It feeds my sushi cravings but leaves me feeling full and happy without making my wallet cry.
author: Sonia J.

description:
Iwana (arctic char)
Hirame (flat fish... ie. halibut or fluke)
Aji (spanish mackeral)
Kurodai (black sea bream)
Tai (red snapper... or sea bream)
Unagi (freshwater eel)
Kanpachi (young amberjack)
Hamachi Toro (yellowtail belly)
Sake Toro (salmon belly)
Tekka Maki (tuna roll)
Shiro Maguro Sashimi Special (complements of Chef)
2 glasses of Shochu

One of the best sushi dinners in a long time... all while listening to a Costco 80's mix! oh, and I love how they put the special board on the floor next to you when you sit down!

thanks Kazu
author: Brian L.

description:
quality - really fresh fish - favorite new sf sushi spot.

service - the girl serving us seemed a little confused about everything - for instance I ordered a roll and she took our orders with no problem and then came back 10 minutes later after my boyfriend already was served his roll that they didn't have it and i should order a new roll.  but honestly  she was very nice and seemed like she was doing the best she could so it didn't put a damper on my meal at all.

Need to get:
Salmon Toro
Crunchy Tuna Roll
author: Jessie L.

description: Went to this place back in early January and it did not live up to the hype at all. I think I ordered the spider roll, which was mediocre. We had to remind our waitress TWICE about my friends food and when it arrived after I had finished my entree there was practically no apology. The chicken definitely came out of a bag and had been frozen. I could tell immediately by looking at it and it was so unappetizing my friend barely touched it. I refused to try it and when we politely complained there was no offer to take it off the ticket. The waitress was way more interested in talking to her two male friends at the bar. In addition she and another woman that worked there were eating behind a privacy screen which I find unsanitary and unprofessional.
author: Neal B.

description: Cute sushi restaurant.  The food didn't blow me away.  It was somewhere to eat and luckily there was some space at the bar area for us to sit.  There are not a lot of tables, so don't plan on coming with a group larger than 4.  Not going to happen.  Wish the prices were cheaper, but what can you do?  Nothing.  Parking is super tough to find in this area, so if you live within walking distance, even better.  If not, bus might be your option, unless you rock and finding parking.
author: Michelle M.

description:
A very standard sushi restaurant. Came around 7pm on a Saturday night and there was plenty of seating. It was pretty quiet inside and they had like elevator-type music going on in the background. Nice windows facing one of the neighborhood-y streets of the inner sunset.

- Jurassic Park roll - had avacado, crab meat, alfalfa, and tempura asparagus. I didn't expect the asparagus to be fried! it was ok
- Crunch roll - had these little fried things around it. Honestly I can't really taste the difference between different rolls of sushi.. hahah

The bill was something like $20, which I guess is not too bad, but I think we were both full but could have eaten more.
Nothing really special, just another sushi place on the block!
author: Suejung S.

description:
I really, seriously, and HIGHLY recommend both the CRUNCHY roll and the JURASSIC PARK roll.  

Other rolls like the King Kong roll, Yamakake (?) and Dragon Hamachi roll were good, but those first two were fantastic.  

The service was great, wasn't too busy at 7:30 on a Tuesday night (but did soon fill up around 8:00), and parking is manageable around the area.  However, this place is NOT for large parties - the seating is limited.  

I wish I had known about this place earlier!  Do try.
author: Cora L.

description:
This place is pretty good and it was a big surprise because we picked this place on a whim not expecting anything. In fact the front page picture for this place is a Jive Ass Roll so I wasn't expecting much. Turns out the itamae does not make many of them - he leaves them to his apprentice (his son, maybe? He looked half-Japanese.) The itamae makes all the real stuff.

First thing I noticed was the price. If you are looking to get a la carte nigiri, be prepared to rack up a large bill.
