Price for 2 nigiri bottoms out at like $4.50 for tamago and only goes up from there. I decided to try shinko which was on the main menu at $7.xx but apparently the price of the day was almost $10! Of course, they told me about it, so that was fine.

Sushi rice was great. Fish were very fresh and nigiris were packed just right, maybe even erring a little on the dense side, but definitely very good. My only complaint about the nigiri was that the itamae was a little heavy-handed on the wasabi that is integrated into each piece. In some cases I wasn't able to really taste the fish for all the horseradish invading my senses. I'll give it another try, it may just have been an off day.

Also, their service varies, they have only 1 dedicated waitress (or at least that was the case when I went there.) She was very overtaxed and we had to wait a while to get tea, get the bill, etc. I would suggest coming on a quiet weekday night to get the most out of the service and the itamae.

That said, currently Okina Sushi is still at the top in my opinion. Just a better, more intimate experience overall. Read my review...
author: Josh K.

description:
My disclaimer - I don't eat raw sushi.  

That being said, maybe this place is excellent but not for me.  I wanted sushi but the cooked ones.  My family ordered the raw sushi and it looked fresh but was really expensive / small portion compared to other places.

Given the price and limited seating, I probably won't come back.  Maybe I do like chain sushi restaurants like Mikuni's in Sac much better than an authentic hole in the wall expensive sushi place.  

Sad to say that I haven't found a good place in SF for cooked sushi but have tried a few great places in Sac.
author: Cin T.

description:
I came here with Michelle C. & Co...to tidy myself over with some Sushi snacking. The place is tiny and not many 4 seater options. We chose to eat at the bar and that was fine. The staff were Japanese and so were the sushi chefs which earns high marks...and we were served efficiently.

I ordered the White Snake roll (crab, lettuce, avocado, cucumbers, with tobiko)...it was flavored well but the portion cuts were huge...instead of a roll of six or so...it became 4 giant pieces...so it was a mouthful to go on. Tiffany ordered a california roll...and it was tasty and okay. 

The prices have changed from the yelp menu link, just add $1-2 on top of that menu price and you won't be sticker shocked.

This restaurant is fine for a neighborhood...just nothing about the food stands out. *You know, the slap you in the face flavor punch that makes you teary eyed.* Parking is vicious here, so make sure you have patience and quarters.
author: Pauline L.

description:
Didn't expect to find such an authentic Japanese restaurant in fusion-infested San Francisco!!! I was becoming tired of sushi rolls covered in mayonaise and teriyaki bento boxes that tastes the same everywhere... But when i walked into Kazu, I was happy to see a board-full of Today's Specials (written in Japanese & English). 

Without hesitation, I ordered few dishes off from the Special menu including miso cod and kanpachi kama. Miso cod was intensely flavored, and kanpachi kama was so fatty that you can taste the umami as the delicately broiled fish melts away in your mouth. Also ordered ika geso fry (fried squid legs) which had a nice accent of aonori (dried seaweed flakes). The Agedashi was lightly battered and fried to perfection. I wish they used silky tofu instead of firm tofu though, but that is just my own preference. 

At the end of the meal, we asked if they had any ramen type of dishes as an ending course, and the chef was nice enough to prepare a special bowl of ramen for us to share! The ramen had a seafood based broth and even though I was so full already,  I had no problem finishing the entire bowl of noodles + the soup. 

First time around, I tried mostly their cooked dishes, but I can't wait to come back here to try more of their sushis and sashimis!
author: tiannaaah J.

description:
This is my new favorite Japanese restaurant. I'm ashamed to say that it's taken quite a long time for me to step inside here.

Do yourself a favor and don't order the rolls. Nigiri and Sashimi is what they're best at. If you're willing, go try a bunch of different pieces of Nigiri, or try Omakase. Things to note: Akimono and Uni is really good here. Prices are very decent and the fresh fish is great.

The only negative is it's location. Parking around here will take you a minimum of 20 minutes to find if you come in after seven in the evening.
author: Clinton L.

description: Great local sushi spot where you can enjoy a pretty authentic Japanese meal.
author: Steve S.

description:
Reasonable prices, easy free parking on a Saturday evening, delicious hot sake, and fun speciality rolls.

I recommend the crunchy spicy tuna roll and the spicy hamachi - both really fresh and fun combination of flavors.  I was not a fan of the sabagari (mackeral with ginger, the fish was a little too fishy for me). 

Also, Kazu is within walking distance of Golden Gate Park - great place to go walk off the food afterwards.
author: Kimya P.

description:
If I could give it zero stars, I would... And the only reason why we settled on this place was because Ebisu Sushi was so full, and we didn't want to wait another hour after having already waited one because we were starving! (and I bet it would've been better there too) 
The ambience was very quiet and it was very quaint so we thought it'd be a nice, cozy little spot and boy, were we wrong.
Their service was terrible and inattentive if they didn't think you were spending money and not only that, but I went with friends, and some of us had to wait until EVERYONE was done eating before some even got their first roll.... So, not only did I manage to go out with friends on Valentines Day but I also ended up eating alone, when the point was to eat with friends. 
Also, people who came in AFTER us got served way before us because they were ordering alcohol or they were trying to accommodate to them simply because their bill was going to be bigger than ours. 
The sushi was whatever and overpriced and they managed to get our order wrong a couple of times.
My recommendation, save your money and your time unless you're willing to spend more money to get better service.
author: Marla C.

description: I don't get it.  Came here based on all the very good reviews, but left disappointed.  Average at best with mediocre quality sushi.  Dinner started out very promising when hot towels were provided to cleanse thy hands, but soon after everything else when nowhere.  The hamachi Kama was under seasoned.  The uni nigiri not at all fresh.  The albacore nigiri was frozen.  Agedashi tofu very small serving, and lacking taste.  Only saving grace was the clam miso, and somewhat efficient service.  My wife and I love to support local eateries, but places like these really need to fine tune their foods.
author: Joel M.

description:
No, I do not own this place. hardy har har. Of course, though, I had to try this place out due to the name, and also because I read other reviews that it's a legit Japanese restaurant.

Came here on a weekend night, and found a table right away. The decor, as well as the list of specials on the whiteboard, remind me of a typical casual Japanese restaurant in LA. Yay, reminds me of home!

We ordered some hijiki, a fried iidako (tiny octopus) dish, and a sushi combination. The fried iidako was delicious! Very light batter on the outside and very light octopus; similar to good calamari at an Italian restaurant. The sushi we had was pretty decent, as well. We didn't order any of the expensive fish, but for the price that we paid for the combination, it was pretty good. The shari (rice) was pressed just the right amount, too, indicating that this sushi chef knows what he's doing.

Sushi Kazu passes the Sushi Nazi Kazu test!
author: Kazu O.

description: I can tell that this establishment is very good.  Fish and rice was high quality served at a perfect temperature.   The UNI was the best I've had in a long time.  I noticed they serve items not on the menu to regular customers.  I have to say though, that my service was average, head chef had " other things " on his mind. My nigiris were really "sloppy" looking .  I can definitely tell he can do a much better job.  There were a lot of mis communications with customers that night.. Many we're questioning their bill.. I'll come back though .
author: Demanding T.

description:
stumbled upon this restaurant with a friend and i must say it was pretty good.  It's small but they weren't too busy when we got there.  

seaweed salad- can't really go wrong with it.  

monkfish liver- my friend's never had it so i decided that he should try it!!!! I like it but can't say the same for him.  It is definitely an acquired taste.  it was paired with ponzu sauce (i think) and it was fresh and creamy like it should.  

combo sushi plate- the fish was fresh and yummy.  

everything was reasonably price too.
author: JY L.

description: Have eaten there twice in the last two weeks. Everything my wife and I had was good to very good. The curry shrimp soup being the best of what we sampled. Sushi was good, fresh. Shrimp dumplings ehhhh.
author: John S.

description:
Everything about this place is awesome.

High Quality fish, expert preparation for your nigiri, and excellent quality for the non-fish appetizers.

Take a look at the negative reviews here. None of them focus on the quality of the fish, but rather complain about a lack of rolls or some perceived service slight.

Yes, the restaurant is small. Who cares?
author: Owen R.

description: In spite of being a vegetarian I need to say. This is the best sushi place I have been to. THe review might not be fair as I mentioned previously I am a vegetarian
author: Milana R.

description:
I had a Japanese server AND the sole sushi chef was Japanese too! That's a rare find in SF.

Was greeted with a steamed towel (oh so Japanese) and filled my belly with quality miso followed decent sushi. I think I had the King Kong, some crunchy roll, and one other that I can't remember. One of the rolls had all cooked fish in the middle which I did not like and I don't believe it was mentioned on the menu. Another roll had some clear white goo drizzled on top that made for an interesting but not-so-appetizing consistency. 

I would like to come back to give it another try but definitely was wow'd by this inaugural visit.

Miso + 3 rolls + soda = $34. Not bad for a party of two.
author: Jasmyn M.

description: Situated in the heart of the inner sunset. It's your traditional hole in the wall sushi joint. They offer a very vast selection of rolls and abundance of veggie rolls for you vegetarians. Place is good, reasonable prices.
author: Al S.

description:
Didn't have a very good experience at Kazu Sushi last night with 3 of my friends. We saw the good reviews and wanted to get some delicious sushi before hitting up the Nightlife at the Academy of Sciences.

My friend ordered a modified roll, with salmon instead of tuna. She ordered very clearly, mentioning she wanted the salmon instead of the tuna twice. The roll came with tuna.

Two of my friends were done eating for a good 10-15 minutes before me and my friend ever got our food, which for a busy place is potentially excusable, but there were only 4 or 5 other people in the restaurant at the time. By the time the food came, I was too hungry and frustrated to really enjoy my rainbow roll, but I think it was pretty good.

After finishing, we just wanted to leave. We got the bill, figured out how much each person owed, and wrote down our names and how much we owed for each of our respective credit cards. We told the waitress that we did this, and she verbally confirmed our request to split the bill this way.

She split it evenly between the four of us.


Three strikes and you're out. Sorry, Kazu. It took an hour and a half for us to get in and out of here on a non-crowded Thursday night. If you don't mind the wait, this place would be worth it - the food was good, but it left me with more frustration than it was worth.
author: Danny O.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants in town.  We've been going there for years and it never fails to deliver.

I think a restaurant is infinitely better if it's run by a husband/wife team.  I believe the owner is the sushi chef and wife takes care of the tables. 

Service is adequate, have to be patient when they are busy.  The food quality is excellent, fresh fish, sushi rice is done just right, I hate the cold and hard sushi rice or sometimes too much vinegar, but Kazu always makes the best rolls.

Cooked food is great too, tempura not too oily, potato croquette is one of our favorites.  Most hot food comes with ample salad so no need to order salads separately.  

Most of the time we were there, there were always Japanese people eating there, that's always a good sign right?
author: J L.

description: I come here as much as possible, fish is always fresh and delicious, staff is always friendly and welcoming. Don't pass up a chance to have some of the best sushi around.
author: Evan P.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night around 7 and was able to get a table immediately. The place is small with which looked like 4 people working, one chef, 2 sushi chefs and one waitress all of which were Japanese.

We ordered combo a (which came with miso soup), a crunchy roll, king kong roll, agedashi eggplant and the homemade pork belly. As you may have suspected, we overordered! All of which were decent but I think the agedashi eggplant was great. We normally order agedashi tofu so it was a nice departure. The porkbelly  was homey and was a big piece of the pork similar to the ones in ramen noodles.
author: Marissa C.

description: Don't come here ready to feast because the portions are tiny.  Pretty decent quality though.  We ordered Hawaiian Poke (skip!) and soft shell crab (really good but only enough for two) as appetizers.  And split 3 specialty rolls: Double Double (get!) Zigzag (so good! but only 4 rolls) and Caterpillar (typical)  It seems like a small mom and pop shop.   Service was really nice.
author: Tammy N.

description: Mediocre service. The sashimi was okay. If you're really craving sashimi or sushi, this will quell your craving, but you'll quickly forget the experience. No ambiance whatsoever.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
atmosphere - really Japanese

quality - very fresh and satisfied 

service - moderately well. I can see why people say it is bad but you need patients here. 

Overall - I would come back and can would recommend to others if they are just looking for sushi that is not fancy but still have quality fish. 

Tips - sit on the counter and if you speak Japanese is a bonus!
author: S S.

description:
AVOID. 

It's one thing to have to wait a while for your food to come out of the kitchen at a restaurant where you can't see the chefs, it's another when you order rolls for two people in a practically empty sushi restaurant and get to watch the sushi chefs get drunk and loudly socialize with their friends for 35 minutes while you sit and wait with no food in front of you.  We ordered rolls at Kazu last night at 8:15, when the restaurant  only contained customers who had already finished their meals, meaning the chefs had only our table to make food for.  The whole experience felt pretty insulting, just sitting there waiting and waiting and waiting in plain sight while the older chef got drunk and socialized with the customers sitting at the bar who had finished eating and the younger chef flirted with some girl.  It's fine to multi-task, but neither one of them even had their hands doing any work the majority of the time.  

The whole thing was ridiculous.  They could see us sitting there with nothing but tea for 35 minutes with zero concern.  Sort of hard to believe they're still in business with that kind of lacking service.  What should have taken 10 minutes for any sushi chef to prepare took them 35--our food finally came at 8:50!  It's not like any of the food even had to be cooked.  There was literally zero effort put into our service.  About 25 minutes in the younger chef gets out a huge plate and begins plating one of our rolls--and then continues to make the other four for the next ten minutes, meaning we have to wait until the whole order is done before even getting anything.  Knowing we've been waiting they could have at least sent over the food as it was being completed, instead of making us watch it sit there until they felt like finishing the rest of the order.  The review that mentioned the server coming over to pour tea and then getting distracted after pouring literally three drops and walking away happened to us too!  Obviously if you don't know the owners they won't bother to make you feel welcome or bother even preparing your food until all of their more important customers/friends have left and they have nothing else to distract them.

When the food finally did arrive 2/5 rolls were decent/good, but the other three were embarrassingly bad/inedible.  Fishy, tiny rolls, ununiformly cut, and sloppy.  

I wish we had walked out somewhere during that insultingly long wait.  I doubt they would have even noticed!
author: Alicia J.

description: Very good quality of fish, fresh and and tastes great. Great service , clean restaurant, prices are reasonable. Ordered sashimi salad, hamachi toro and both were excellent. Will definitely come back here for chirashi and hamachi kama.
author: Claudine V.

description: My favorite place for sushi. The chefs are friendly and hospitable. I like the Santa Cruz roll and the tropical roll the best. They have great ingredients in their fresh rolls.
author: Kim D.

description:
Came here on Monday night around 7:45 pm. I wanted to try other places in the area, but most Japanese restuarants are closed on Monday. We ordered nigiri, a couple different rolls, and tempura. The food itself was not that bad. The main problem was the pace at which the food arrived. 

There was one waitress for the whole restaurant, which was full -- that's 1 person serving 26 people. Took us 15 min. to order. Another 15 min. for our first round of sushi to come out. 20 more min. for more food to come out... Also, I didn't realize that the specialty rolls would only be 5-6 pieces, cause I feel like most of the time, more complex rolls have 9 pieces. You might want to order more sushi than you think you can eat, cause the pieces are quite small.

Around 9 pm, the tempura still not arrived, so we asked our waitress to cancel our order (which was fine with her cause they still had not started making it). Then we went to San Tung down the street, where our orders were taken promptly and we were served our food within 5-8 min.

I guess this place is not bad if you're in the mood for talking and a slow dinner, but I was in the mood to EAT.
author: Jessica W.

description:
With Ebisu and Koo just around the corner ... I was pleasantly surprised with Sushi Kazu.

FOOD - Good quality, fresh fish.  Wide variety in menu, although, many of the rolls include tempura.

DRINKS - Sake and beer.  Not impressive, but have the basics to complement any of the dishes.  

AMBIANCE - Some awkward and tight seating at the bar, but otherwise is a quaint and cozy restaurant.  Casual dining place, good spot to catch up with a friend.  Not too much to comment on, and certainly nothing to rave about.

PRICE - Prices are acceptable for the quality of fish.  Pricier than many other Japanese restaurants .. but on par with Ebisu and Koo on pricing.

SERVICE - Great effort, but a little slow.  Sat at the bar and sushi chef was not engaged at all.  (Good or bad?  Expected at a Japanese restaurant?)  

Overall, good option to add to the rotation.  Open on Mondays when others are closed.
author: Good U.

description:
Thanks to my friend Jen for dragging me out to her hood to try her sushi place. Their special rolls are quite tasty. We tried the Beef roll and the Double Double. Both were good, but the Double Double might be my new fave sushi roll. Who would have thought that mango and raw fish would be such a tasty and beautifully combination? 

The nigiri we had was also expertly prepared. We sat at the bar so we got the added entertainment of watching how two sushi chefs manage to produce a variety of rolls and nigiri in the tiniest of spaces.

Zushi is still highest on my list but Kazu is a very close second.
author: Dani D.

description:
Oh kazu, how I wanted to love you. Like an ugly but convenient boyfriend, I kept coming back instead of breaking up. Hoping it would get better. I let this relationship - and this metaphor - go on for far too long.

The sushi itself isn't the biggest problem. It's the service. And it's been going downhill. Once we literally waited an hour before any sushi was served. Today, after asking for tea and water, we received one tea and one water. When this was pointed out, it took another fifteen minutes to get another tea and water.

The waitresses are sweet, but horribly inefficient. They are usually standing around the sushi bar and never at the front of the house, leading to long waits. We've been here at least five times and sadly the service is equally slow at any time of day, any day of the week. 

The sushi is good but not great. Sometimes looks sloppy and tastes mediocre. For high quality sushi with good service, take your business just a few blocks away to Koo. I regret not finding out about Koo earlier. 

Thanks Kazu but I think it's over for real this time.
author: S. L.

description:
So FINALLY, I have found an affordable, yummy sushi place in the city!!

I always get Sushi Combo B - a set of nigiri + unagi maki for $20.  Pretty good deal because the nigiri are a decent size and good quality fish.  It comes with miso soup.  

This place can take a while because the staff is small, and there is limited seating.  I recommend going on a weeknight.
author: Melissa W.

description:
Last night was Hodaka and Scott's b-day dinner. We had reservations for 10 at 6:30. We got there a little before then and there were no tables available for us. Apparently a group of 8 walked in at 6. When we got there, they were asked to leave or wait by the Kazu staff. (Ouch!) They just sat down too. 

Our party of 10 had a good time and met some nice people who bought a bottle of sake for the birthday boys. They too are on Yelp and one's parents own a Chinese restaurant down the street. How cool is that!

The sushi was very good. We had the special spicy tuna roll, Bay Area roll, huge-ass hamachi nigiri, Snapper nigiri, aji nigiri, uni, nigiri, Maguro that melted in my mouth like butter, Spider roll, and the duragun roru. 

The spicy tuna roll was not just a regular spicy tuna roll. I don't remember the name but according to our server, she called it 'too rong name roru.' Ok maybe it sounded funnier when it sounded like she said the 'too wrong name roll.'

A little too much wasabi on the nigiri. But otherwise, very good. The service was excellent. It turns out our server, Kimiko, used to work at Murasaki. She was there the longest since we've been going there. She took care of us all night and even discussed used panty vending machines in Japan with Hodaka. 

It was a 5 star experience for me. Although I took off a star because they kicked the other people out after we said we'd wait since all of our party had not arrived yet.

I think Nobu would approve.
author: Kevo M.

description:
Great friendly service, great food, try it out!

I would get there early because it's only street parking and the place is rather small. I would try and sit by the bar, the chef (Kazu) makes a great person to have a conversation with.
author: Amy C.

description: Terrible service! We waited SO long to get our very few orders. Our used plates weren't cleared away, we had to constantly ask for water, and it felt like the waitstaff had totally forgotten us... which is totally ridiculous because the place was tiny! The sushi wasn't anything special at all. I've had much better all over San Francisco. We decided to leave and weren't even close to satisfied. What a disappointment for Valentine's Day!!!! Thankfully, Tart to Tart saved the evening.
author: Suzi G.

description: Horrible service. Took an hour to get any food and it was difficult to even get the servers attention. They are such a small restaurant that its not possible they were too busy to make food fast enough. Also, the normal/typical rolls came out in 6 pieces, which is about average. But the more expensive specialty rolls only had 4 pieces each... such a rip off! All of the food was mediocre at best. And to top it off, their heat was off/broken. They had a little heat lamp on in the center of the room, which really didn't do anything. It was freezing and I had to have my winter coat on the entire time! They never once acknowledged any of this - from the delay in food to the freezing temperature. Very disappointing...would definitely not recommend!
author: Steph G.

description:
CELEBRATE GOOD TIMES, COME ON!!!!!!!!!!!! Kim W. and I finished first video project presentation of the semester, so we decided to thank our main actors by taking them out to dinner.

We didn't go to Ebisu because that seemed like $$$ and Gary Danko was out of the question, I wouldn't have even paid for myself let alone additional people. We opted for this place, but we didn't think it would cost around $90 including tax & tip. Kim and I were still hungry, friends seemed like they weren't but we were STARVING when we came.

We ordered...fried fish cake, deep fried oysters, sake, 5 different rolls...Double Double (mango & I can't remember what fish), something with minced spider, one roll had cooked fish, other rolls...can't remember their names. Many were spicy, but not too spicy. I would say to definitely get the deep fried oysters. The presentation looked nice.

The waiter was nice, when we entered, she brought a heater towards us then showed us the specials on a dry-erase board. Then they took it when a new customer came in, after that we didn't feel special anymore.

We should have went to Kiki's but we didn't have a coupon, so we didn't go. You can't go to Kiki's without a coupon, that would be a jip.
author: Kylie L.

description: Solid neighborhood sushi joint. The fish was good quality, and the rolls were delish. Nothing too fancy.
author: Sophia B.

description:
I'm a vegetarian, so bear that in mind when reading this review...

Anyway, as a vegetarian, sushi is always hit or miss. Most of the time I get stuck eating a little cucumber, avocado, ume, and rice. Some tempura too, if I'm lucky. Not so at Kazu! They have a whole vegetarian menu, and it's the most complex vegetarian sushi menu I've ever experienced. I got the spicy veggie tempura roll (I like everything spicy, and this delivered pretty well) and the veggie dragon roll. The dragon roll had eggplant instead of the typical eel and was omg sooooo good. Why can't more veggie rolls incorporate eggplant, I must now know. It was garnished with cilantro too, which I love. The spicy veggie tempura roll had dollops of a spicy mayo sauce which, even despite my volatile hate for mayo, I still liked a lot. But I'm a sucker for spice, what can I say. 

So I think Kazu might be my favorite place for veggie sushi at the moment. I can't wait to try more off the vegetarian menu. Why four stars? Like a previous review said, the service is a little slow and the place is kinda cold. Luckily I brought a sweater thanks to that informative review, but my poor boyfriend did not. They seemed to know this, they had a couple space heaters running.

There are a ton of sushi joints in the neighborhood, but be sure to give Kazu a shot!
author: Ambika C.

description:
One of my go-to sushi locations for the following reasons...

** I really love riding my bike here - specifically. The Inner Sunset has some great shops, there are minimal hills to this location and I feel accomplished riding there...even tho it's not that far from my house in the Mid-Richmond.

** The sushi rolls are a good mix of modern and traditional. Pricing also reasonable.

** The flavor profiles mix spicy and sweet well. Love the mango in my sushi. Thanks for that, Kazu.

** Lastly, the small restaurant seats people comfortably at the bar, or at a table with minimal wait time. This makes it a great place for a date, since you're not swallowed up by a large crowd of people or a blanket of noise.

My favorite is still Sushi Bistro...but this is a close second having so many of it's own qualities that really make it a stand out restaurant.
author: Katy A.

description:
My experience at Kazu Sushi was good. The service was slow since there were only two waitresses attending the whole restaurant. But, the quality here is unbelievably fresh and the service is still really nice. They have a really cute dispenser for soy sauce that looks like a teapot, and you get warm hand wash cloths before your meal. Downside is that this is a small restaurant with tables too close together. The music they play reminds me of the music played in a department store.

My dad and I ordered 1] Hawaiian Tuna Poke, 2] Soft Shell Crab, 3] Hawaiian Roll, 4] Uni Sushi, 5] Halibut Nigiri for a total of $43 pre-tip. I can't say much for the uni or the halibut nigiri because I didn't try those. However, the soft shell crab did not fully meet my expectations; it was not as crunchy as I hoped, but still delicious over the salad they dressed with a teriyaki dressing. The mango in the Hawaiian tuna poke and Hawaiian roll were extremely fresh and sweet.

Come here only for sushi. Don't expect other Japanese food such as teriyaki stuff over rice, udon, etc. Kazu Sushi, hence the name, is generally all sushi. I give an extra star for their huge variety here. Downside is that they're only open for dinner.
author: Priscilla W.

description: Yelped it and went here with the dad. Fresh nigiri. Slow service (one waiter for the entire restaurant). This place doesn't have udon and stuff. Ordered a few rolls - they were all four piece rolls.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Omakase, please!

The quality of the nigiri improved drastically since our first visit many moon ago. 

First rate neta, NICE! No hot Shari, VERY NICE!!!! Also, bonus point for the toasted Nori.

Love the super dry Asahi! 

Service was a bit slow between the nigiri but given that it was Saturday night with a full house that is to be expected. Room for improvement, here! 

Out of special Ramen. =(...Maybe next time. 

=)
author: DAVID N.

description:
We started off at another sushi place that was packed and reeked of, "you ain't get'n laid tonight smelling like that" cologne, so we ended up here. We had been here once before, but forgot how much we liked it. (Hey when you eat out a lot, you forget things like to go grocery shopping and which restaurants you've eaten at before.)

 The service was very friendly, the fish was really fresh and the spicy tuna roll was super yummy too! 

The place is on the smaller side, but that means less noise. We will be back here for sure.
author: Kat M.

description:
pretty good japanese sushi place

cod hotpot: really good- extremely light
15 piece combo: slices are pretty big and pretty fresh
one of the special rolls: rolls are really big and delicious
author: Janet Y.

description: Nice little place. Sushi was good, and great ambiance. I had a miso soup and the fat tuesday roll. Both were great!
author: Courtney M.

description:
was very good, great for the area.  nice vinegar rice, not too dry or moist, good temp, only occasionally fell apart, thick sliced fresh pieces (thus ratio bigger than 1 bite), expected prices. great shoga.  no toro avail.
had kanpachi, aji, salmon belly, wild sockeye salmon, japanese scallop, halibut
kanpachi kama, albacore carpaccio, spicy tuna roll -- all good.
not easy to find parking on weekends at prime time!
author: Rob C.

description:
The food here is good, unpretentious, and sometimes very creative.  And especially in a neighborhood where there are about 4-5 other sushi restaurants within walking distance of this one, competition could be perceived as fierce...yet Kazu manages to set itself apart from the other places by offering items on the menu that you won't find at the typical neighborhood sushi joint!

In fact, my SO doesn't generally go here knowing what he'll order:  he asks the owner, who usually is working behind the sushi bar, to recommend something, and my SO's taste buds have never been let down!

The downside?  The services is VERY SLOW.  And the waitress either doesn't understand English very well or is extremely scatterbrained, I haven't figured out which.  Don't be surprised if when you order something with special instructions she brings it out wrong on the first try.  How do I know it's her fault?  Well, we got into the habit of ordering take-out from here once a week, and the sushi chefs memorized our order...but she still kept giving it to them wrong, and they'd correct her for us!  I'm not sure, honestly, why they continue to keep her as an employee, although to be fair, she is polite and seems nice enough.  

The other downside is that this restaurant is TINY!  You can't get a table for more than four people, and it will still feel a bit squished.  This is definitely NOT a place to bring a large party, they simply won't be able to accomodate you.

One really nice thing about Kazu is that you never feel rushed.  While other restaurants try to slash and burn their way through customers to get tables sat and re-sat as many times as possible in an evening, Kazu lets you take your time, enjoy, and doesn't make you feel hurried.

I would go here more often if the prices were lower.  It's not that Kazu is overpriced (it's quite reasonable considering the quality), it's just that sometimes I want basic, lowkey sushi rolls that are dirt cheap.  But when I want something a little nicer without the pretentiousness some of the finer sushi restaurants in SF offer, this is where I go.
author: Amy L.

description:
Indeed, one of the finer Japanese establishment in SF.  

The Uni was memorable.  Enough said for a sushi purist.
author: Alexander H.

description:
Came to Kazu Sushi with my dad, who is a sushi chef, and said that we should go eat here together.

This restaurant has a great selection of fish, so if you're into nigiri or sashimi, you're in for a treat. I didn't eat any of the rolls, mostly because I'm more of the traditional sushi eater, but they looked very appetizing. I tried the kuronama Asahi beer and it was really good. Goes well with sushi. The oyster was so fresh and I really enjoyed the ponzu and garnish.

At the end, we had squid ink ramen. Whoa, that was surprisingly delicious! Ramen usually uses pork broth, but since this was fish/squid ink based, it was so crisp. Loved it!

I'd give it a 4.5 stars because there were many times that we wanted service, but it was difficult to get the waitress' attention. Cannot blame her though, she was working by herself and had to divide her attention between all the other customers.

Overall, really nice restaurant. Might be a little small, but the food is superb.
author: Momo C.

description:
My girlfriend and I decided to stop at Kazu one cold December night. We were immediately seated (just beat a rush of people) and a heating fan was directed toward our table. Their menu was a little on the short side in terms of rolls they do but they have a nice list of specials. The fish was really good and fresh and the service was great. 

The down side of this place is the size, very small making you feel crammed in there. Also as a said before so more rolls would be awesome!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Interestingly Kazu Sushi was opened during the Inner Sunset Street Festival and they were selling various street food. Sausage on a stick, Yakitori, Takoyaki, and drinks. Prices were alright and the takoyaki looked pretty good so I brought one. The takoyaki tastes fresh like it's freshly made. 

I'll definitely head back here to try the other stuff.
author: Steven B.

description: Best Sushi in the city! Authentic sushi. I had a chance to talk to the head chef and he told me that all the fish are fresh from Tsukiji, Japan! You gotta try Omakase! Will blow your mind!
author: Miki F.

description:
We went to this place with the kids after a swim. Ebisu was too crowded and I wanted something in the neighborhood. Chose this place because of the Yelp ratings.

The nigiri and maki was good. I felt that the fish was good quality. We had uni as well - very, very nice.  A good sign.

The chicken karage was not so wonderful. Not terribly crisp and it felt really fatty (yes, I know it is fried) - perhaps they used some very fatty pieces of chicken. The tempura was not bad but not super crisp.

The reason that I am not giving it higher stars is because of the service which was, hmm what are the words, haphazard and unpredictable.  Rice, which I had ordered with the chicken karage appeared ten minutes after the chicken karage appeared. Tempura that was ordered right at the beginning (before the chicken karage) appeared towards the end of the meal. When we added in a request for another bowl of rice halfway through the meal that also took about ten minutes. We had to request refills for the water. People who had come for dinner much after we had got their order way before we did.  

So, two stars mainly because of the service - which is important for a restaurant experience.  Food - good. Service - not so much
author: Nick K.

description:
Sushi here is good.  Really good!  Staff is nice and it seems like a nice intimate place to go eat.  Only thing that took a star off was the timing of the food.  There seemed to be no flow to it.  We either had 3 things in front of us all at once or nothing at all.  Also the prices could be a tad lower.

If this doesn't bother you then you'll love this place.  They were also kind enough to take us in when they were near closing which was very sweet of them since we were very hungry.

We will definitely be back, but we'll make sure not to be starving next time.
author: Vicky C.

description:
Best first:  the Uni was oh-my-god amazing.  It was literally glittering on my plate when they brought it out, a real trophy showcase example of the delicacy, and it tasted as good as it looked.  Quite possibly the best Uni I've ever had, and I'm a huge Uni slut at this point and quite jaded on them bitches so they gotta be REAL classy to impress me.  Impressed.  So they got +2 stars right there.

Worst next:  the sushi rice.  Look I know this is remedial stuff people (and you know i'm looking exasperated right now) but it's got to stick together .  The rice this evening was sticking together about as good as the senate democrats.  I'd pick up my nigiri out of the lil' soy sauce dish (what *do* they call that thing) and half the finger of rice would fall off.  C'mon.  Minus 1.5 stars, almost minus 2 but I'm a happy drunk.

More good stuff:  Big carafe of hot saki, $6.50, can't beat that with a tatami mat.  In fact I am still good and tipsy if you couldn't tell.    Special fish selection was great too, I had a type of toro I hadn't had before which was really excellent, and an unusual silky-firm texture that I wasn't sure about at first but ended up quite liking.  

Service was totally fine, I don't know what all the fuss is about.  Everyone was friendly, one of the sushi chefs even asked me how the uni was (unheard of with surly sushi chefs, but I think he knew he had an exceptional specimen on his hands and saw my little mouth orgasm expression).  

If they get their rice shit together, haha, an easy 5 star update.
author: Goolie G.

description: Seems the sushi tasted fresher last time (I came the same time last year) but still decent. The lady that is always there is very sweet.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
I should be studying for finals now, but I figured I should write this review before my memories of it will be attacked by the school-related material I will be cramming into my brain, but little do they know they will be pwnd by the amount of alcohol I will ingest after I'm done with them.

Anyways, after reading what you yelpers said about Kazu and after 20 mins of hunting for parking around the area. Me and my boyfriend ended up at Kazu for dinner. He ordered the Hamachi nigiri and another nigiri variety plate, I forgot what it was called, but the portions were really generous. I LOVED my Fat Tuesday roll, which had unagi tempura, cream cheese, cucumber wrapped with smoked salmon. Mmmm....doesn't that sound good now?!? Jurassic Park Roll, which had crab, avocado, cucumber and others I might be forgetting. That one was just okay to me. 

It's a very small and intimate place. The sushi was definitely fresh and wait time was a little long, but reasonable enough cause they probably spent the time preparing our sushi. The portions were pretty generous. The waitress really friendly. A little bit pricey, but it was well worth it. I'd give it a 4.5.
author: Serena W.

description:
The good thing about this place is the freshness of the fish. The tuna, salmon, himachi, were all flavorful and had great texture. Absolutely no stringiness whatsoever. The rolls were all standard (spider, rock n roll, dragon, etc.) and made good use of the fresh product. The quality of fish is extremely important in a sushi restaurant, but thats where Kazu stops being amazing.
     I like eating my sashimi with sushi rice, but they refused to give me a bowl of sushi rice. The sushi chefs looked bored and were completely silent. The service was pretty much non existent. The prices should be represented by 3-4 dollar signs and not two. You probably won't be full unless you spend at least 30 per person. A sashimi combo meal is 25 dollars.
     On the plus side, they did give me a frosty glass for my sapporo. Too bad its not enough to make me come back every week.
author: Siao W.

description:
Decent sushi but have experienced bad service here. 

On more than one occasion they have taken over two hours to prepare a small phone order for two people (while promising it would take 30 to 45 minutes). They were not apologetic for the delay and did not offer an explanation. For that reason alone I stopped going there. 

With Koo and Ebisu just around the corner, which both have better sushi, I have never had a reason to go back.
author: Dan H.

description: Great sushi, fresh fish. Customer service is a little slow and difficult to get.
author: Sabrina S.

description: The sushi here was wonderful.  Fresh and clean.  The rice of the nigiri could have been better formed though.  It fell apart when I lifted each piece up.  There was only one server, however, and as a result, the service, while friendly and helpful, was lacking in attentiveness.  We waited quite a long time and they forgot one of our orders.  It's a little on the pricey side, but, then again, when (outside of Safeway, ick) is sushi not overly expensive?
author: Allegra H.

description:
3 1/2 stars, really.
We dropped off Jr. Yelper for a pizza birthday party at nearby Cybelle's Front Room and ventured a couple of blocks down the street into Kazu for our adult meal of raw fish which would otherwise elicit ear piercing "eewwhhheeww" from Yelper youths.  This is strictly a sushi place, you're not going to find tonkatsu, teriyaki or tempura meals here.

The place is small with seating for 24-25 max and no more than 4 at the sushi bar.  I decided to try this place on the suggestion of Yelper Nobu, who posts a list of his fav sushi places.  The solo waitress was running around the room trying to keep up with the orders.  I love the portable circular heater which was close by us on the floor, but the poor thing had to navigate around it with dishes in her hands.  

This is a good place to come with friends so you can sample different things.  We had fresh oysters on a shell, 3 for $8 from the extensive daily special menu.  It was nice and garnished with bits of ginger and scallions.  2 orders of Combo A, $16 came with a piece each of tuna, hamachi, ebi, salmon, eel, white tuna and hirame.  The hamachi here is very tender and fresh, practicially melts in your mouth.  BFF ordered combo D, $25, which is combo A and a Rock n' roll (delish) and hamachi sashimi - the sashimi was even better than the fish pieces on the nigiri.

I ordered 4 pieces of unagi ($4.75/2 pc) and 4 hamachi nigiri ($4.95/2pc).  The unagi was so tender.  What we didn't like was the rice, not flavored and fell apart to easily that you'd have to pick up the piece with your fingers and quickly shove the piece into your mouth.  Forget the chopsticks, it only breaks up the rice and cause the grains to collapse as easily as a sandcastle, all over your plate.   Now try picking that up with your chopsticks.

We shared one of their special rolls (19 selections), Dragon $11.50 which was shrimp tempura, cucumber, onion wrapped  with eel and avocado and topped w/tobiko.  I thought it was too sweet.  The miso soup which accompanied the combos was flavorful and had lots of seaweed in it.  Our bill came to over $30/person with sodas and one sake.  

There's so many choices on the menu and specials of the day that it was hard to make a selection. I'd consider another trip back to try other items.  Their largest table seats 6, a couple of twosomes and we were the only table for 4.
author: Ry T.

description:
I hate to use the word cute for this place, but I have to.

This is a great small, cute and sweet sushi joint that is truly intimate.  I think there are 6 tables in this place.  I've come here a few times and the sushi is always fresh and tasty.  Reasonable/cheap prices as well.  Service is fast and you get a warm damp towel to wash your hand with before eating.  This is especially welcome during the winter!
author: Jen K.

description:
Usually you get 2 piece when you order Nigiri.
But "Omakase" menu you'll get 1 each but more different kind fish.

My gf's brother-in-law visit SF from Boston.

She said, " My brother-in-law is coming for conference, but he wants to go Sushi with you. He said he'll eat anything you order."

I said, "Right on. My kinda guy. Let's do it."

So, last night 3 of us at Kazu, 

I got there earlier so I asked Kazu for the special fish. I picked 10.
So, the dinner sushi menu had been set before they come.

it turned out that we were having semi-Omakase by my choice with Kazu's recommendation.

We had, 

Iwana, charr from Alaska. $10.50
Hirame, flatfish $10,50
Iwashi, sardine $9
Kibinago, slender sprat, $10.50
Aori-Ika, bigfin reefsquid, $8.25
Shima-Aji, horse mackerel, The King of Mackerel!!! $14.65
Maguro-akami, red tuna, $9
Kuro-dai, black sea bream, $9
Saba, mackerel-shime, This is Kazu's Special. The best! $6.75
Anago, conger eel, very light & tender. $13.45

(the price are for 3 Nigiri)
+
"Sazae no sunomono", cooked top shell with vinegar.
 Deep fried Anago's spine, it was about 15" long, crunchy as chips.
+
2 extra large Asahi Super Dry directly from Japan. $12x2
+
1 order of Kazu's special Ramen divided into 3 small bowls. $8.95
+
Tax
=$148

$60 each person include tip!!!!
I couldn't believe it when I got the check.
I was expecting more.

It was a really satisfied great sushi dinner experience.
The semi-Omakase was a good idea.
author: Nobu K.

description: Really good food! Stopped in here for dinner and was not disappointed. The sushi was spectacular, the sashimi was very fresh, and the service was friendly. Highly recommended.
author: Michael S.

description:
i think i found my new sushi spot and it's in my neighborhood!! my friend took me last night after having a great experience and i'm always looking for really good sushi places in SF to compare to the one's in LA but still haven't found it. This place comes very close with the fresh fish, cut & perfect portion of rice. 

We started off w/grilled hamachi, which was perfectly grilled and very juicy. The special nigiri pieces of Japanese scallops and salmon toro just melted in your mouth. I'm not into rolls but my friend ordered 2 of their special rolls that were OK but I would recommend getting the simple rolls like spicy tuna. The only disappointment was they ran out of my favorite items of hirame & uni. 

The service was excellent! I can't wait to go back and try more of their other fresh items!
author: Deb C.

description:
4:55 neon open sign turns on so i sat at the empty sushi bar and ask for omakase. chef says i can pick which piece but now i'm confused because omakase means chefs choice so i told him to pick.
5:05 waitress finally comes by for drink order and brings water
5:08 its been almost 15m and i still havent gotten my first piece. getting annoyed and bout to walk to san tung for chicken wings.
5:10 1st piece arrives. hirame. not bad but not impressed either. 
5:25 the sushi keeps coming. nothing stands out but i'm getting full. after 10 or so,  chef serves up tamago and finally speaks "want a maki roll?". no i replied for i'm full and there was no indication that it would blow my mind. 
5:30 i'm still the only patron in this joint. the waitress finally shows her face again to present the bill after a 20 minute absence. my water glass still empty but no offer to refill it nor any inquiry to my experience. $52 for OK sushi, below average decor, and garbage service. no greeting or goodbyes from any of the staff.  i gave another $5 for tips and still felt i over tipped.
author: Charlie C.

description:
We were looking for a Japanese restaurant around the district and found this place from the reviews, so we checked it out.

The sushi rolls were okay, I did enjoy the Ultimate Crispy Spicy Tuna roll,  although there wasn't anything "Ultimate" about it except for the bits of Tempura batter all over the roll.  

Other than that, everything else was just fine.  Nothing really stood out, but it wasn't bad either.
author: Ren L.

description:
I have to preface this review by saying that the food was AMAZING! but the service was the killer.... simply terrible and all the food took forevever to come out. We ordered the ocean salad, sashimi salad, a hamachi with shrimp tempura roll, and a special roll (yamatake? kamatake?) 
Everything was delicious but the waitress literally waited like 5-10 minutes between each dish to bring another out. 

even worse was watching the table next to us... that happened to speak japanese (hmmmmmm....) get everything out in a timely matter. 

And our last roll, the special roll, was covered in something slimy (the yam sauce?) we coldn't even pick it up with our chopsticks! Worse, we had to wait extra long for this one. I felt like she looked at our empty table and though "oh shit, i forgot about their last roll!"
I might come back because everything (except maybe that slimy roll) was super tasty but maybe clarify that i'd like everything at once since i like to sample.
author: Lisa H.

description: Possibly the best sushi I've ever had in San Francisco!! It is so authentic and fresh and delicious to boot! It is even better than Sushi Zone and Amasia!
author: William L.

description:
Fresh, clean, well prepared dishes.  The cuts of fish here are very fresh.  Good size cuts and the quality of the seafood is top notched.   They have some very original rolls.  I like the food here because you get good value and good quality.  The only downside is service is a bit slow when it gets too busy.  You can't rush quality and not expect it to suffer.

The hamachi, kampachi, hotate, and uni are exceptional!
author: MTBer I.

description: a cozy and ethnic place, loved the food. must visit a place
author: Vrushali P.

description:
It was surprising to find this gem in the Sunset district among all the Ebisu, Hotei, and Kiki's in the neighborhood.  This is certainly a place for those who appreciate fresh sashimi; NOT for those who want bento boxes and combination rolls drenched in mayonnaise. You know it's good when ALL of the staff speaks Japanese. 

Here's what my girlfriends and I indulged in:
Bin toro: albacore (white tuna): sooooooooooooooo buttery melt-in-your-mouth goodness. Now I know what people mean when they say toro melts in your mouth. I've had toro before but this experience was different; it was phenomenal.
Kanpanchi toro: yum! It's a more crunchy fish that doesn't melt but still has that buttery toro flavor.
Wild salmon: a softer fish that is noticeably better than farm-raised salmon so it's good for those who love salmon. 
Hamachi toro: the fish was harder in texture than salmon; really good.
Uni: very good, sweet & creamy uni
Miso Black Cod: very, very flavorful. Each piece of meat was jam-packed with flavor. YUM! The piece was quite small; maybe a little bigger than my digital camera.
Ankimo appetizer: three pieces of ankimo swimming in ponzu sauce. Very creamy and soo good. Went well with the small pieces of green onion.

$48 per person including tip + tax

Overall, great sashimi and nigiri! Order from the daily special's menu and you'll get the freshest fish. There's a good variety and I noticed they have fish not typically seen at other restaurants. They had a variety of toro from different types of fish. Most of the fish from the board are on average about $8 for two pieces. Miso black cod is also a must-try!
author: Tina T.

description: Came here for dinner last night and I must say I will be coming back! Everything we ordered was super fresh, especially the Uni. Yums! Service was great and the chef was extremely nice.
author: Philina M.

description:
If you're looking for bento boxes, I suggest going else where. FYI, Kiki's is right around the corner. So is Ebisu and Hotei. You won't find any of that here.  ;)

This place is good but pretty expensive. We ordered: negi-hama,  crunchy spicy  tuna roll, nigiri appetizer, kisu tempura, yakitori, chu-toro, and 2 orders of nigiri from their special menu. Our total was around $93 (including tax). o_O I know, right!? Hella expensive! But then again, the chu-toro sashimi my bf ordered was around $20 and he also had some sake.

Fish was VERY fresh! My 5 piece nigiri appetizer ($11)  was delicious! It came with unagi, sake, ebi, maguro, and hamachi. Soooo good! Haven't had super fresh fish in a while. That crunchy spicy tuna roll we ordered was surprisingly good! I don't really like ordering rolls like that but my bf wanted to try it. I'm not into those crazy rolls.  But they had some crazy rolls on the menu. I had to pass.  Anyway,  if the crunchy spicy tuna roll is still on their special menu, I highly recommended it. Its delicious! It wasn't even that spicy so I was still able to taste the freshness of the fish.

As for that chu-toro...it was my first time trying it. I thought it was pretty intense. Bf loved it.  Kisu tempura was good. Not too much batter. I still like the one at Rumble Fish better. Chicken yakitori was tasty. It was very tender and had a nice flavor.

Service was nice. My glass of water was always full. This place is also very small. So I'm sure it gets really crowded on a busy night. We got here around 6:30pm and it wasn't that crowded.  Oh and its Japanese owned. 

Btw, parking is a bitch around this area. We circled around for over 15 minutes and gave up. We ended up parking at the parking lot which cost us around $8. =T
author: B B.

description:
It may not be on the menu, but order the Spicy Salmon Tempura Roll. It will blow your freakin mind!

I wish the portions were bigger, but I cant complain because it was so damn good. 

Oh and the Tamago Nigiri=amazing
author: Nelson S.

description: We love this place. We have gone to this Sushi restaurant for many years. The atmosphere is calming and they have nice music. The fish is very fresh.  The waitstaff are nice and professional. Overall this is one of the better sushi restaurants in San Francisco.
author: X X.

description:
A restaurant with a 4-star on Yelp should be good enough to give it a try right? Maybe not. We went to Kazu Sushi in a group of 6 with empty stomachs on a Monday night. We left 2 hours later with our stomachs only half full and feeling very disappointed. 

When we arrived at the restaurant, it was still empty (with only two tables occupied) so the waitress was able to arrange a large table for us quickly. As we sat down and started looking at the menu, I asked the waitress for recommendations since we had a relatively large group. However, it became clear that the waitress didn't know the menu very well. She said "I will try" but was clearly struggling to come up with something interesting for us. Eventually, we ordered hamachi toro nigiri, beef tongue nigiri, grilled miso cod, tempura, some fancy version of agedashi tofu with crab meat (I forget the name), pork belly and some rolls. 

Hamachi and beef tongue came first. The hamachi was very fresh and tasty, but it was so thinly sliced and laid over such a large clump of rice, that the taste of the rice overpowered the fish. I wished we had ordered sashimi instead so that I could fully enjoy the fish.

My friends were expecting some raw beef tongue, but what we got instead was some slow-cooked beef tongue over rice. The beef tongue tasted okay, but it was a bit dry on the edges, which was mostly because it had been pre-cut and left to sit uncovered for some time. 

The pork belly was a huge disappointment. Not only was there just ONE small piece, but also the meat was very dry. Yes, we were served some dry fatty pork belly!

The agedashi tofu sauce was too thick and had too much ginger, and this is despite the fact that I love ginger. I was also disappointed that they did not use silken tofu. 

The cod was cooked just right, but too salty.

The tempura was awful! Instead of getting the usual fluffy and crispy tempura, what we had was the exact opposite. The shrimp was small and overcooked, and the batter was soft. I would have returned the dish if my friends hadn't eaten them so quickly. 

The rolls were okay, nothing very special and were a little bland. Maybe they would have tasted a little better if they hadn't come at an interval of 20 minutes each.

The food was mediocre at best and the service was ridiculous slow! It's true that the restaurant is small, with 7 tables plus a sushi bar, but it's not so small that it only needs one waitress. The restaurant filled up quickly after we sat down. The waitress was so busy taking care of other tables that she paid little attention to us. Our tea and hot water were only refilled once for the whole night. After numerous attempts to ask her to refill our cups, I finally asked her to give us a pot of tea and hot water so we could serve ourselves. It took her 10 minutes to bring us half a pot of hot water. The tea never came. 

While we were "patiently" waiting for our food to arrive, we overheard the couple next to us complaining about the freshness of their sashimi. They wanted to cancel their order, but the restaurant refused to do so. The couple ended up paying the full bill. After they left, I saw that their food (one sashimi platter and a couple rolls) was pretty much untouched. 

Fed up with waiting 20 minutes between dishes, we left before we were full. 

In a nutshell, Kazu Sushi is over-rated, over-priced, and under-staffed. 

The best thing about the restaurant? The orchids displayed in the restroom. They were so stunningly beautiful that for a while I mistakenly thought they were fake.
author: Kelly N.

description:
This place one of the only place we go to have sushi in the city and japanese food. The fish here is really fresh and they don't try to over feed you with rice on their rolls.
The service can be slow but the food is definitely worth the wait! If you're expecting your rolls and food to come out in 5 minutes i suggest you going elsewhere. Their food is fresh and is made to order, it's not microwaved and reheated like other places i know. 
The restaurant itself is quite small, which I don't mind. The kitchen food is also superb - I would definitely recommend KazuSushi to any person that is serious about their sushi and Japanese food!
author: Em K.

description: Excellent fresh fish, great tuna and salmon, large cuts, and decent prices. My go to sushi place.
author: Emily D.

description:
Awesome Sushi, great prices, I can tell you this place has food on par with the Ebisu around the corner.
unagi & uni are great here, as is the Sake selection.
author: Jennifer R.

description:
My one true (food) love in life is sushi. I could honestly eat sushi everyday and continue to love every bite. Now eating sushi AND drinking sake w/ an ice cold Japanese beer in a chilled glass? Even better. On top of that, getting to clean my hands with a hot towel before consuming my meal? Could it get any better? Maybe. But on a chilly Monday, no. 
Every time I've walked past Kazu, I noticed from the corner of my eye that it was packed. I automatically figured it must be good. Well, I was right. But once going inside it's not surprising why it's always packed. The place itself only has about 5+ tables and sushi bar seating. But that's part of it's charm- I've always been a fan of super small sushi bars, because there's something intimate about consuming my favorite food with a limited amount of people with prompt friendly service! 
I didn't order sashimi this time, but I got the King Kong roll, which was delish. As well as my go to appetizer- a seaweed salad. In some ways Kazu is pricier than other sushi places in the area, but the food is tasty and fresh, and I like the ambience. So no complaining here! Being that it's right up the street makes me think that it should turn into a Monday tradition.
author: Sonya D.

description: Soup was tasteless and super salty. Soy sauce was very salty as well. Rolls are not bad, but can't say the same about fatty salmon sashimi. Two stars.
author: Squi Z.

description:
Good location, really good food and great people!
My buddy took me here after trying to get into Ebisu around the 
corner (always too packed). Kazu is not as pretty as Ebisu is 
with the remodel but more importantly the food is better and 
the welcoming atmosphere as well as the uniqueness of the food makes you feel as if you are in Japan or at least not in SF. I have been there twice so far and the second visit was as good as the first. Oh, they also have this fried chicken that is da bomb! 
IMPORTANT NOTE: P.M (Patin) who rated Kazu as a 2 star is a 
complete idiot. He slammed my business as well. Nothing makes 
this guy happy. Ignore him.
author: Mark C.

description: Great little spot with a huge selection of food, all decently priced and delicious to boot.
author: Dilly M.

description:
Did you break up with me over text message?  Because I'm feeling a little baffled by your behavior, and I just don't know what I did to make you hurt me like this?

After the magical monumental time here, twice, I've been back.  It was really nice the first time, but then I had stomach flu and anything that didn't make me puke would have made me happy.  But the last two times, I feel like you're not into me anymore.  

I came here with the really judgmental BF.  And it just didn't quite deliver.  The BF was underwhelmed.  Of course, he picked stupid sh*t to order but he's a white guy and I have to give him some slack.  But the Seafood Sunomono was lacking.  It had cooked ika and not crunchy slices of raw ika.  But I do like the cucumbers that you use.

Then I came with Lou, to celebrate...the day.  I ordered the Moriwasa sashimi and there was no aji.  Where was exciting selection of thick slabs of fish?  It was thinner.  Less exciting.  More safe.  Are we past the honeymoon stage?  Do we fart in front of each other now?

The tempura appetizer was still delicious and so was the miso soup.  Lou says that you still have the best rice, but what happened to your fish?  Is the economy really that bad?  Am I not special anymore?  Are you mad at me?  I want kohada, ika, uni, aji and mirugai.  I want what you used to have, and I want the generosity too.  Now, I feel a little left out in the cold.  I feel like you're just not that into me.
author: Christina C.

description: Always fresh fish, specials change daily, friendly service and casual atmosphere.
author: Alana S.

description:
Good food mired by very SLOW, FORGETFUL service

The good:
1. Quality Authentic Japanese Food
2. Friendly Japanese Staff
3. Clean Restaurant

The bad: 
1. TERRIBLE, terrible service
a. For our order of Sushi Combo C (2 rolls and 5 nigiri), 2 rolls, and Chicken Karage, we waited 2.5 hours. 150 minutes. Half my night. 
b. They forgot one of our rolls. Promising us it'd be 5 minutes since they realized their mistake, it was more along the lines of 15-20 minutes. This wasn't so cool, after wearing down our patience from 2 hours of waiting.
c. Asking for more tea, again, they forgot. We waited 30 minutes as they made a general round around the restaurant for more tea, ignoring our initial request.  
d. Waiting 15 minutes just to give them payment for our check, a part-time staff eating at the restaurant processed the credit card for us, since she realized how badly we were being served. The waitress was no where in sight.

Other Notes:
The restaurant seats about 30, but there's only one waitress serving everyone. There's also only 2 sushi chefs. We sat right in front of them at the bar, and watched as they were obviously understaffed.

This is a straight sushi bar,They have some yakitori and appetizers but not the usual  udon, ramen or donburis affair.

Some of the worst service I've seen. Allot extra time when eating here since they're pretty slow.
author: P M.

description:
for a vegetarian, this is a great sushi joint.  small, intimate, casual and with an entire page in their menu of vegetarian items.  they even had some vegetarian specials on their board.  everything we had was fantastic.  after our first visit, we've found a sushi joint in our neighborhood for us!

and for oyster lovers, like my boyfriend, they've got kumamoto oysters.
author: Karen O.

description:
Kazu a pleasant surprise.  I've walked by it several times, but never thought about eating there until I read the reviews on Yelp.  The place is very small with about 6-7 tables and a small sushi bar.  The place is very plain, but the sushi is very fresh.  We had yellow tail, fatty tuna, agedashi tofu, spicy dragon roll (special) and a seaweed seafood salad. The bill came to about $55.  Everything was very good except the fatty tuna (at $12 for 2 pieces), which is usually my favorite, was fresh but a bit chewy.

The clientele is largely Japanese (70% the night we were there) the night we were there.  You can hear Japanese being spoken throughout the restaurant.  

They offer a large number of specials on a white board, but since only the names of the specials were given in Romanized Japanese with no further description, it was difficult to order any of the specials, unless you already know a specific name (i.e. Toro).  

I would go back again as I though the fish was fresh and the price was reasonable.
author: Paul K.

description: Pretty good for SF.  Better than Sebo, not as good as Koo, about the same as Ino.  Sit at the bar; they recommend calling ahead if you're serious about sushi...so they can get fish from Japan.  Itamae is friendly and laid back...food comes out a tad too slow though.  About half as expensive as Koo.
author: woojin k.

description:
Just went to Kazu again last night and MAN, I love this place. This time, I ventured out and tried a bunch of hot foods and was not disappointed. Chicken meatballs, butakakuni (fatty soft pork mmmm) and gyoza. All highly recommended. And of course the sushi was not disappointing at all. Fresh and tasty. 

I am not sure why I'm sharing all of this with everyone. Please don't fight me to get into this (somewhat) hidden gem once it gets even more popular!
author: Deann M.

description: First let me start off by saying I am a sushi chef who grew up in Tokyo and have been trained by Japanese chefs.  I have been exposed to excellent sushi both through eating in Japan and training.  I can speak only on the fish at Sushi Kazu due to the fact that I have only eaten sushi, sashimi, and some rolls.  The fish are always fresh, portions are large and excellently prepared.  Kazu is there everyday and his quality control is superb.  It is obvious he is more concerned with customer satisfaction over profit.  It is very traditional and has a small staff, so if you in a hurry this probably isn't the place you should go for a quick meal unless you arrive early. But if you want quality fish from a master chef this is the place for you especially if you sit at the bar.  Kazu prepared fresh anago(sea eel) most places carry it frozen  and ankimo(monkfish liver) that were excellent.  Cuts of fish are large both sushi and sashimi and rolls are delicious with a good variety .  Many Japanese frequent the restaurant which is a telling sign!
author: Swen S.

description:
They had amazing fresh fish! 
Super small though, don't bring a large party!
Mostly sushi, not bento's or anything of the sort.
author: Monique K.

description:
Kazu is everything I look for in a Japanese restaurant. I don't understand why this place isn't constantly packed, but it's also great to know that you can go in whenever and there likely won't be much of a wait, if any, for a table. 

As far as Japanese restaurants in the US go, Kazu skews more traditional and while they do have various fancy rolls, they also have lots of dishes that can be harder to find. I've never had anything here that wasn't delicious and given their giant specials board is updated frequently, I trust that everything is fresh.

 I think the prices are pretty reasonable for the quality of food and while the service isn't maybe the most warm, they are perfectly friendly as well as efficient.
author: E. Elizabeth N.

description:
A cute, small Japanese restaurant with limited tables. Slow service so prepare to wait for being seated, getting: the menu, your order, tea, and then, the bill. But despite all of that, the food that I ate about months ago was actually pretty good. Not the usual Americanized sushi with mayo drizzled all over the rice in my opinion. Kazu sushi focuses more on the taste of each ingredient.

I tried the grilled nasu ($3.75) and King Kong roll ($7.50).
Small portions even for my standard.
The grilled nasu had a smoky, BBQ like taste and King Kong roll was delicious despite of its minimalist presentation.

I was skeptic looking at how bad their service was and how minimal the presentation was. And then, skeptic about the price and portion. But Kazu sushi did leave me with a satisfied stomach. If they have better service and price, I may come back.

Price: 3***
Portion: 2**
Food: 3**** (how can you make a little half star anyway?)
Service: 2**
author: Cliff T.

description:
I live in the sunset so it's usually hard to come by good Japanese restaurants, especially authentic ones. I come here every time I'm craving a fresh sashimi dinner. I love that the quality of their fish is consistent no matter what day of the week it is. I also tried one of their hamachi rolls and that was pretty good.

I don't remember what else I've ordered here before, but I'll update this the next time I go there.

Also, I'm not sure how strict they are about closing hours, but I remember coming here around 10:30-11pm before so it's worth a try if you're hungry and didn't make the 9:30pm deadline for most other restaurants.
author: Cristal G.

description:
One of the best sushi restaurants I've sampled in the city.  Everything we had was delicious, fresh and exquisitely presented.  Dishes did take a while to come out to the table, but edible art does take time. The chef was welcoming and friendly as were all the staff.  

Place is small and does get busy, so best to make a reservation.

Can't wait to go back!
author: Angela D.

description:
Aside from the fact the place was totally empty at 6pm on a Tuesday night, the waitress made my friend and I move from a 4 top to a 2 top, insisting that it would get busy and we shouldn't take up more room than necessary. First off, I wasn't raised in a barn. I know better than to hog a table for four people if its a crowded or a busy restaurant, but to be told to move when there are crickets chirping quite frankly is offensive. 
With half a mind to leave, I was so weak from hunger I toughed it out. The food was decent, nothing spectacular. The standout dish was the ahi carpaccio. It was a nice fresh portion of succulently flavored ahi. 
Service was mediocre, but an ok spot to eat. 
P.S. - not one person came in after us to dine....hope the waitress felt like a dummy.
author: Stacy T.

description:
This little unassuming restaurant is such a great little secret...no big glittery signs to draw you in..but absolutely delicious.  The service is attentive & when we walked in on a chilly rainy night, they set up a personal heater near us! 

The special rolls are totally inventive, yummy and generous in size! The sashimi is tasty & fresh.  The fish just melts in your mouth.  You really can't beat these prices for the freshness of the food.  

This little family owned jewel is fabulous & highly recommended. 

**only complaint i have is that the miso soup wasn't as hot  as it should have been...came out lukewarm and with not much tofu/seaweed.  boo
author: Lulu C.

description:
Cute little spot with fresh sushi and lots of cool specials on the board. We went by randomly one night when both of us were in need of a little cheering up via fishiness. Tried their iwashi shioyaki (salt-grilled sardine - excellent and came with a cute little pickled apricot slice), spicy hotate roll (not that spicy), sabagari roll (mackerel with ginger, one of my faves), popeye roll (spinach and mushroom - excellent and super-flavorful for an all-veggie roll) and some nigiri. Their uni is not as great as some of the other places in the city but even so, I would still definitely come back. 

The interior is very modern and comfy and they play jazz! It almost seems like a place my favorite author Haruki Murakami would frequent.
author: Angi C.

description:
Lost and found!

This place def gets lost among the sea of restaurants crowding Irving, but now is found...by me and my hungry stomach!  Kazu definitely felt homey - probably because I associate it with its previous owners who were just the cutest family...

This time around, though things were a bit different - the food was still great.  I adore their dry erase board that had all the specials.  Its small, so they'll place it on a chair next to your table so you can read it.  Each patron had their time with this board.  Its on the smaller side, so I recommend going at off times or making reservations.

FYI: can't go wrong with sashimi - fresh as can be!
author: Julie H.

description:
Fantastic, fresh, generous portions, intimate, great specials on the board. You cannot go wrong here. We left Ebisu because of the acoustics and insane noise level. Not wanting to give up a great parking space, we tried Kazu. We ended up finding our new favorite sushi place. 

Not to be missed.
author: Ken H.

description:
I came here about 3 times.  The first couple of times I came away impressed...but the last time it was just okay.... will elaborate.

I love sushi joints that are close and in this area there's like 4-5 within a 5 block radius. Around here I've been to Koo and Ebisu besides Kazu.  Haven't been to Ten and Jimisan yet...but for some reason they do not tempt me much.  I'll get around to rating those other two one of these days...but Kazu was definitely one I liked the most of the three..  

What impressed me the most and why i've been coming back about Kazu is the VARIETY.  The regular menu may seem okay..but check out the tiny white board they have for the specials and they have fish that i've rarely ever had...I've done Kohada, Aji, Sayori at other places and this place not only has these, but they have ebodai, kurodai, 2-3 different Toro, 2 types of ika, and a host of things I don't know but continue to try. Why I come back, maybe i've been watching too much "Bizarre Foods" lately... 

other pluses:
-They give you a warm towel to clean your hands... like Yu Zen and Kappo Gomi.. instant plus to me.
-Japanese owned... the chef seems well trained in his art.
-The rice was a good portion and decently seasoned...and the dab of wasabi the sushi chef used was perfect.  
-Good selection of cooked plates... again some pretty authentic items. I need to stop ordering the Nigiri and get some more of these tapas style plates.
-they have a porter style Asahi...forgot what's it called..and comes in a frosted glass.

Cons:
-the blue fin Otoro...was not otoro..at least the types i get a Yu Zen and Kappo Gomi (melt in your mouth pink type).  The portion here was big..but seems like it was half otoro and chutoro..i.e. right at the border maybe...and had some tendons.  
-the other con as that i came on a Wednesday.. and the fish was good but lacked the uber freshness of the last two times...which were weekends..
-One time the rice on the Nigiri fell apart... i think there's an apprentice in training.
-small place..would not come here if you have more than 4 people.

Despite the couple of negatives... overall food and experience were still great.   The staff was friendly and again this place has fish I never had elsewhere but was very delicious.
author: Vien C.

description:
The boyfriend and I stopped in here to satisfy our sushi craving and hoping we'd find a neighborhood sushi joint we wouldn't have to cross the park to get to. It's a rather small restaurant with a few tables and a couple seats at the sushi bar which we ended up sharing with some of the regulars.

We ordered the geso fry (squid tentacles), ankimo, nuclear roll, spicy dragon roll and a couple nigiri (ikura, unagi and otoro). The squid was crispy without being overdone, the rolls were spicy and yummy and the nigiri was fresh. The servers were friendly and made sure that our tea cups were always filled and our food was brought out promptly.

Right around when we got our rolls one of the regulars who was sitting next to me starting gesturing in front of my face and complaining very loudly that a bottle of sake she had left at the restaurant had been drunk without her knowledge. The owner appeared to be slightly embarrassed and politely asked her to turn down the volume.  She retorted that she was quieter than other patrons, which she was not.

I will definitely be back here again but hopefully not at the same time as Ms. Sake.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
***my hella starving party were very patient... OH SO VERY PATIENT***

-sushi is above average (rather good, actually!), but....
- the service was horrible: waitress forgot to put in the bulk of our order, so we were staving off our hunger by nibbling on appetizers (which came in 20 minutes after we placed our order) and engaging in conversation for another 45 minutes.
-my friends' rolls come in, while I wait for another 30 minutes for my special roll, only to find out that they "ran out of sushi rice," despite the fact that we were there over an hour before the arrival of other customers, who were getting their orders prepared.

*it would greatly help to alert the customer that you are "out of sushi rice" when you actually do "run out"
