*sorry if this is a really crappy review, but waiting for almost 2 hours for our food is not cool.

***This review should be full of F-Bombs... but I'm being patient... OH SO VERY PATIENT***
author: Grace M.

description: The nigiris that we got were much skimpier on the fish than the picture shows online...and hamachi kama was only half the size of elsewhere but for the same price...maybe there was some kind of cost cutting effort?  Im not sure i will be back.
author: Adele W.

description:
Hey...you know...maybe it doesn't have the most creative of menus...but the stuff it has is super tasty. The sashimi was VERY fresh and really tasty.

I must have walked by this place several hundred times and never thought to walk into it. I mean, the sign...it really isn't inviting. There's only one place that shyed me away more (It sounds like UC Sushi...makes me think they should have called that place "I see dead fish").

The staff here is really friendly and welcoming. Their specials menu can sometimes, it seems, be out of date and have things they might be out of, but that's OK it is a specials menu.

Yum Yum
author: H B.

description:
Some of the best, freshest fish I've ever had came from Kazu. He maintains a rather dynamic specials board so you know whats really fresh and can handily try new things. Also, bang for the buck, considering the quality of the fish and size of the cuts, seems above average here.

Finally, tipping the scale is the ambiance. Most other sushi places I'm familiar with that provide this quality of food are either too loud, too bright, or the service is too slow, Kazu's place is dim, generally quiet, with maybe a small group enjoying themselves at the bar.

For these reasons, Kazu has quickly become a favorite.
author: Essron J.

description:
Anyone that knows me knows that I cannot eat fish. So why did I come to sushi kazu? Well... There is this little man that I love very much who LOVES sushi and before we met, used to eat it every other day. Since he met me, he's lucky to eat it every other month. Not that I keep him from his beloved sushi. It's just we don't go to places that are fish only restaurants. But last night, we did. He was happy. I was happy he was happy. 

I went for all the non-fish stuff. So if you are a sushi lover and reading my review to learn what's good and what's not about their sushi, you can skip right past my review. Thank you, come again! 

If you want to know what's good on their appetizer and specials menu, please, keep reading. 

My favorite thing of the entire evening was the Chicken karaage. They definitely use free range chicken for this dish. It's very tender and super juicy. They pour ponzu sauce over the chicken that is sitting on a bed of lettuce and thinly sliced red onion. After I ate the chicken, I ate the lettuce which was by that time, warm and drenched in ponzu. SO GOOD. 

My second favorite thing was the shiobuta kakuni. This is a huge slice of thick salted pork belly that seems like it has been slow cooking for days and days. The fat, though still intact, melts on your tongue like warm butter. The meat is soft and flavorful. Usually, I cannot eat huge pieces of fat on a regular grilled pork belly. But this fat was much different and MUCH better. 

The gyoza were awesome! I like that they put a little hot chili oil in the shoyu dipping sauce. 

The tsukune were HUGE. Almost as big as tennis balls. But they lacked flavor, sadly. 

The service is ok. Pretty slow. There's really only one server and she was running around like crazy alllllllll night. But other than that, no complaints.
author: Jen D.

description:
Chirashi break!

It wasn't even on the menu, which makes it better.  The chef chose ten different fish, one slice each cut thick and perfect, arranged artistically amidst the usual tamago, octopus and shrimp on extra good sushi rice with more than your usual garnishes -- a carved lemon, fresh crab meat, perfectly shaped shiso leaf, daikon sprouts, sesame sprinkles....it seriously took him at least ten minutes of constant attention and it came out a work of art.

How was it?  The fish was ultra fresh and well textured, that perfect sushi temperature.

The fish is a new friend.  Five days later I am still grinning.

They have the usual line of Japanese and American sushi items but a  wider fish selection than most, plus five or six special fish and some things written only in Japanese.  Things I never heard of.  Rolls come thin and nigiri large, as it should be.  A whole page of appetizers, half standard (sunomono, agtedashi tofu, wakame, hamachi kama) and half new-style (tatami tower).  What you won't find are comfort items like noodle soups or sukiyaki.  Strictly sushi.

The decor is clean, modern, bright, and stylish without sacrificing the basic respect that it is sushi.  Music is a CD of light but upbeat instrumental jazz.  It is a very small restaurant with only a few seats.

Things are a step upscale.  Miso soup is extra good with many seaweed squares and no tofu pieces.  Soy sauce comes in a small clay pitcher, not a glass bottle.  A steamed napkin.

You pay extra here but not as much as you think.  Worth it if you can afford it.  If not, be like me.  Order a special and skip the alcohol and apps.  Finish your rice, boy.
author: Gil S.

description:
I was extremely disappointed by this highly rated sushi restaurant. And I am not one of those picky, snooty restaurant go-ers. I am easy to please and hard to disappoint...I rarely review places on Yelp, but I felt compelled to warn all of you out there in inner sunset seeking to satisfy your sushi craving like i was...

In a nutshell: Our food took forever to come out. Miso soup and tempura appetizers didn't come out until after our rolls. The "specialty rolls" which are already too expensive ($11-$13) only contained FOUR pieces! Our last roll never even made it to our table because we got tired of waiting and asked for the check. Rice came out at the end. Sushi was okay at best. We noticed that every couple or individual that came in after us and had reservations were waiting around in the tiny, cramped doorway for at least 20-30 minutes.

Overall: Sushi and service is not worth the price here. Take your business to one of the many other restaurants in inner sunset to satiate your sushi tooth!
author: Stella C.

description:
wow definitely worth the 2nd trip while back in SF for the holiday week,  my sister is a regular there, if I still was in SF and worked at UCSF I'd be a regular here as well.

Food: great fish quality and selection, b/c of them I'm not a fan of ocean trout sashimi

Service: excellent they are always very attentive but not too pushy as to intrude in your conversations

Ambiance:  cozy little spot that can get full fairly quickly, but those small little holes in the wall are like usually the best spots to hit up, very clean and well decorated

If you are in the neighborhood make sure to check this spot out if its not too crowded.
I will be back for sure in a few weeks when I'm on Christmas break, I love to support family owned businesses that strive to bring high quality food and great service
author: Christopher C.

description:
Pork belly......pork belly......pork belly............makes all my problems on Earth go away. In fact, this whole place is my answer to any bad day. Extra kudos to the Ultimate Crunch Spicy Tuna roll and the Rainbow Roll. Wonderful service, they always remember us when we come in. Kazu himself works at the bar every night, and if you're cool he'll even give you free samples of new stuff on the menu that he's trying out (and sometimes a free Sapporo). 

Best sushi place in SF. My girlfriend and I cannot go anywhere else for sushi, we've been too spoiled by Kazu. It's slightly pricier than other sushi places, and I suppose all sushi places are, but its not going to put  you in the poor house so try to make it a once or twice a month occassion.
author: Stu C.

description:
Kazu is the man.  He was the ex-head chef for Ten-Ichi on Fillmore but because of his mad ninja skills, he was able to start his own restaurant.  Good for him!  Really.

The restaurant is small but clean.  It would be good for small groups.  The bar only holds 5 people so that's kind of a bummer, but at least you will get the attention of the staff without a problem.

Kazu-san at the helm, whips up some derishus sushi rolls that he creates on the fly.  I named one.  It's called the Bay Area Roll.  It's a salmon skin/avacado/herring amalgamation of East meets West SIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIDE.

Kazu-san still needs to work on his sake bomb preperation, but as long as he gets pointers from his ex-mate over at Ten-Ichi, Johnny-san, he should be fine.  Johnny B Goode.

You won't find a bigger cut of hamachi in the country!
author: Hodie K.

description:
Sorry, but the service really was awful last night. I was with 3 others, and after the appetizers (which came on time and together), each person's meal come one after the other.  

It's like we were all going throught a drive-thru one by one, only sitting down.

To top it off, my dish, the sashimi platter, came last!  This is not paella cooked inside unleavended bread under a wood fired stone buried in a morroccan desert sand oven or some such.  Hello, I'd like some cut, uncooked fish placed on a clean plate. Oh, that'll be 40 minutes please.

If they couldn't get that straight, then I got a little worried that they didn't do the sashimi right (i.e., kept clean, fresh, etc).  In fact, very uncharacteristically of me, I didn't finish it b/c something was rotten in the state of Denmark: something tasted, well, fishy.

So that just made me less predisposed to this place:

-- The chairs were wierd (folding, I later realized), so whenever I tried to move my chair, it would seem to catch on the rug when in fact it was folding up.

-- Music.  This is a sushi restaurant, not a club in the castro.  Okay, a slight exaggeration.  But why do restaurants to this nowadays?  Why don't they put in garish, hard plastic seating while they're at it?  Or those bird spikes found on building ledges?

-- Large, round plates didn't fit well on the small table.  I see why the rectangular dish rules in sushi joints.

-- I didn't think the selection was particularly interesting (cod and other fish are big these days, but not at this place yet).

There are lots of great sushi joints out there- this isn't worth revisiting for a while, in my book.  

I think the problem is that they seated us before our party had all arrived, and we spent some time between ordering appetizers (which were fine and on time) and ordering the main dishes. This is where they fell apart, and they couldn't get us back in the queue.  Maybe they were squeezing in our plates whenever they could, which is why we got them piecemeal.  Sigh.
author: T W.

description:
Food: 3.5 stars
Service: 2.5 stars
Total: 3 stars

The appetizers came out quickly and I enjoyed the gomae, agedashi tofu and grilled hamachi collar. Didn't like my miso soup very much though, it was bland. Weird, isn't it hard to mess up miso soup? Maybe it was just an off day for the soup. Hope it  was an off day for the service too because they were extremely slow getting the sushi out to our table of 4. My friend's sashimi plate order came out last, after the rest of us had already finished our meals! So well, we kept him company while he ate. I thought my nigiri sushi and rolls were delicious (although not melt-in-your-mouth, amazing fish) but my friend was disapointed with his long awaited sashimi. The place was packed and there was only one server. She was nice and somewhat apologetic about the long wait for the food.

Bottom line for sushi (based on taste only) in this part of the Sunset: Way better than Ebisu . Better than Kiki's. Comparable to Koo.
author: Trinh T.

description:
I've eaten at Sushi Kazu on 5 different occasions now. Why would I keep going back, you might ask, if I only rate it 3 stars? The dilemma is in the food vs. service, as has been noted by several others. We eat at sushi bars all over the Bay Area and the fish and creations on offer at Kazu are excellent.  

It has a very intimate and authentic atmosphere. 

The problem is that there is only one dedicated server (Kazu's wife, I believe). Her demeanor and service are great. The problem is her efforts alone are simply insufficient when the restaurant is over ~ 50% capacity.  I'd had one bad experience with service there before last night and last night drove it home for me. I was without water for a good portion of the meal (which was close to 2 hours for 3 rolls and 1 order of sashimi). 

Luckily we received our first roll inside of 15 minutes (which saved my wife from eating her hand) but then we literally had a 30+ minute wait before the second roll arrived.  No matter how good the food is, that type of delay makes for an unpleasant dining experience.

SO now I've learned my lesson about Sushi Kazu. To enjoy their excellent fare, here is what you do: 

1) Drive, bike, walk or scooter to the adequate front window of the restaurant.

2) Look inside.

Here's where we come to the "choose your own adventure" part:

3a) If there are several seats at the sushi bar and the tables are less than half-occupied, you're in luck! Go in, grab a seat at the sushi bar (best service) or at least be sure to order quickly from your table (make sure you check out the specials whiteboard) and pray that large numbers of people don't show up until your food is served.

3b) If the sushi bar is mostly full and the tables look fairly full, KEEP MOVING - go on to Koo, Ebisu or Ten (I would recommend in that order)...all also along the Irving Inner Sunset corridor and serving excellent to solid fare in their own right. Come back to Kazu on another night. It's that simple.

If you continue in to Sushi Kazu when it is over 50% occupancy, it is at your own peril and you can not later claim that you haven't been warned.

Though Ebisu or Koo may be more crowded (you may have a longer wait for a table) rest assured that your total dining experience will  take less time. And I'm not arguing that a meal needs to be fast to be enjoyable...just efficient in the sense that so long as you are ordering food and drink it is brought to you in a fairly expeditious manner.

Good luck!
author: Noel B.

description: I remember eating here a while ago.  I'm catching up right now with writing reviews and this place didn't stick out too much, but I probably should give it a second chance since everyone is giving it an average of 4 stars.  I remember the service was ok and the food was just ok.
author: John H.

description:
I'm torn!  

The Sushi is 4 - 5 stars.  The service is 2 stars. Can I give 3.5 stars? Ok, I very reluctantly settle on 4.... 

First the food:  
Hamachi sashimi
Tai nigiri
wakame
miso soup
and some sort of specialty Super Spicy Crunchy Tuna Maki

Everything was very fresh and tasty, and I really had no complaints.

The service:
One woman was responsible for all 8 tables in the restaurant.  I've waited tables most my life, and that's just too much to handle.  It's not this poor woman's fault, it's just too hard to do 85 things promptly all at once, in fact it's humanly impossible.
Our poor, flustered waitress was trying her best, but jeeze, give the woman a break and hire some more help!
author: Shayna N.

description:
Thanks to Danny @ Sebo for pointing out this place to me, as I had passed it many times before eating there.  Don't be put off by some of the crazy names of rolls on the menu.  Kazu is a legit talent.  And conveniently for me, the restaurant is much easier to get into than Koo.  Don't skip the wonderfully varied and extensive selection of hot dishes.  The grilled sardines and saba misoni were very nice.

The service is both professional and warm, and the interior has an air of calm and class that nicely contrasts the restaurant's busy surroundings.
author: Ben R.

description:
Non-nigiri items at Kazu are pretty good: regular makimono are pretty good here.  I also had a fried small fish appetizer here that was really good too.

But let's be serious.  Nigiri is the reason I eat at sushi bars.  Kazu Sushi's nigiri have not been very consistent.

Kazu's sushi rice is some of the best I have ever had: just enough vinegar, each grain tender, not mushy, and just sticky enough to be cohesive with its neighbor.

The fish, though always fresh, was better on my first visit because it was cut more neatly.  On my first visit, I sat at the bar and ordered mainly off the specials board.  That had a good variety for fresh local and imported fish, many not commonly seen on menus in SF.  I had a great meal.

On my second visit, sitting at a table rather than at the bar, I got a sushi combination dinner, and the knifework was kind of shoddy: the fish was all raggedly cut, and didn't sit on top of the rice quite as well.  However, the uni nigiri I got were eyes-rolling-back delicious.

Perhaps the chef will do a better job on the fish if you're sitting at the bar or ordering something more interesting than the same ol' maguro/sake/hamachi/tai standards. I'll be sure to test this theory in the future.
author: Suo L.

description:
My sister and I decided on this place and man, it was good!  She had the Hawaiian roll and I had the Dragon roll.  She liked hers and my Dragon roll was the best I have ever had.  We both decided to get another one since we had worked up an appetite moving furniture.  She got an Alaskan roll and I got the Zig Zag roll.  I highly recommend the Zig Zag roll!!  It was very good!  Try it, you just might like it.
The atmosphere was quiet and quaint.  The service was awesome, especially the warm towels before the meal.  The food came out quick and the presentation was very nice.  The only thing I have a problem with is it's in the city and I live in the East Bay.    

Easily five stars all the way!!!
author: David S.

description: Sushi was good, customer service was poor. We stood in the doorway 15 minutes before even being approached. Once we sat down check-ins were sparse. My wife waited until we finished all of our sushi for her wakame salad and asked for additional ginger three times before it came. It's fairly pricey too for what you get sushi wise.
author: Roman I.

description: Simple and nothing out of the ordinary, but this spot has really fresh ingredients as well as the fish.  I cant stand going to the 101 other sushi spots in the city that serve low grade fish.  Would recommend this for the not so crowded sushi spots on weekdays of course!
author: Bo Y.

description: It is good but they do charge a pretty penny for medium deliciousness.  I'd rather eat at Koo.
author: Erika C.

description:
Kazu is one of the best if not the best traditional sushi restaurants in San Francisco. If you are looking for the ordinary experience of California and dragon rolls and a few pieces of tuna nigiri, you may or may not find Kazu to your liking. But if you enjoy ordering off the specials board, and enjoy cooked food as well as sushi, you're in for a treat.

The fish Kazu carries is exquisite. I have for sure had the best hamachi at Kazu that I have had in 20 years of steady sushi eating all over the United States. Fish does vary from day to day no matter where you are, but the quality at Kazu is consistently excellent, and the variety is as good as at Sushi Sam's in San Mateo.

In addition to sake and beer, Kazu carries shochu, which is a pleasant treat if you are into that sort of thing. (I am.)

Like many traditional sushi restaurants, table service may be slow ("relaxed"), so be prepared to get your entire order in at once, and don't expect your food to arrive all at once (it won't). If you want to order a bit at a time, you need to sit at the bar.  It is not necessarily expected that a waitress will take a second order for food (unless you have specifically ordered just appetizers) from a table.

If you want to eat at the bar, call for a reservation at least a day ahead. Sometimes it's full all evening.

If you are a genuine connoisseur of Japanese food other than sushi, you may be able to arrange other meals (like sukiyaki) with Kazu, given a week or two of notice, although I wouldn't advise scheduling it on a busy night.

For parking, drive toward 12th on Irving.
author: Joseph H.

description:
Is the sushi fresh?  Yes

Is the service slow?  Yes

Will they let you sit there all night bantering with the sushi chef and nursing your sake?  Yes

Is the o-toro ridiculous decadent for a ridiculously undecadent price of 2 for $12?  Yes

Is the format of this review worth continuing?  No

This is a great neighborhood sushi place and now one of my new favorites in SF.  Please only tell cool people - we don't want to ruin it by making it too crowded with fake-me-out sushi fans.
author: Jason S.

description:
If you're not a regular Ammmbs reader let me clarify by saying that I love sushi, know sushi and don't mind paying $$ for my sushi-within reason. Stop the whining non-sushi types.

Updated 06/24/07.    I had outstanding sushi here that was ordered primarily from the specials menu.  The highlights included hirasama, ocean trout, kona kanpachi and kanpachi kamma-not sushi but it's it available try it. 

The food is very good and reasonably priced.  The saba shioyaki and miso cod are excellent.  The fish is fresh and flown in from Japan so go here instead of Ebisu if can do without the line and all the fancy rolls.
author: Amber L.

description:
This place is Japanese owned, and I can tell in the style of their dishes. Usually, when you go to a Japanese-fusion/Americanized Sushi restaurant, you see a lot of deep-fried rolls, ones with cream cheese, or so spicy that it overpowers the fish you can't really taste the fish. But I know, it's the sushi that america had created, so I take it in and appreciate it the way it is. 

But Kazu is cool because even though it's got the Americanized sushi of the roll culture, it's fusioned with a Japanese flavor. For example, we ordered a roll that had yuzu miso on it. Or another roll that had yama-imo on top. I liked it, because it was different than they typical sushi place here, and you can really appreciate the flavor of the fish. Straight up, Japanese-steez.
author: Emy s.

description:
On principle I'd normally eat at a place twice before writing a review, but there's no way I'm going back.

To start with, you walk in off the street and you're almost in the kitchen.  I've been in small restaurants plenty of times.  I appreciate intimate and quaint settings.  But there's something awkward about waiting for your table while breathing on other people's food.  

The place was packed.  No seats at the bar and there was a party of ten or so in the corner.  Maybe that's why the service was awful.  It took a while for the one waitress attending to everyone in the restaurant  to come over to us to give us menus.  After that, it took a while for us to get our tea.  

When we finally got a chance to order, half the stuff we wanted wasn't available.  The ankimo, and 4 of our sashimi choices were unavailable (ankimo, mirugai, aji, super white tuna).  We settled for some tempura as an appetizer.  Highly disappointing.  It was soggy with grease.  No crunchy-crispiness to it.  

Our sashimi was average.  Not stellar.  We've had better elsewhere.  We had hamachi, kanpachi, and another I can't remember.  We had a Double double roll, which was actually decent.

As alluded to earlier, service was sub-par throughout our meal.  When we finally got our bill, we realized how overpriced this place is for the kind of meal we had.

In the end - not going back.  For a better dining experience and better quality sushi, try Nama Sushi in Daly City (next to the movie theater) or Barracuda.
author: Maovish X.

description:
This restaurant was a great find. The line at Ebisu was too long, and we went around the corner and found a cozy, much less crowded sushi place. 

The service was a little slow, but the food was well worth it. Sushi came in surprisingly good sized pieces and tasted wonderfully fresh. Salmon and yellowtail are my favorites. The specials rolls are very creative and tasted delicious. 

If you can, go sit at the bar. It's fun to watch the sushi chefs work. Both of them are very nice, especially the younger assistant chef.  He was a little backed up on orders and kept apologizing. He was so nice and friendly though that I couldn't bare to make him feel bad. It's also very reasonably priced. I highly recommend this place.
author: Jen N.

description:
Probably my favorite sushi place in the city. I've had multiple people tell me it's the best sushi they've ever had. Some of their rolls are a bit on the modern side, but I think they're done with a nod to traditional ingredients. Their combinations really approach cuisine art.

In rolls, I recommend the Hamachi Dragon & the Double Double. I'm not as much of a sashimi fiend, but what I've had has been very fresh & tasty. Check out the specials that float around on the little dry-erase board as well.

The space is pretty tiny, but I've never not been able to get a seat. Might not be the case if you're planning on going on a weekend night. Everyone is very friendly and they have good attention to detail (warm hand towels when you arrive). Prices are also very reasonable for San Francisco.

One small note: the place isn't exactly centrally heated (though they do make a nice if doomed attempt at keeping you comfortable with a rotating space heater) so if it's a cold day or you often shiver in your extremities, wear an extra layer.
author: jim o.

description:
I was hoping it'd measure up to my beloved Chika so I don't have to drive to San Mateo to satisfy my craving for good Japanese food anymore.  I was disappointed.  For two people, we ordered Ankimo, agedashi tofu, hotate nigiri, uni nigiri, unagi nigiri and the King Kong roll.   All were just so mediocre.  And agedashi tofu came last for some reason, and I felt like if I were to ever attempt agedashi tofu at home, I would result in something like that.  Considering how (in)experienced I am at cooking, that is NOT a compliment. 

And for that little amount of food (had to get bread pudding at Tart-to-Tart after wards), it was around $40.  For this place?  hmmmm.  I guess I better make a trip to San Mateo next time.
author: Candice B.

description:
I came here via Yelp, big ups to all you guys. I can see how fish quality can vary from night to night, anyways, this was my visit

great 
- salmon
- tako (octopus)
- spicy hamachi roll
- hamachi dragon roll

nice 
- asahi or sapporo large

just ok
- moriawase (mixed), comes with miso soup and rice
- tuna
- butter roll (kyoshu? not on the menu), the seared fish they had on top was kinda bleh (hamachi? see below)

sucky
- this huge hamachi chunk i got, wtf (two pieces that coulda been cut to four or more.. in the end quality was questionable)
- kitchen / chef be slowness
- the place is so tiny
- bring your Japanese speaking friends for better service, maybe

to try
- ankimo (uhh $9)
- crunchy roll
author: xo x.

description:
I know 3 stars is a little hard for this place but let me explain. 
The food is a 4.5 stars, the rolls are good, the fish is fresh, it's a good sushi place as they know what they are doing behind the counters. 
The thing that needs to change there are the waitresses... have you seen chicken without heads running? This is what it looks like.... there is no organization at all, they run in every direction, don't talk to each other and make opposite decisions (therefore can annoy customers...). 
If you call to make a reservation, make sure they take your name, or they will make you wait (even if you call to see if they have space... I saw it for a couple, and they were not happy) 
So, someone needs to go there, train them a little, organize something. 
Waitresses, sorry about that, but I give you a big fat 1 star. 
Other than that, the place is nice, wait seems long (I always order for pick up and I still end up waiting an extra 20 mins....) and I think I will keep ordering to go so I don't have to deal with these waitresses.
author: Pascal P.

description:
Now, of all the sushi restaurants I've been to in the City, Sushi Kazu stands above all the rest. 

This is coming from someone who loves, loves, loves Sashimi and as a general rule, deplores sushi rolls. I am not a sushi snob, but a sushi purist - I believe that the best sushi does not need soy sauce, eel sauce, or any other condiment to cover up the fresh, slightly sweet taste of a perfectly cut piece of fish. 

With that said, I ordered off the "white-board menu" which are the Kazu specials. All sashimi was of the finest quality! Perfect temperature, perfectly cut, perfectly tasty. I ordered the scallop, sweet shrimp, kampachi, toro, mackeral, some sort of special Japanese mackeral that is only in season a few months of the year (i forget the name), albacore, hamachi, chicken kaarage, pork belly, carpaccio, and the tofu salad. 

Although I usually avoid it, I actually have tried the rolls before, and they are very good as well, much tastier and more creative than your average sushi restaurant.  Steer clear of Japan Town - this place will please everyone, except anyone who likes soupy stuff like udon and soba. Unfortunately, they don't serve it. :(
author: D N.

description:
This place is great. A cute little 100% japanese owned place in SF. Refreshing! They have a decent menu but more interesting are the items on the special board, which is what I always go for.
We had:

amaebi- fresh, good, not the best but at $7 it came with three fried heads! That was the best part. I guess some "Lo-fans" (chinese folks will know what I am talking about) at the bar ordered the same but didnt want the fried head. Ch-ching for us!
Hamachi toro nigri-yummy
King Kong roll forgot what was in it but it was crunchy and it was good.
chicken meatballs-there is a japanese name for it but I cannot remember- they were juicy, and well seasoned not too salty
Kampachi nigiri-awesome, fresh
some other nigiri,  I cannot remember 

overall was very good and not too expensive ($4.50) for nigiri-$7 for specials

They have some very unique cuts of fish that you dont get anywhere else or your run of the mill japanese restaurants which I LIKE!

Service is good. Next time I will try the sushi bar.
author: Petri Y.

description: Followed yelpers' advice and ordered the special rolls. Delicious. It seems short-staffed with so many tables and only one waitress, but it worked. The food came out in a reasonable amount of time. I would've liked a little more service- but it's fine.
author: Janelle V.

description:
I believe we were there on the same night as graceypoo. 

They did run out of sushi rice and asked us to wait a further 15 mins. 

We waited over an hour to receive our ordered items.

So, why the 4 stars?

Every sushi restaurant I go to; I order the Hamachi nigiri as a comparison, a sort of a sushi litmus paper, if you will.
The Hamachi here Rocked. The 'neta' fresh, juicy and large. the 'shari' warm, plump and sweet. Hands down the best Hamachi nigiri i have yet to devour in SF. I wished i ordered more nigiri instead of the rolls. 

Yes, it took a while for our order and this can be disheartening to anyone thinking of dining here but the service was polite and friendly. They were courteous enough to give us some edamame while we waited and a sashimi salad with our dinner, both on the house.

All in all, I'll be back with dinner full of nigiri and hopefully they don't run out of rice....i mean is there a shortage?
author: Tak H.

description:
4 1/2 Stars for food.  It filled a flavor void that I had been missing for so long.  The last couple of times we had sushi in the neighborhood I left feeling cheated.  Kazu made my tastebuds very happy!  The hamachi kama came out very last however made a lasting impression, it was perfectly grilled and nicely seasoned.  The ultimate crunchy spicy tuna roll was excellent, the king kong roll was good, I almost would have wanted to try the hamachi on it's own, but the flavors all worked together very well.  We had the unagi, buttery, warm and tender....just as it should be.  The grilled squid was good.....enough squid for 4 or 5 people...wonderfully charred and seasoned!  All in all we had a great dinner...the service was a little slow, but I think it was due to the fact that it was a busy Saturday night and only one server.

* one note, when we arrived we were asked if we had reservations (7pm on a Sat...I understand that), however we were given a time limit, however the food took longer than our limit, and when we left there were still 2 four top tables available.  ??
author: Brye L.

description: Good servingness. Hamachi toro melts in my mouth not in my hands. Good pricingness too.
author: Michael B.

description: Was in the market for some Sushi last night and after seeing Kazu I busted out my Android and took a quick look on Yelp to see how many stars that they had. We were definitely not let down.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Small, intimate sushi bar and restaurant with friendly service.  Sushi selection is v. fresh but limited, as is the seating at the bar.  Amenities (I like the oshibori, hot towel) and sake selection are very good.  Good off-menu items, where the owner, Kazu-san, demonstrates his expertise in choosing and preparing foods.

I've never been here when it is really busy, so I don't know how service is at these times.  I've only tried the Shisamo appetizer, which was good but standard fare.  There are many other Japanese dishes on the menu.  Many customers know Kazu from his prior restaurant.  There is parking on street (difficult) and in a city lot between 8th and 9th.
author: YearOf M.

description:
There are so many reviews about this place and their slow service for parties more than 2. Basically, if you are hungry and you're here with your friends, you're screwed in an unsatisfying way because you'll be left so hungry that you'd lick the bottom of any plate. My friend had been here a couple of times and suggested this place for dinner. Boy...we were disappointed.

The service was horrendous. We were a party of four and arrived at 6:30PM. We didn't have to wait very long for a table as they were clearing a table. The party in front of us (two kids) were sat maybe a minute or two before us. When did they get their food? Almost an hour and a half before ours. We sat there for about 15+ minutes before our order was taken. We sat there for 1+ hours while we waited for our order to arrive. One of our friend's roll came out about a little over an hour. Ours...twenty mins later. 

I will say that the rolls were tasty, but they added my friend's roll on my plate and when I tried to move it into another plate, the roll disassembled. The rice kept sticking to the other rolls. I had the spicy veggie tempura, florida roll, and the spicy scallop roll. The prices were reasonable. I paid $18 for three rolls and a can of coke.

However, back to the service...our teas were rarely filled. I had to wait ten mins for my first a cup of tea. When the waitress asked us if everything was okay, I told her that we ran out of soy sauce a while ago, our teas had to be refreshed, and we still didn't get the last two rolls. There was one waitress and two sushi chefs. I've been to other sushi restaurants that know how to bang out delicious sushi quickly. 

I don't know what the chefs are doing at Kazu Sushi. Maybe while you wait, they run to the ocean to catch your fish before slicing it up and finally serving it...an hour later.

We thought we'd have a quick dinner, but we didn't end up leaving until almost 8:30PM because the service was THAT slow. I'd definitely pass on this place. Not worth it unless you want to spend half your evening waiting for your food.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
If you are looking for good, fresh sushi, Kazu is 99.9% reliable to satisfy your desire for sushi. First off, I'd recommend sitting at bar b/c the staff is very kind and the head chef for sushi is quite a character in a good way. Anyways, I've tried every single sushi there, and everything tastes different and delightful. The unago tastes great if you want a different style of eel than unagi, and the Ama Ebi tastes nearly perfect and what Ama Ebi should taste like.

On a side note, the restaurant is quite comfortable and very welcoming. The volume never gets remotely close to out of control or even annoying, but there is slight noise like all other restaurants. Definitely a great place to go if you want good sushi.
author: Dylan T.

description: not sure what all the high ratings are for...i've had much better at places that are only a few steps away. i won't be going back.
author: Cat T.

description:
Skip the line (and the smell of dead fish) at Ebisu on 9th ave and walk a 1/2 block to Kazu. A family run business that has some of the best Sushi in the city (in my opinion). 

I used to go for sushi on "sushi row" around Geary & 18th Ave, but my favorite place closed! (We miss you Peter!). Found Kazu - and it's my new watering...er, sushi hole.

They have all the staples one might expect in a sushi restaurant but consider ordering off of the specials board, they always have fresh fish of the day and inventive rolls. I've been after the Kona Kampachi lately - awesome!

Biggest complaint? The secret's out, and the place can get crowded on a weekend. Sometimes I have to sit at a table as opposed to the sushi bar (gasp!).
author: Craig G.

description:
I liked this place the moment I stepped in. They were playing Jamiroquai and the hostess was Japanese (a rarity in SF nowadays). To make it even better, the sushi chefs/owner was Japanese also (again, a rarity since most seem to be Chinese or Korean owned, and sushi chefs Mexican).

We had almost everything on (and off) the menu and it was ALL delicious. Ask for the off-menu butter roll. Its got to be one of the best tasting rolls I've had anywhere.

The service was hit or miss. It was a busy night, but sometimes it took way too long for more tea to come or if we wanted to order more. The food did take a while to get to us. My sushi dinner arrived after everyone else had finished their food, so I was left eating by myself while everyone watched.

Prices were pretty steep also (ouch!). Pricey, hit-or miss service, slow food arrival.... but hey, the food itself made up for it. Oh, and parking sucked balls.
author: Rocky K.

description: The miso soup that I tried there was OK. I really like the spoon! But their menu with Today's special is funny - the waitress is just carrying it, though it's a huge board, from table to table. Nothing special about decor... Just a regular sushi bar.
author: Katie K.

description:
First the good:
-The fish was fresh and tasty

And now the bad:
-Ungodly slow service (food for the 5 of us arrived over the course of 1 hour)
-Mistakes with the check (took our cash and still tried to charge us the entire amount of the check)

To be fair, they did fix the problem with the check but it was a pretty big mistake to be made in the first place.  Still, given that our party made up half of the occupancy in the restaurant you'd think that we would have gotten better (i.e. faster) service.  Even getting the process of getting the check after we made it clear we were done with our food was painfully slow.  Maybe it's because they just opened, but for now the service is unacceptable.
author: Casey M.

description:
I thought Koo was one of the better places in the Inner Sunset but after having tried Kazu there's no doubt that this is really the top restaurant. No comparison to Ebisu either. The sushi is probably the freshest in the area. We have sampled almost all the ones on the menu so far. The toro, scallops and hamachi are esp. delicious according to family members. As I'm preggers right now, I'm staying away but could see from the look of the fish and the look on everyone faces that they're fantastic. The mackerel looked good too but of course I couldn't have that either...

My personal favorites are the kamikaze roll, goma-ae (spinach salad with sesame) and the black cod. Also tried a few pieces of the soft shell crab rolls, which were fabulous. The miso soup was a joy as someone had mentioned before - not salty and far from overpowering.

Small place, so it's good to come early and during the week. Service is super nice and can be a bit slow at times but hopefully they will hire one more server soon.
author: Hadley K.

description:
Went with a friend at 7:30 on a Monday.
The King Kong roll was delicious - a great balance between (cooked) fish, tobiko, and greens. The Caterpillar was great too, good eel and avocado. Also tried one with mackerel, which had a nice contrast of saltiness and ginger. We also got the California roll. All recommended.

The place was very cozy and had just the right amount of people - almost filled to capacity, but not; and not too loud, but definitely some background chatter and jazz music.

Like a few other reviewers it seems, I find Ebisu to be overrated, and was very happy to have such a pleasant experience here. As others have also commented, though, the service is indeed slow - food takes a while, drinks aren't refilled quite as fast as you like. I feel this is justified because they put a lot of care into everything; whether or not you agree with this will probably determine how much you like Kazu Sushi.

Our bill for the four rolls and an order of nigiri tuna was $31 - not cheap, but not exorbitant.
author: Max M.

description:
BAD service. Food took way too long, waitress/owner(?) was scatterbrained.  They brought one dish after another (v. at the same time). Crappiest dining out experience I've ever had.

It was a Wed night too - not much people. Its sad. Not going back there.
author: David Q.

description:
The atmosphere is simple, clean, modern. 

The sushi was really, really good and fresh. Very well made. I like how their sushi sampler doesn't come with a roll that makes you feel gross afterward because you just ate too much. Yes, it's my fault, but come on, it's hard not to eat.

The service was slow because there's only one server.  

She was nice enough but so busy, she was constantly running around.  You have to actively get her attention if you need something. 

In fact there is only one sushi chef and probably only one cook in the back, so things are slow. But in my experience, decent sushi restaurants are always slow no matter how many chefs are there. 

So if you are in hurry, this is not the place. But if you want a decent place for date or guests or even casual meal out that is low key and not tacky, this is the place.
author: Suze W.

description:
I LOVE this place.  The chefs, Kazu and  Kiyoshi, are very personable.  Kazu's wife is the waitress, and their young daughter, who can be found running around the place, is a sweetheart.  The first time I ate here with my friend, we stayed until closing.  Kazu would make whatever we requested based on our personal favorites, and also let us try some interesting dishes that weren't necessarily on the menu, including giving us a complimentary bottle of unfiltered, cold sake.  

The presentation of their food is amazing, and the fish is fresh, and tasty.  It's a perfect sushi place without all the hype - very quaint, and homey.  I recommend sitting at the sushi bar and striking up conversation with the chefs.  They really do their best to cater to your needs and requests.

If you're not in a hurry, it's a comfortable, relaxing, and friendly place to eat delicious sushi!  

Mmmm...I just talked myself into getting some sushi right now!
author: C. R.

description: Why go here instead of Ebisu?  Let me spell it out for you F-R-E-S-H-E-R F-I-S-H.  Plus, you can get a table right away.  Nuff said.
author: Ted R.

description: Always delicious, always a good time, always pleased. Convenient fun location, fresh specials and a well rounded menu.  Great service in a small-ish place - so it's nice and quiet in case you want something a bit intimate. All in all this is one of my go-to Sushi spots in SF.  Thanks for being there Kazu!
author: Artnok A.

description:
Having just moved back to SF from LA, my fiancee and I have been searching for a great place to find some hamachi.  I ordered the sashimi dinner (all hamachi) and was amazed to find approx. 12 thickly cut slices of FRESH hamachi!  the presentation was subtle and elegant, the service was friendly, and they even had Kanpachi (a kind of yellowtail that has eluded me over the years).  

We also had the Chicken Karaage which is super tender and fried ever so delicately!  We can't wait to go back!
author: Russ N.

description: I stopped in for dinner last night with my GF. The service was a little bit slow, but the waitress was friendly.  The food presentation was very nice and was also tasty. Portions were a little small for the price charged I felt.
author: Neramitt S.

description:
OMG, how I love Sushi Kazu!!! The sushi is delicious and the staff is delightful. I would definitely recommend sitting at the bar to get the full experience. You get to watch your food being prepared as you chat it up with Kiyoshi and Kazu behind the counter, while downing bottles and bottles of sake with your resident sushi chefs. 

The Kanpachi and the Hawaiian Roll are absolutely to die for!!! Ummmm, sooooo yummy!!! I love, love, love the food and the guys at Sushi Kazu and would eat there everyday, but my wallet cries at the thought. Boo.

Update: Order the Butter Roll. It's not on the menu. OMG~! ORGASMIC!!!
author: Glory W.

description:
I would say this is a hidden gem ion 9th&Irving crowds. There are so many sushi restaurants, I literally had a hard time to pick a new place to go.. 

I saw they had pretty solid reviews so I was pretty surprised when I got there, the place was empty! I walked by Ebisu and it was so crowded. I wasn't up for the waiting.  

They have a lot of special rolls and they all looked equally yummy. It took a long time to pick them out. We got Crunchy and Double Double. I'm a huge fan of salmon, so very please with Double Double. We also got some nigiris. The cut is very generous and they have a really good quality of fish. The salon so buttery soft and just melted in my mouth. Hmm...I still could feel it. Okay, I think fish taste in someone's mouth isn't very attractive, but I don't care! They're so good! 

The service was excellent. They're fast and friendly (maybe because it's empty?) and the price was about right, especially for their quality. I will definitely go back to try all their special rolls!
author: Perry S.

description:
Atmosphere: Definitely not what I expected from a 4-star reviewed Japanese restaurant on Yelp. I generally enjoy the small Japanese restaurants with a good feel to it, but this place did not have that.

Service: Service was okay. They were quite prompt on bringing our menu and taking our order. During the meal, there was no service, couldn't even get them to refill our water until after a couple waves. Possible that the people at the sushi bar were VIPs so they had to converse with them first.

Food: Definitely will not be the spot to hit up when I'm in the neighborhood. We weren't too hungry so the two of us just ordered two rolls and the agedashi tofu.
The rolls, Double Double and Yamakake, so dinky. But that didn't really bother me. What really bothered me was the lack of any of the listed ingredients. Just stuffed with the cheap stuff. Irked. Maybe I should have went the nigiri path.
Agedashi, not the best. Too much ginger for sure.

Overall: Probably not coming here again unless it happens without my knowing.
author: Jimmy N.

description:
A small cozy very-like Japanese rest. 
I saw some bad review about slow service...yes...there was only ONE waitress to serve 7 tables. When it is busy, she is everywhere and we did have to wait a little bit for each order. 
However the food was VERY reasonable for the nice quality. My bf and I were very happy with the food, we FOR SURE will be back soon! 
Reservation is recommended~!!!
author: Sisi W.

description: Interesting sushi combos and fresh fish. Decent atmosphere.
author: Aeon G.

description:
Sushi Kazu is a great pick if you're looking for a nice neighborhoody sushi place.  It's clean, the waitstaff is attentive and friendly, and I just love, love, LOVE that they provide you with hot hand towels to wipe your hands with before you begin your meal.

My roommate and I walked down the street to Sushi Kazu at around 8pm on a weeknight and were promptly seated right next to the window.  The hamachi was fresh and I remember it being reasonably priced.  I've been meaning to go back here for some time now.
author: Katie C.

description: I love this place!  It has a chill and relaxed atmosphere, and the sushi is excellent.
author: Lisa D.

description:
The freshest fish in the city! I've been looking for a local sushi place that was more about the fish than the decor and image of the customers and I found it in Kazu Sushi.

Beautiful sashmi, prepared with care and precision that I haven't seen since Japan. Great selection and attention to freshness was impecable. Small, family run shop that takes care of the customers all through the meal.

My only wish is that this place was closer to my house!
author: Abra A.

description:
Small, intimate, minimalist in decor, and elegant is what I would say about this place.  It has seats for about 26 people max and that is perfect for this neighborhood joint.  

Service was great, the girl came out and took our orders right away, and was helpful and very patient as we navigated our way through the menu and specials.  In fact because the special board was so far from our table she went and brought it to us to read.  She also recommended when asked, her favorites which we promptly ordered.

All the nigiri we had was delish and super fresh.  Beware though- lots of wasabi in between the fish and rice.  We ordered two rolls, the crunchy spicy tuna roll and a the whitefish roll ( i think) and both were delicious, though Leon R and I both agreed that the crunchy spicy tuna roll was our favorite.  In addition we had the mochi ice cream balls which were the perfect way to end our evening.  

Would definitely be back if I lived in the neighborhood, will be back even though I don't live nearby.  It's a cute little warm and inviting place.
author: Denise B.

description:
Overall this place is good.  The fish is fresh and they have some varieties I had never heard of before.  One of the sushi chefs admitted he hadn't heard of some of them either before working here.  Points for originality.  I thought the service was a bit spotty (which I've come to expect at sushi bars nowadays) but this time, the bar didn't totally save the experience.  An amiable sushi chef staff can make slow/slightly incompetent  service or other minor inconveniences seem like just that, minor.  These guys weren't terribly kind and seemed rather irritated that we were there (taking up their precious "regulars" seating).  There are only about 6 spots at the bar and they're usually reserved for regulars.  This was even the case when I went not long after they opened.

Points for this place because the fish is fresh and unique

It's close to my apartment

It's another more desirable neighborhood sushi place than Ebisu
author: M M.

description: This is my favorite sushi place in SF.  I have tried several others in the area, on the recommendation of others only to be disappointed.  The fish is very high quality and very fresh at Kazu which is what I am looking for in a sushi place.  They don't cater to the pop sushi of colorful rolls made with fake crab and over-powering sauces.  I have never been disappointed.
author: D M.

description:
i can't say anything was amazing, and i can't say anything was bad. except we both walked out of there thinking we paid way too much for what we got.

perhaps we ordered wrong? the fish quality is definitely high, and i enjoyed that, though the uni wasn't amazing.
author: Ameer N.

description:
We just came back from Sushi Kazu.  
We had Ankimo & Agedashi Nasu for appetizer and they were both delicious!  Thier nigiri sushi was so fresh and so good!!!  The items we liked the most were Uni & today's special bluefin tuna ootoro.  They both melted in our mouth.  We also recommend their Yamakake roll.  Everything was so fresh and tasty!
author: Spoon K.

description:
After discovering Koo, my friend and I went on a Sunset search of other FAAAABULOUS sushi joints! We headed over to Sushi Kazu by recommendation and proceeded to order everything on the menu. 

Akimono 
Sashimi dinner
Spider roll
Sweet Shrimp + head
and two more sushi rolls

Everything was good. Definitely not great. It turned out... we were more excited about $6 L sakes and $6 L Sapporros! 

I think I'll stick to Koo. But i might be tempted to go back for cheap hot sake on a typical foggy Sunset night.
author: Angelinaaah h.

description:
I imagine it must be hard to live up to Chika, its predecessor that generated a group of faithful followers in the Inner Sunset suhi circle.

The night I went, the sushi was very fresh, though the wait was beyond reasonable.  The place is very small, and very clean.  Kazu seems very good at making his various sushi items.  Uni and Aji were both excellent.  But the wait...  Yes, there were quite a few customers that night.  But with 2 sushi chefs and 1 waitress, I don't suppose I should have waited 30 minutes for 2 pieces of sushi.

I will visit again if I happen to be in the neighborhood.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Wow, this is the worst experience I've had at a Japanese restaurant, and the Japanese are known for great service so that's sad. I came in with my husband for a romantic dinner. But from the very start, things were not enjoyable. 

When we walked in and stood with three other people in the crowded doorway, nobody greeted us, much less seated us, for at least ten minutes. It got  to the point where I thought we should just seat ourselves at one of the empty tables, except there was that one party ahead of us. I then whispered to my husband, if no one even greeted us in another ten minutes, we should leave. Finally, the one and only waitress there seats us. 

We took our time looking at the menu because it seemed the waitress would take a long while before getting back to us. (The table next to us were ready to leave but were getting annoyed about not receiving their check after a long wait.) A look at the menu shows a very appetizing selection of rolls and nigiri. I ordered the spicy veggie tempura roll, and my husband the beef roll and saba shioyaki. 

While we're waiting for our food, we notice a couple of things that don't make sense. First, the dining area which was already crammed, was further shrunk by the huge shoji screen they placed at the front side of the bar. I realize they probably want to make a "behind-the-scenes" area for the sushi chef but it makes one feel a little claustrophobic. Second, AFTER we ordered our food, we then saw the "Specials" whiteboard which was sitting on a chair, facing only one of the tables. We later learned that they rotated the placement of this whiteboard as parties were seated and looking at the menu. But they didn't bother to show the specials to us, or maybe the smarter thing to do would be to just hang up the whiteboard so everyone can see! Hmm...what an idea. Lastly, it was freezing cold and they didn't have central air so they placed parabolic space heaters on the floor. It was a nice courtesy for the heat but it got in the way of getting to my seat and walking to the bathroom. One of the heaters was also placed so close to a tablecloth we thought it could be a fire hazard. 

When our food finally came twenty minutes later, which I think is considered fast for this place, we did a double take at the portion size. We had ordered two rolls but got only one plate with eight pieces on it. I seriously thought another plate was coming but to our disappointment, each roll was only four pieces! I mean, four-piece maki at those prices?! They tasted good, not amazing, but they were so NOT worth it. If you want vegetarian sushi at a more reasonable value, try Cha-ya. We've never been disappointed there. Also, my husband's saba shioyaki was ridden with bones. Not four or five, but almost wrapped in bones was how he described it.

I think this place tries to be authentic and high quality but the execution of a fine dining experience just isn't there. Definitely not returning.
author: Nancy W.

description:
I have three sushi places; one in the City, one on the Peninsula, and one in the South Bay.  In the City, it is Kazu Sushi.

The fish here is F-R-E-S-H FRESH FRESH FRESH!  If I'm going to try something I've never tried before, this is the place I'm going to do it.  Kazu never steers me wrong.  He's usually behind the sushi bar, and he's always willing to answer a question or offer a suggestion.

Take advantage of the special board.  It's got a lot more than most restaurants, because Kazu knows his fish and loves sharing with his guests.  I once got the most sublime piece of Pacific Trout belly at his recommendation.  

Non-sushi standouts include the "Albacore Carpaccio", an appetizer of albacore sauced to perfection, and the here-and-gone-and-back-again aji fry.

A long time ago I had a really slow service.  It's only really happend once.  I've also had a few misunderstandings when calling in a take-out order, but they always make it right before I leave.

The price is middle of the road - it's not as expensive as Osaka, it's about the same as Ebisu, but it is so much better than both of them.

Really, go for the raw, fresh fish.  A standard trip for me is the albacore carpaccio and whatever my budget will stomach off of the specials board.

Great.  Now I want sushi.  It's all your fault.
author: Mad S.

description: I came here with the boyfriend on a Saturday night at 8 and immediately got seated. We ordered two special rolls, the double double and yamakake and two nigiris, the hamachi and chu toro. Both of the special rolls were pretty good, but the nigiris were excelllent! The waitress told us that they were out of the chu toro so we got the toro instead. The fish tasted very fresh. The dishes do take some time to come out but that was alright with us. This was more on the pricey side for us, but we'll probably make a few more visits to this place!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Delicious! The boyfriend and I came for dinner last saturday night.  We showed up at 7, and were immediately seated.  I love that the menu is pretty much only sushi - no bento boxes or other distractions.  Quite a few appetizers that sounded good, including agedashi nasu (eggplant), but we settled on the hamachi kama and an assortment of nigiri and rolls.  The spicy salmon came out first, and pretty quickly...but then it felt like maybe another 20 or 30 minutes before any other food came out, and even then the rest of order slowly trickled out.  For us, this was forgiveable, as we were sharing everything that was ordered, plus there was a big group (10 people) who were seated right before us so we had counted on some wait time.  But for diners who like to order their own dishes and not share (shame on you, sushi is more delicious when shared!), this could have been a problem.  

The sushi was all so fresh and made perfectly! For nigiri we ordered the maguro, kanpachi, hirame, and hamachi. we wanted the tai, but they were out.  The kanpachi really stood out, so fresh!  The spicy salmon roll was fine, but the spider roll and the king kong roll were soooo good.  The soft shell crab was fried light and crispy, just like it should be.  Oooh and both of these rolls had pickled gobo (burdock root), a personal fave. The hamachi kama was served with a bit of daikon and a ponzu-soy tasting sauce for dipping. delicious.  ooh, and only $70 to fill us up on sushi and asahi.

We were so pleased with the food, especially the quality and freshness.  I would give 5 stars for food, plus 1 star for how nice the waitresses were, but minus 2 stars for slow service and ambiance.....4 stars total.  can't wait to go back.
author: marissa a.

description:
One of the The best/freshest sushi in all of SF...
Great small-sized restaurant.
Best California Rolls Ever!!( w/fresh Snow crab and avo)-no cucumber needed in this one.
Vegetable Dragon Roll--Awesome, 
Double-double-w chili threads...
Fat-Tuesday,
Cucumber, Spicy Tuna,,Maguro,TORO
Great house specialties.
Prices are reasonable. My girl and I eat for under 35 bucks.  We don't drink...we sure get stuffed though.
Must check it out!!
open 5pm-
closed Sundays...
author: Rick H.

description:
Kazu has great decor and friendly waitstaff, but the sushi was rather bland. 
I went on a Wednesday night and the service was slow and they got our order wrong. The sushi is presented very well, but that did not make up for the lack of taste. Personally, I would rather go to a hole in the wall restaurant that had better tasting food.
author: Naomi H.

description:
i live nearby and this is, hands down, my favorite sushi joint in the neighborhood.  what makes this place insanely great:  the fish is always fresh, the restaurant is small and unpretentious and most importantly, kazu's attention to detail and expert preparation that goes into everything on the menu.

the best seat in the house is at the bar; you get a chance to see kazu at work and he really makes the art of sushi appear effortless and fun.

in all honesty, the waitress can be a little unresponsive at times, but i don't come back for the service, it's all about the food in my opinion.  the quality of the sushi more than makes up for this.

my recommendation: get one of the sushi or sushi/sashimi combos and order more sushi a la carte afterwards.
author: Alex L.

description: They don't do beef teriyaki here. Actually, they don't do very many cooked items at all. I don't care but my beef teryaki loving friend did and we had to eat elsewhere. I will only come with other sushi loving friends in the future. Haha...
author: Queenie C.

description: Came here Friday night with a friend. I made reservations and the table was ready when we arrived. She ordered the sake nigiri, monkfish nigiri, and poke. I ordered the rainbow roll and sashimi salad. I ordered another roll, but it never arrived, (that's OK.) won't stop me from coming back. Nigori sake was our choice for alcohol. Kazu doesn't disappoint, but I was more concerned about my friend's impression about my choice of a sushi restaurant. Apparently, she seemed satisfied! (dodged a bullet...whew!)...Kazu, where's the chirashi?
author: Dan P.

description: The food was delicious and the fish was fresh. I recommend the King Kong Roll, Hawaiian Roll, and the Hamachi and Salmon nigiri.  The customer service could have been a lot better and friendlier, so I bumped off a star.
author: H. A.

description:
This place has really great sushi, and for pretty good prices. I love the crunchy california and the spicy veggie tempura rolls!

The only downside is that they can be kind of slow on service, although they're always very nice. It's never so crowded that you need to wait more than 5 minutes to sit down - which is a huge plus in the neighborhood!
author: Ny M.

description: My friend brought me here for the last dinner at this neighborhood half month ago. Pretty good service, A-OK food, but very neat place and price. So, nothing could complain about.
author: Flora F.

description:
My girlfriend and I went to Kazu sushi last night. Overall, it was a good meal. We gave it a 4 out of 5 stars because although it wasn't perfect (the service was a little slow), it was better than a 3 out of 5 because the food was really good. 

We had the three specialty rolls the King Kong Roll, Spice Veggie Tempura Roll, and the Double Double (DD). The King Kong and the Spicy Veggie were 4 pieces each while the DD was 8. All of them were really good, but the Double Double was by far the best, although it did take a while to make. They apologized and gave us edamame on the house before it even felt like too much of a wait though and I thought that was a nice touch. 

What's more, even w/ a large Sake and a California Roll to go, the bill was low. We'll definitely go again.  I would highly recommend going to Kazu Sushi!
author: Paul E.

description:
I love Sushi Kazu! My boyfriend and I have been going to Kazu before it opened, back when it was Chika. I think Kazu is waaaay better. I enjoy the small, unassuming dining room. While the service isn't as zippy as some may be used to, you get a sense that you're in someone's home. It's run by a husband and wife with 2 helpers. Their young daughter often graces the dining room with her presence. 

Now on to the food...

I'm a vegetarian and do not eat fish. Sushi Kazu has a wonderful vegetarian combination dinner with lots of interesting creations . It is beyond satisfying for a vegetarian and you will not go hungry. 

I highly recommend a night out at Sushi Kazu. Be prepared for a nice, long evening. It's a great date place (ladies bring a sweater, it gets chilly in here during the winter). 

Enjoy!
author: Louis C.

description:
We have been back to this cozy, neighborhood Inner Sunset sushi joint a few times.  Love the vibe, the service, fish is great across the board.  Fun date spot...

Hamachi Kama, Softshell Crab appetizer, and still eating the White Snake Roll.  The sashimi we had this weekend was so top notch maguro, hamachi, and sake.  

The better sakes can be pricey but we got nice pours.  The servers are super on top of it and accommodating...  A winner!
author: Lo F.

description:
They're actually one of the legitimate Japanese restaurants in the city. It's actually owned by Japanese people, friends of my in-laws. Their food was excellent. HOWEVER, they made us wait 1 hour before the first dish arrived. We were a party of 5, and one person did not even get served until 2 hours after we got seated. I guess this wouldn't be a problem if we were just ordering tapa dishes to compliment our alcoholic beverages. But that was not the case.  We were there for dinner. Definitely not acceptable. 

We went back there with my in-laws few months later. Totally different attitude just because they knew the owners. We got served with priority even though I saw other tables waiting patiently for 45minutes until they got their sushi roll. 

I'd say the food was still great. I'd go there if you have all the time in the world and a great deal of patience.
author: Laura O.

description: Food was bomb!! The service was a little slow, do to the fact that they only had two chefs and two waitress. Try the "ZIGZAG" its off the chain!
author: Heng S.

description: Tonight I dined alone at this sushi bar was pleased with everything. This is a very "Japanese" sushi bar with a large vegetarian menu. I only had some albacore tuna sushi and a new york roll and a beer. Cost me $16+tip. All very fresh. I will return, hopefully with a vegan goddess who has never had veggie sushi.
author: Spoke K.

description:
did i ever mention im a sushi snob? sure im not as versed as the likes of nobu and toro, but hey i can hold my own with my sashimi knowledge. 

this place is good. i didnt have the chance to really eat much, they had harushika blue, oooo i rikey, but from what was presented, hmmmm pretty damn good. got to try some stuff from both the sushi chefs. nice. 

i REALLY liked the tai the older man ( i assume kazu san) prepared. wow. its odd for me to say this cause, well, see koreans like their hae (sashimi) prepared very simply. take a fresh (live) fish. chopped slice and dice it up, and eat with either soy sauce or spicy diping sauce. they prefer white meat fish. 

i asked for the tai. looked good in the case. the assistant handed off to kazu san. i thought, hmm weird.....

wow. it was presented with some others stuff, looked like granted radish with some spice to it, chopped green onions and daikon sprouts and some sort of sauce on the tai. i tried the tai alone..mmm good. next, i tried with a a little bit of everything. WOW good. 

i can easily recommend this place. 

on a side note, how the hell does a girl barely a couple months in sf, junie, get to be a known person at places? we walked in, she seemed to know everyone there?

must be the doctor and kevs doing.

holy crap that grilled smelt that lady terri posted up looks damn good!!!
author: Euge L.

description:
I thought this place would be great based on the reviews. While the food is decent, many aspects of this restaurant are not...

DISORGANIZED: This is a small place, but the staff is so disorganized. We got our appetizer and a side of rice LAST. Also, they serve your items one at a time in whatever order they feel like. We got our sushi 15 minutes apart, then got the miso soup, then more sushi, then our appretizer, then after we had finished... the side of rice... 

OVERPRICED: $11 for a weak 4 piece roll

Very disappointed.
author: J P.

description:
Best veggie rolls in . . . the WORLD!

(One full page of their menu is dedicated to veggie sushi options.)

Also, one of the besk-kept secrets in San Francisco.

Beautiful presentation, freshest & best-quality ingredients, innovative creations. (Yummy saki :-)!)

If you're here for the fish, you must at least also try the veggie crunch roll. If you love eggplant, I also recommend the veggie dragon. Head sushi chef is an artist. Our last server was graceful & sweet--new server is a chipper pixie dynamo. Love love love Kazu.
author: J Z.

description:
Kazu has recently filled the substantial void in the neighborhood left by Chika.  Just had dinner here tonight, and it was quite good.  The chef has some skills!   Everything here was good, though the prices were a little high.  For instance, if a hamachi-kama (yellowtail jaw) is around $10, I expect to get the WHOLE jaw, not just 1 half.  However, the jaw was perfectly grilled/roasted shioyaki.  The gindara was excellent, black cod perfectly marinated with miso, however the serving size was not as large as Koo's, although the quality was comparable (I like koo's presentation better with the greens and "soupy" base).  The nanbanzuke was quite interesting--never had anything quite like it.  It was a fried fish (can't remember the name in english...I remember it was a spanish name starting with a vowel like E) that was marinated after it was fried, so is served cold in a slightly sour ponzu-like sauce, served with green onions and cilantro.
My favorite dish he made, however, was the hotate ayaburi (I think that was the name) tataki, served as nigiri sushi.  It was a seared scallop (hotate) with some scallions and ginger on top--the flavor balance was impeccable, as well as texturing and everything.  Quite awesome.  I would order LOTS more of this sushi.   Unfortunately, they were out of my favorite uni.  As raw fish goes, their king salmon was excellent (no tendons, well portioned, excellent cut), their amaebi was good--and the head was quite good, since they removed the main outer shell for you, making it a lot easier to eat.  Next time I will ask for it in a miso soup, and see if he'll prepare it that way for me ;).

While I didn't order it, they did have a chirashi sushi here.  $22.  Not a bad price.  I'll have to get it next time, since my friend asked to have more maguro and sake than I personally need--I want to see what goodies it comes with.  The tamago, however, did not have the nicely carmellized layers like Kitsho did.  From what I saw, though, the fish all looked good.

I will definitely be back to try some of the remaining items, which look interesting.  Definitely good food here.  The sake menu looks to be remnant of one of the old Chika sake menus, so the selection is not bad--though they lack a lot of the high end stuff chika had, like the kubota.  They still have some nice daiginjos and ginjos however--be sure to ask for the sake menu.

The chef, Miyauchi-san, is from ten-ichi in the fillmore.  Never been there, but he was head chef there for 12 years.  Very nice guy.  Miyauchi-san suggested next time I get the crunchy shrimp.
author: Fong L.

description: I wavering between 3.5 and 4 stars for this one purely on perceived value of the meal.  Don't get me wrong, the food here is good, but it's a bit pricey considering the location (few blocks from 9th and Irving) and the decor (pretty bland).  The miso soup with clams we had was pretty good, very good looking clams and tasty broth.  All the sushi rolls we ordered were very fresh with the texture of the rice being just right.
author: Ming L.

description: Order sashimi  dinner and the fish is amazingly fresh.  The roll is also above average.  Not many people for the weekday night but spend quite a long time to find parking
author: Becky C.

description:
BE CAUTIOUS WHEN DINING HERE!*

A friend and I had decided to go try this place out on a Wednesday evening and while I didn't really care at the time, we were pretty much the only customers when we first entered.

We ordered four items, Toro sushi, Saba sashimi(always a must for me), some type of hawaiian roll and a dragon roll. The sashimi was fresh.  I was even told by the waitress that the toro was from Costa Rica.

*The BAD:
We had noticed that Masago was deceptively substituted for Tobiko on our sushi rolls.  For those who don't know, Masago roe is much smaller and cheaper  vs. Tobiko roe(by 4-5 times cost difference).  We asked the waitress to confirm and she first stated it was Tobiko and quietly stood at the edge of our table confused.  She then went to the back to get the real answer and did confirm it was Masago and that they were totally out of Tobiko.  That was pretty lame, because I did notice Tobiko on our neighbor's table.   I also experienced the "destructable roll" as I was picking up pieces.  The restaurant might be Japanese operated but this act is just plain insulting to customers and a disgrace towards other Japanese restaurants.. makes Kazu cheap and sleazy.  To top it off, I almost ate a piece of leftover saran wrap from a piece of the dragon roll (I thought it was eel skin until I looked at it closely) -I guess the rolls are not fresh..   

Service was a bit slow like some of the other horror stories some people have experienced in their reviews..I think it pretty much depends on how hungry you are and what mood you're in.
author: Josh G.

description: the Sushi combo was okay over all, but the fish that I like was very good.  They took great care of me with free edamame because they thought I was waiting too long.  I hadn't been waiting too long.  Good fish and good people, what's not to like?
author: milos d.

description: Great sake. Good rolls (better at Nagano though). Smelt could've been better. Service was super duper. OH! I actually had chicken here and it was amazing....I never eat chicken when I can eat sushi, but no regrets here....anyway, I'm sticking to Nagano, but this place was nice.
author: Aristocles P.

description:
Kazu is one of those holes in the wall restaurant that you won't notice it passing by unless you intentionally go out to look for it, but once you found it, boy, you are so glad you did. 

My friend took me to this mom and pop Japanese own and run restaurant in the Sunset area for dinner. The place is very small and fits a sushi bar and about 8 tables. When we got there, we didn't have any reservation so we had to wait for about 15 minutes to get our table. While we waited, we studied the menu and discussed our game plan to strategy what we should try that evening. 

Although the place is small, it offers a pretty remarkable variety of sushi with top quality fishes. In addition to the regular menu, the restaurant also offers specials of the day with fish and seafood they can get their hands on. Our server brings us a white board with hand written specials, unfortunately we didn't recognize some of the Japanese names of fishes and seafood. But we quickly overcame this problem with the help of our nice server describing to us the texture and taste of the fishes. We ordered 3 different kinds of fish nigiris and tried 2 kinds of clams nigiris featured on the board - one has a soft texture and not briny at all, and the second one a little more chewy and has a stronger taste of the ocean. Both were very different and very tasty. We also ordered amaebi nigiri and when the deep fried shrimps heads arrived, we both looked at each other and laughed as we confessed that the real reason for ordering amaebi was for the crispy, salty, deep fried shrimp heads. Is like eating shrimps chips. Don't deny it, you know you do the same too. 

We split an order of mixed sashimi salad with salmon, tuna and yellow tail cut into cubes and served with a bed of mixed greens and seaweeds drizzled with Japanese sesame seed dressing. We loved the salad because it is healthy, very tasty and satisfying. We talked about copying the recipe to make it at home, but we were too afraid to handle raw fish in at home fearing of food poisoning if we didn't do it right. 

I just love small, intimate restaurant own and run by the owner and family that serve wonderful dishes. Kazu not only offers great sushis, but also a comfortable feeling as if we were having dinner at home.
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
Small yet intimate sushi setting, with daily specials.  I found a wide selection of sushi and non-sushi dishes.

Service was a little slow, but my brother and I enjoyed our time at the bar meeting a Japanese/Russian couple and getting dibs on the best dishes for the evening.

Reservations are a must, and the place doesn't break the bank for the quality of food presented.
author: That's For N.

description:
it's okay to have expensive food. but after $90 and I'm still not full, is not okay...

I came here after class at dinnertime, and boy is this place the wrong place to go when you're starved..

I like how there were different kinds of rolls and diff types of nigiri, but I was looking for something fast and filling, and it wasn't either.  

Plus side,  good service! very Japanese etiquette
author: kim w.

description: I love living in a neighborhood where you can walk into a decent restaurant without any reservations for good solid food.  Kazu Sushi was only half-full on a Wednesday night.  Service was attentive and the sushi was of generous proportions and fresh-tasting, the rolls flavorful.  We tried seaweed soup which was mild but pleasant, not as salty and overwhelming as some miso soups.  The tuna poke was good but could have used more seasoning as it was a tad bland.  For dessert, mango mochi ice-cream was perfect!  My friend and I were full and satisfied for ~$45 total, no drinks.
author: KC S.

description: Decent food, but over-priced. The service was also okay. It's a relatively small place with very limited seatings. For the quality of food I don't think the price is fair, but once again Kazu Sushi sits on Irving and 9th Ave, a prime spot, so we have to pay partially for their rent.
author: Namio S.

description: I just called this place and politely informed the manager that there are numerous complaints about slow service because they have only one server waitress, he laughed at me and said bye.  Make your own judgement call.  would i go to a place that just a few minutes ago laughed off my serious concern? What a jerk.
author: david t.

description:
