While I am rarely religious, I decided to do the Lenten thing this year, and Thank God I did.  If I had not, I would never have gone to Kazu Sushi.

I had heard about this place months ago from a Japanese (honto no nihonjin), but just never gotten there until I need to skip the meat for a day.  

I ordered Hotate, Spicy Tuna Roll, Ikura, and Uni.

Let's just say I thought it was great, and I have been back 4 times since.
author: Daniel M.

description:
ohh! it's soo good! at first we were going to go to Koo, which i know and love. but we decided to try something new, so we went to Sushi Kazu. I remember Chika (the former restaurant at this location) from when I would go there with my dad after school when I was 6 years old. I would always order salmon teriyaki, and the ikura they put on top was my introduction to sushi, as I began to order ikura sushi. anyway, so many years later here i am at sushi kazu.. wow. it was really yummy. we ordered the oysters (3 gigantic oysters for $8). the oysters came with ponzu sauce, tobiko, and green onions on top. total taste of the sea. explosion of ocean water in the mouth. SLURP!!!!!!!!

then, we got the tuna carpaccio.. wow just scarf up those 6 slices of tuna drizzled in more ponzu and tobiko. MMM. i love these flavors so much.

i also had uni.. it was great with a wonderful texture. the spicy hotate (scallop) roll i had was great too, a nice hot, but not overpowering, flavor! i tried the sake (salmon) too, which had the perfect hint of sweetness that salmon should have. and of course i had tobiko.. MMM... wow. crunch crunch splizzit (flying fish juice squirting in mouth) crunch. i love the feel of tobiko exploding between your teeth, don't you?

for dessert i had mango mochi ($1.50). Yummy. sliced in half too, how cute!! I would definitely go here again. yes they only have one server (a japanese woman.. she was very cute. for instance i asked what a hotate kiyokyu (i spelled that wrong) was, and she couldn't explain it, so she drew a scallop on the back of her server pad and highlighted which part of the scallop was included in that dish. my tea was constantly being refilled. service was a little slow, but it's understandable. go here, relax, and enjoy. authentic japanese cuisine.
author: O K.

description:
This is my first review.  It's actually really late because I went to Kazu Sushi in November last year, but better late than never... right?

It was my birthday and my boyfriend took me to Kazu Sushi because I'd been talking about wanting sushi.  We're both Japanese so we have pretty high standards for sushi.

We were both happy with the quality of the food.  Apparently it's usually far more crowded but we were lucky.  It wasn't ridiculously cramped (which is good because I'm not good with too much noise and the idea of inhaling everyone else's air makes me somewhat ill).  It also gave us more time to talk to Kazu, who is the owner and is also behind the sushi counter.

He's a nice guy (possibly somewhat shy at first).  There were a few regulars there that night who said it was their third time there that week.  Dedicated indeed.

We'll definitely be back, too.
author: F. H.

description: Three words: white tuna tataki. You're welcome.
author: Nora G.

description:
It's sushi at it's best!! If you want the freshest sushi in the bay, this is the place to try! I've been there multiple times now and I've been satisfied every single time. Since I have been there often, these are the things i recommend new people that want to try Sushi Kazu out go/do.

1) Ask for the specials of the day. It's usually on a white board near the entrance on the right. Kazu-san gets many types of fish that other sushi places never carry, and they are worth trying. Yum!

2) Try to go on Tuesday, Thursday, or Saturday. I've noticed that those are the off peak days for some reason and an early dinner (6-8pm) is a great time since they seat around  25-30 seats and you don't want to be there when it's packed. Less people = Faster service 

3) All the sushi are to die for but if you would like some appetizers to start with i recommend: "Yakitori" Momo=chicken skewer / Tsukune=chicken meatball skewer (w/salt), better than any yakitori restaurant i've been to in ages. "Ankimo"=Monkfish liver (cooked w/ponzu sauce i believe) Melts away in your mouth before you even know it. 

4) You must, and i say you must try a glass of the "Takenotsuyu"=Nihonshu=Sake. It's something like $9 a glass but boy  is it good!! I usually don't drink but even my buddies that love to drink all agree with me that this Sake is delicious. I tried to look for it everywhere in the Japanese supermarkets and other restaurants but it's no where to be found, so I get one or two of these glasses while i enjoy my food.

I hope my review will help some people out that are looking for a great place to eat "Real" sushi.
author: Andrew S.

description:
After a brief period of mourning for the loss of Chika, which used to occupy this space on Irving between 9th and 10th Avenues, we decided to check out this new sushi place. It is a worthy successor to Chika. 

This is a straight-forward sushi restaurant - they are not into the eccentric fusion sushi and bizarre rolls here.  However, there are some interesting-looking hot dishes that I'll try in the future. Prices are reasonable for what you get.

The fish was of excellent quality - best kohada I've ever had. The shiro maguro was like butter. My companion loved the toro. The portion sizes of the sushi were very large. Presentation of the fish was clean and spare. The sunomono (cucumber salad) presentation was beautiful, and it tasted as good as it looked. Everything we had was wonderful, including 2 dishes that just appeared at our table, compliments of the house. (New restaurant = trying harder to get you to come back.) The first of these was two grilled sardines, with a little piquant sauce of some kind, diced green onion, and shiso (?) strands - very  tasty. The second freebie was delivered to our table by the sushi chef himself, along with 2 shots of a sake he thought would compliment the dish (he was right). I had never had this dish: squid with a sauce made of squid stomach (I *think* that's what he said). It had a very unusual taste to a Western palate. We chatted with the sushi chef, who told us that he is from Tokyo. 

The menu lists several decent sakes - we had a bottle of a junmai gingo, very good and reasonably priced. The waitress is pleasant, but her English is minimal - this would be a good place to practice your Japanese. 

As for the decor, it still looks pretty much like the old Chika, but it's been de-mom-and-popped: the TV is gone, replaced by a music system; the posters and clutter up front are gone, replaced by tasteful art and a screen up front. The overall effect is lighter, more elegant and spare - just like the sushi. This is a good addition to the Inner Sunset community, and I anticipate many repeat visits to Kazu.
author: Debi L.

description: Excellent sushi and interesting hot appetizers with nice presentation.  The tuna, albacore, king mackeral, and house cured salmon sushi (including the high grade rice) were of the highest quality and taste in SF.  The Uni, yum, it was super fresh.  Kazu knows fish.  Kazu sushi has a clean minimalist  feel to it (might  feel a bit too antiseptic) with a modern styled sushi bar for small parties and a small seating area. The music needs more thought.
author: Mitch L.

description: We went here on Valentine's Day and it was one of the worst dining experience ever.  The place was full and there was 1 waitress for the whole place.  The place seats about 25 to 30 people and 1 server is just not sufficient!  She runs around with her head down so you can never get her attention for even tea while we wait 1 hour to get 1 roll and 4 nigiri orders.  What's worse, they missed our 2nd roll after the hour.  We were so upset, we left rather than wait for that roll....  It was written down but they forgot our order.  The table next to us also had their order forgotten.  Unbelievable.  The food was decent but the service was poor, just poor and unacceptable!!!!  If you don't mind a long wait, then sure, go for it.  But I sure wouldn't go ahead....
author: Irene C.

description: Only good things to say: fresh, unusual, artistic food presentation and most of all, very, very tasty!! Not for the ones who are in a hurry and expect tons of food for less money. For that, go to a buffet. Instead, take your time as Kazu likes to infuse his personal touch to all his dishes and make every bite so memorable!
author: Philippe L.

description:
Amazing quality of fish.  BUT, too much wasabi on nigiri.  Big pieces of sushi.  Combo A is 5 typical pieces + miso.  Rolls were OK, spicy scallops rocked, the special, amazing tuna/spicy tuna crunch was  very alright, but not amazing.  I'd definitely go back and eat fresh nigiri.  

-LT
author: Lance T.

description:
if u're looking for real real japanese sushi taste, u can try this one.  
if u're looking for Americanized bulky fast & junk sushi, u may skip this one.
i would like to say most americans they don't know what is sushi, their formula is rice+fresh fish are equal to sushi, then they never know what is real sushi.
anyway, the quality of this shop's sushi is above average and tasted like real japanese sushi, and the shape of the sushi looks professional too.  and they call daily fresh menu.  
u must try the beef tongue and the hamachi toro if they have.
I minus 1 star becoz of the speed, but I don't care as long as it's gd food
please don't share u ate great sushi next time, if you actually don't know the food culture and spirit behind...
author: terrific h.

description: This is only regarding their izakaya offerings as i did not partake in their sushi. Was totally unsatisfied with their food. We ordered the Agedashi Tofu, Chicken Karaage, Goma-Ae, Grilled Nasu and buta kakuni. I can honestly say every single item was lacking in flavor. The taste was off and I was really kicking myself for being so lazy for not making the drive to Oyaji instead. To make matters worst the service was extremely slow albeit there was only one waitress working, although the restaurant only had one other table to wait on at the time. We then had to wait while a party of four came in for a togo order. They came in way after us but some how managed to get their food and left and we were still waiting for our food to arrive.
author: Ericka A.

description: This is the real deal, and fairly priced, too.  Outstanding sushi, top-notch service, and a refined (but not snobby) atmosphere.  Kazu is the name of the owner -- and head sushi chef -- and he knows what he's doing.  Seriously.  This is a restaurant that, after leaving, you feel not only well-fed, but well taken care of, too.
author: Kevin B.

description: Lovely waitress - ready to please with a sweet, delicate, amiable disposition. Quiet (you won't encounter obnoxious drunks or loud talkers here). Freshness is above average, there is a lot of variety--from the nigiri to "western sushi" (california, dragon, rainbow rolls)  but I am still on a mission to find a place that makes amazing ikura. And..I had my revenge on the sea urchin (since I got stung by one while surfing) =P
author: Audrey L.

description: This is a tiny almost hole in the wall on Irving that serves really exceptional sushi and other Japanese cuisine. This place was introduced to me by Justin C. (holla!) and it was damn good. Great sushi that is really fresh and the other non sushi items were delicious. Especially the spinach salad, super tasty dressing. The service is very nice and genuine. Would definitely come back.
author: Cathy T.

description: Kazu Sushi was unfortunetely a let down. I have been dying to go there ever since I moved to the Sunset. And it just did not live up to my expectations. I ordered the Jurassic Roll and the Fat Tuesday roll. And they were simply "ok." They both sounded orgasmic in their descriptions and they ended up being a little less flavorful and less interesting than I thought they would be. The other disappointment was that our waitress was not very attentive. She seemed like she was trying but it just wasn't up to par. She took my boyfriend's order early even though we told her we just wanted appetizers first. And I told her I would order when she came back with the miso soup. She instead ignored that and brought my boyfriend's order while I sat there. Sure, maybe she didn't hear me or simply forgot...but come on! Additionally, she never asked us if we wanted any water to drink or even if we wanted another coke after our first cans were long gone. As a matter of fact, she never stopped by to see if everything was going okay for us at all! To top it off, we had to wait forever for her to bring over the bill. Sorry honey, you were cute...but being cute doesn't get you that far! This restaurant is TINY, so I don't know what she was doing instead of paying attention to her tables. No thanks, Kazu.
author: Katie S.

description: great tasting sushi. very small place. wouldnt bring a large group of friends but its great for you and your special some one. they have one of my favorite dishes (grilled hamachi kama)
author: Wei W.

description: Fresh hamachi, sake, uni nigiri.  That night the service was really slow (sushi chefs too busy flirting with the bar patrons and waitress was spacey).  I heard service is normally not that bad.  Sushi Kazu doesn't have that many tables and it was surprisingly pretty full at 9pm weeknight, though we had no wait.  Seemed to draw mainly a local neighborhood (Inner Sunset) crowd.
author: Chris P.

description:
Nothing frustrates me more than something that is amazing that continually falls short of it's potential.  Even with the frustration i feel with sushi kazu i still had to give them 3 stars cause when they get it right they get it oh so right.  Their cuts of fish, man i have dreams about them, and you have to get the hamachi (wow)

But when it comes to service give me a break.  The repeatedly just drop the ball so hard  it makes me want to cry with frustration.  The last two times i had their food i ordered out.  I should have known after the first time when they told me it would take 40 minutes to prepare my food and when i showed up they realized they had forgot to even start it!  I sat for ANOTHER 40 mins waiting for the food and yes they gave me a free cup of tea and a apology but that didn't help the grumbles.

then the other day i give a call cause i have a lot of hope in humanity.  20 mins they tell me.  So my gf and i head out and arrive 20 mins later at the store and we sit (with tea) for another 20 mins!  Finally belly's grumbling we get home and what happens?  We open our food to find they got three of five of the rolls wrong, ahh the frustration!  

Not sure if i will be going back there cause disappointment just sucks but know if you do get them on a good day the fish is some of the best i've had, so sad on service.
author: Robin R.

description: My favorite sushi restaurant in SF.  The quality of the fish is so good; I always find myself wanting more even after I've eaten a whole sashimi dinner.
author: Melinda C.

description: Very nice.  Great, fresh fish - although the pieces were a tad too large.  (I know, what a lame complaint.)  The hamachi was ridiculously good.  (I had stopped ordering it as for the past couple years each piece I got was meh - a tad chewy and fishy.)  This was sublime - melt in the mouth delicious.  We sat at the bar, and the chef wowed us with his choices.  He even created some off the menu roll for us.  It was great, encompassing all the taste sensations.  Decent sake list.  Sadly, the non-sushi chef service was lackadaisical at best.  But the fish was so good, and the prices very reasonable (2 people, sushi, 1 bottle sake, + 2 glasses sake for $75 incl. tip) that I restore the stars lost by the poor service.  I'll definitely return here.
author: darla s.

description: A+ for imagination... Kazu has some interesting contemporary combos (i.e. sushi con mango) that stays true to its Nippon roots. The sashimi here is pretty good, although I think Ebisu (which unfortunately closed for remodeling) is a bit better.  The place is ultra cozy, I love how they have a little portal heater in the middle of room for additional warmth.  Service is slow though b/c there's usually only one waitress running around for the entire place. She tries her best, so kudos!
author: Mischen C.

description: Sushi Kazu was better than P and I expected.  We just wanted a quiet dinner in my hood and were pleasantly surprised.  They offered really fresh fish and a variety of special rolls.  We started off with the edamame and wakame salad, which were nice hefty portions.  Then we ordered sake, unagi, aji, and hamachi nigiri, which were top notch quality and generous cuts.  Rollwise, we tried the double double roll with salmon and mango, a nice combo but pretty spicy, and the soft shell crab roll, fried properly and not greasy at all.  I wholeheartedly recommend Kazu over Ebisu any day.
author: Pelle Y.

description:
Pretty good sushi place for San Francisco, the quality and freshness of the fish is definitely very high. I had uni, unagi, hamachi, and tekka maki. I also had rice and saba misoyaki. Compared to Koo and Hama-ko, I would say this place seems to be better with regard to quality of Sushi. The saba misoyaki, was a little too asian-fusion like(think upscale french restaurant) in the way it was served (in a deep bowl garnished with thinly shredded green onion and raddish)and was a bit over priced $9. Ie you can get it at Nijiya for about $4 for double the quantity. My meal came to $34 including tip. 

So its I guess what you could consider normal for one person at a sushi restaurant. The reason I don't give 5 stars is that the waitress, who appeared to be the sushi chefs wife was busy writing something down the entire time I was eating and I had to call her over ( to get a tea refill, order more food and get more ginger). So not so good service since I was only one of two parties at the restaurant. Overall, if you're looking for authentic sushi/Japanese food go here if your near 9th ave, go to Koo if you're near 3rd and want a choice of rolls, or go to Hama-ko if you're near Carl.
author: Porkers T.

description: I thought the sushi was very mediocre...The wild salmon nigiri and hamachi did not taste super fresh.  The rolls were pretty good - but nothing to write home about.  The service was perfectly fine - the staff was polite and quick.  We did go relatively early on a Thursday night.
author: Eric C.

description: Best sushi in San Francisco.  Chef Kazu is a true master of his art.
author: Alex M.

description:
LOVED this place.  My husband and I went on a Friday, early evening (by/before 6pm) so there were plenty of tables and we didn't have too wait long for our food. Sounds like it's a different story later in the evening.

 The salmon sashimi was buttery goodness that melted on our tongues.  The rolls are fabulous as well...we ordered pretty basic stuff (i.e., catepillar roll, rock n roll) and another I can't remember the name of but it includes egg, cucumber, eel and avocado. My mouth is watering just thinking about their food. We wanted to order more but too full.

I really hope this place continues to succeed and I can't wait to go back and try all the other fabulous sounding items on their menu.
Oh and waiter and sushi chef were very polite and warm. All around great restaurant.
author: rosie t.

description:
Oh my. I have found another keeper on my very short list of sushi places. It came as a nice surprise. We came here a Thursday night before hitting the California Academy of Science shinding. Ordered the Toro (the special-of-the-day menu), tuna sashimi, crunchy roll, and agedashi tofu (*yikes* it might top *T* in FC... Kazu version - small cubes of firm, golden brown crispy tofu wading in hot tentsuyu broth topped with sweet daikon, green onions and... ginger). The Toro, marvelous, melt in your mouth, buttery and couldn't get enough of it. I'm not a Mac-fancy-roll-kinda girl, but I had a bite of that Crunchy Roll. Tasty, fresh, loaded with multi-layers of flavors. Would I order it again, not for me. I am a purist, so I am self-admitting that I am not the best sushi-roll reviewer. Sorry. Sashimi, completely different story. 

It's been a while...  a long while since I've been impressed with a sushi restaurant. Kazu has restored my faith that there are still good sushi restaurants out there to be found.
author: Carmen S.

description:
This is my favorite sushi restaurant in the city.  Kazu only buys the freshest, sweetest fish.  If he can't get the exact kind he wants, he just won't have it in stock.

All his apps are homemade - he makes his own ramen soup, gyoza, etc.  And the specials board has some unique and always wonderful fresh fish, apps and interesting rolls.

One tip, this is a small, family run business, so expect to have a leisurely meal.
author: Karen D.

description: I love love love this place!  It's cute and small with a warm and friendly atmosphere.  The wait staff is very pleasant and the food is delicious.  They have the best sushi and green tea in the city!  Reasonably priced and never a long wait.  Much better than Ebisu.
author: Brig M.

description: After reading the reviews, I decided to make reservations at Kazu for my first date with a new guy. I expected the place to be packed on a Friday night, but it wasn't, and they didn't even ask if I had a reservation before seating me. The service was fast, but the waitress did not show us the whiteboard containing the specials until we had already decided what we wanted from the menu and were ready to order (we took quite a while making this decision, too; there was plenty of opportunity for her to show us the specials earlier). I ordered a rainbow roll with no cucumber and he ordered a crunchy, spicy tuna roll. When the food came, the rolls were small, the avocado was brown and the fish portions were scant. This was disappointing, because so many other yelpers seemingly had a more positive experience. Nonetheless, I will not be back to Kazu. If I wanted cheaply-made sushi, I would go to Kiki and pay accordingly; Kazu over-charges and under-delivers.
author: Erin O.

description: I've never been one to choose to eat sushi but since eating here I have since requested to go again.  All I know is that I liked everything I tried and some more seasoned sushi lovers I went with appreciated it was well.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Kazu is a great place to sit down and have a chat with your friend.  The location is quite small and doesn't really have much space, so it's not good to bring more than maybe 2-4 people there.

The servers are nice, but slow.  If you don't like slow service, this is not the place for you.  The food is reasonablly priced for the quality and the menu is unique to the restaurant.  If you like fish, definitely try their kampachi kama appetizer...very yummy and delicious.

Kazu does not necessarily carry the highest quality sashimi or give the option to buy, but the fish is fresh.   Definitely will return for small treats and dinners with friends.
author: Hu J.

description: Kazu is one of my favorite Japanese restaurants. Fresh fish and delicious izakaya dishes.  The sake selection is always good. And it's fun to drink with Kazu! Cozy place to go with the family or friends or even by yourself.
author: Patty S.

description: This place is delicious. The fish is fresh and the ultimate crunchy is to die for.
author: Cyrus S.

description: The fish is very fresh, and the rolls are creative. The crunchy tuna, in particular, is spectacular! The service can be a bit spotty, depending on the night, but overall it is a great restaurant. Yum!
author: L T.

description: small portions, chewy fish, high prices
author: Kate B.

description: best sushi ive ever had! amazingly plated not to mention ALL THE DAM FLAVOR they pack into a a roll!!!
author: Zachary B.

description: this place is definitely one of the best sushi restaurants in the inner sunset. the wait staff are really attentive and it is reasonably priced. the crunchy roll is yummy and the fish is fresh!
author: Katie W.

description:
I wanted SO badly to write a nice review about this place. It's right in the neighborhood, and my wife and I knew it was on the slightly more expensive end of the spectrum. So we picked a special night and decided to give it a shot.

From the good to the not-so-good:
1) VERY fresh fish. The uni was as fresh as any my wife has ever had. The ikura was equally fresh, but we were surprised by how small they were. The maki rolls were very good as well, but a little on the small side; we ordered the rainbow roll (see #4 below) and another roll whose name escapes me: it's the roll that is the second one pictured by "Daniel K" in the photo gallery, the one with shrimp tempura on the inside. The toro nigiri almost seemed like it had been pre-frozen...there was something not quite right about its texture. I'm used to it practically melting in my mouth (when it's very good). Not so with our order.
2) Overall, relatively high prices for relatively small portions...but we knew about the high prices going in.
3) INCREDIBLY slow service, though this may be due to the fact that we were there on a Saturday evening in a packed little space. Both waitresses are very pleasant, but the guys behind the sushi bar could pick up the pace a little bit. I've never been to a sushi place in the city where there is so much time between served items. Ikura nigiri and toro nigiri arrive (this is really not much food, mind you). Twenty minutes later (no joke), a single maki roll arrives. Consumed in about five minutes. Fifteen minutes later, saba nigiri and hirame nigiri. 15-20 minutes later, another maki roll. At this point, I ask my wife "Is this how the high-end sushi restaurants in Japan do it?" No, it's not.
4) We ordered a couple of maki rolls and several orders of nigiri sushi. Two items, the rainbow roll and the tai nigiri, had not even come to us when the waitress prematurely brought us our check. We were like "Huh??!" She proceeded to tell us "oh, we are out of tai" - umm, that info would have been useful more than an hour earlier when we placed our order (or any time between then and the time the bill arrived...prematurely). I asked "What about the rainbow roll that we ordered?" She was like "Oh...I'm so sorry, did it not arrive? Let me go have that prepared" to which I quickly responded with, "Wait, how long is it going to take?? If it's going to take 20 minutes, we'll just pay now." The rainbow roll arrived in about 5 minutes; it was small but tasty, as expected...but our appetites was already on the way out the door.

I agree with many of the reviewers who say this is probably one of the better sushi joints in SF (ONLY as far as quality of fish is concerned), but the negatives far outweigh the positives for us. From now on, we'll probably stick with Ebisu in the neighborhood.
author: B. Earl K.

description: Fish is great and specials on the board are the way to go.  Their ONE selection of salt-yakitori is not bad (it's jidori or free-range chicken) and they also do a decent job frying things (think fried calamari, fried squid, etc).  But do yourself a favor and come either at 5pm when they open or on a non-peak weeknight, otherwise you'll have to wait a long time and you'll just get really frustrated.
author: P B.

description:
good sushi, mid range prices, small place. fancy to know what the catches of the day are? just ask them to bring the white board to your table and prop it on an empty seat. pretty cool. definitely a lesser known sushi restaurant in the inner sunset, so the crowd scene usually mellow.

if you like nestling at the bar, keep in mind it is VERY small, will seat only around 5-6 people and is usually stocked with appearance based quasi aristocratic/intellectual types.
author: Dayman D.

description: Not bad, not bad...not great, not great. I walked in here at about 7:15pm on a Thursday night to order a couple rolls to go. There were people seated but not every table was full. There were two (or one, i really couldn't tell what was up with one woman) waitresses scurrying around and a sushi chef with a couple helpers. I walk through the door, the "maybe waitress" asks "jus' 1?" I said, no I would like to place an order to-go. She tells me okay and walks away. I assume she is going to come back and take my order, but then she never leaves the kitchen again...hmmmmm, so I stood there looking like a moron for about 5-10 minit watching the other waitress try her hardest not to look me in the face. Finally, she takes my order. Then she gets my phone number because she says there are lots of orders and it could be a while. Fine. I am no fool, I knew what was going on...they were going to make everybody's orders who were seated in the restaurant before even starting on my two rolls. Bullshit. It took 40 minutes for me to get my food. And my fears were confirmed when I watched the girl who walked in and sat down 10 minutes after me, receive her food 10 minutes before me. Again, I call bullshit. Have to admit though, the sushi itself was pretty good...think I'll stick to Ebisu from now on, or maybe I'll just sit down inside the restaurant!
author: Amanda S.

description: sushi there are delicous and fresh!!! for real!! but then sushi came very slow and we wait each dish for three to five mintues.. our bill came to 50 bucks and me and my friends are not full... therefore we went to get crepes two blocks up....
author: Lily T.

description: I love this place for authentic, good, fresh sushi.  If you're looking for the cheesy 'everything and the sink' rolls...then this is not the place for you!  If you're looking for fresh fish and fish that melts in your mouth...then this is the place!  My fiance and I love love love sushi and will go anywhere for it, but now that we've found Kazu...this is our weekly sushi spot!  Kazu and his wife are so nice and accommodating that we feel it's our 'Cheers'.  This place is a no-brainer when it comes to great food!
author: Marsha L.

description: sushi kazu has very good service and the restaurant is also very clean. we had the chicken karage for appetizer and it was very tasty one of the best i've tried. then i had the hamachi dinner and the fish was super fresh and top quality. the various fish dinner was just as good. everything was extremely good from the raw fish dinners to the chicken karage and the miso soup. the only bad part was that the food took a little while to come out. i also liked their little touch that they give u a warm towel before u eat.
author: Cory Y.
